abstract: Delegates then heard formal statements by high-level representatives from more than 70 Parties, outlining positions and views on climate change negotiations and issues related to the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol. <Editor's Note: A complete collection of Plenary statements will soon be available online at: http://COP6.unfccc.int>

title: Ratification of the Protocol:
abstract: The EU, VISEGRAD GROUP, and numerous others supported ratification and entry into force of the Protocol in 2002.

title: UNFCCC and Protocol Commitments:
abstract: The G-77/CHINA expressed concern that most Annex I countries have failed to implement their commitments.

title: Policies and Measures (P&Ms):
abstract: DENMARK called for the strengthening of international cooperation for developing and applying effective P&Ms, and said those with negative impacts on greenhouse gas emissions should be phased out.

title: Kyoto Mechanisms:
abstract: Many countries reiterated the need for the mechanisms to be supplemental to domestic action.

title: Compliance:
abstract: JAPAN said disagreements over the compliance regime should not delay the Protocol's entry into force.

title: LULUCF
abstract: JAMAICA strongly supported an internationally-defined biome-based approach for forests.

title: Capacity building and technology transfer:
abstract: Many speakers stressed that issues such as technology transfer, capacity building, and adverse effects had to be recognized and addressed, with special attention given to the least developed countries (LDCs) and those most vulnerable to climate change.

title: STATEMENTS BY PARTIES
actors: Least Developed Countries|Group of 77 and China
topics: Pre-Kyoto|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Pre-Kyoto|Flexibility Mechanims|Technology Transfer
abstract: Delegates heard formal statements by high- level representatives from 34 Parties. <Editor's Note: A complete collection of Plenary Statements will soon be available at: http://COP-6.unfccc.int> Many speakers highlighted the importance of maintaining the environmental integrity of the Protocol.

title: INFORMAL HIGH-LEVEL PLENARY & CONSULTATIONS
abstract: Delegates convened in the morning for an informal high-level Plenary session to continue discussions and receive interim reports from the facilitators of informal negotiating groups formed around key issue 'clusters' or 'boxes.

title: BOX A - CAPACITY BUILDING, TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER, ADVERSE EFFECTS AND GUIDANCE TO THE GEF
actors: Umbrella Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds 1|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adaptation|Technology Transfer
abstract: The informal high-level Plenary held in the morning began with a report by co-facilitator Minister Mabudhafasi (South Africa) on progress made Tuesday on 'Box A' issues.

title: BOX B - MECHANISMS
abstract: During the morning informal high-level Plenary, co-facilitator Minister Kawaguchi (Japan) reported on progress made in the 'Box B' group.

title: BOX C - LULUCF
abstract: Negotiators involved in discussions on LULUCF met in the afternoon and again in the evening for informal consultations co-facilitated by Minister Carabias Lillo (Mexico) and Minister Miklós (Slovakia).

title: BOX D - COMPLIANCE, POLICIES AND MEASURES, AND ACCOUNTING, REPORTING AND REVIEW UNDER PROTOCOL ARTICLES 5, 7 AND 8
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Compliance and Enforcement|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: In the morning session of the informal high-level Plenary, participants engaged in an initial exchange of views on these issues.

title: CONCLUSION OF THE MEETING
abstract: Reflecting on the reports from co- facilitators and comments from negotiators, President Pronk noted the momentum generated.

title: INFORMAL HIGH-LEVEL PLENARY - MORNING SESSION
abstract: Delegates convened in the morning for an informal high-level Plenary session to hear reports by the facilitators on informal consultations that met on Wednesday night.

title: Technology transfer:
abstract: On technology transfer, it proposes the establishment of an intergovernmental consultative group of technical and scientific experts under SBSTA on the basis of equal geographical distribution.

title: Adverse effects:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: On adverse effects, the note outlines actions to be taken by Annex II Parties, including: initiating pilot/demonstration adaptation projects; undertaking adaptation projects where sufficient information is available in specified areas; and strengthening and establishing national and regional centers, as well as information networks for rapid response to extreme weather events. The note also proposes actions to address the impacts of response measures under Protocol Article 3.14.

title: BOX B Mechanisms:
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: The note proposes that the Executive Board comprise equal numbers from each UN regional group, plus one representative from the SIDS.

title: BOX C LULUCF:
topics: Post-Kyoto Agreements|forests|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: The note proposes that Parties apply the FAO definition of 'forest' under Article 3.3, taking national circumstances into consideration, and apply the IPCC definition for afforestation, reforestation and deforestation.

title: BOX D Policies and Measures (P&Ms):
abstract: The note proposes information exchange on P&Ms and submission of views on the meaning of demonstrable progress and the need for guidelines for reporting on this progress, with a view to having further consideration at COP- 7.

title: Compliance:
abstract: On consequences for non-compliance with Article 3.1 (assigned amounts - AAs), the note suggests that they be agreed in advance and consist of: subtraction of excess emissions from the AA of the subsequent commitment period against a penalty rate of 1.5 to 1.75; and submission of a compliance action plan.

title: INFORMAL HIGH-LEVEL PLENARY - NIGHT SESSION
abstract: COP-6 President Pronk opened the meeting at 12:30 am Friday.

title: BOX A - CAPACITY BUILDING, TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER, ADVERSE EFFECTS AND GUIDANCE TO THE GEF
abstract: Co-facilitators Ministers Mabudhafasi and Auken reported that there had been some progress on technology transfer and capacity building, while questions on the financial issue remained.

title: BOX B - MECHANISMS
abstract: Co-facilitator Minister Kawaguchi said there were too many issues to deal with.

title: BOX C - LULUCF
abstract: Minister Carabias Lillo said the informal group on LULUCF had split into two sub-groups the night before, with one group focusing on the analysis of Article 3.4 (additional activities), and the other on the inclusion of LULUCF activities under the CDM.

title: BOX D - COMPLIANCE, POLICIES AND MEASURES, AND ACCOUNTING, REPORTING AND REVIEW UNDER PROTOCOL ARTICLES 5, 7, AND 8
actors: Least Developed Countries|Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
topics: Adaptation|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: Minister Bjerke reported on the work carried out in the informal small groups.

title: NOTE BY THE PRESIDENT OF COP-6
abstract: Shortly before 8:00 pm, a Note by the President of COP-6 was distributed to delegates.

title: INTRODUCTION
abstract: In the introduction, the note states that it addresses key unresolved issues contained in the documents transmitted to the COP by the subsidiary bodies at the close of their thirteenth sessions on 18 November.

title: BOX A
abstract: Funding mechanisms and guidance to the GEF: President Pronk's note proposes creating an Adaptation Fund, a Convention Fund, and a Climate Resources Committee, as well as increasing resources for climate change funding. The Adaptation Fund would be a new fund under the GEF, created as a trust fund, with special consideration given to the needs of the LDCs and small island developing states (SIDs).

title: Capacity building:
abstract: The note proposes a framework to guide capacity building activities related to the UNFCCC and Protocol implementation, in order to assist non-Annex II Parties.

title: ADOPTION OF THE RULES OF PROCEDURE
abstract: On 13 November, COP-6 considered the rules of procedure.

title: ADOPTION OF AGENDA
abstract: On 13 November, COP-6 adopted its agenda, with the exception of item 5 on 'Second review of adequacy of Article 4.2(a) and (b) of the Convention,' which the G-77/China had proposed to amend to 'review of the adequacy of implementation of Article 4, paragraph 2(a) and (b) of the Convention' (FCCC/CP/2000/L.1/Add.1).

title: ELECTION OF OFFICERS OTHER THAN PRESIDENT
topics: IPCC Governance|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: In a COP-6 Plenary session held on Monday, 20 November, President Pronk reported that some regional groups had requested more time to finalize their bureau nominations.

title: ADMISSION OF OBSERVERS
abstract: On Monday, 13 November, COP-6 admitted as observers five intergovernmental organizations and 85 non- governmental organizations (FCCC/CP/2000/2).

title: DATE AND VENUE OF COP-7
abstract: On 25 November, COP-6 adopted a decision accepting with gratitude Morocco's offer to host COP-7 and deciding that COP-7 will be held in Marrakech from 29 October - 9 November 2001 (FCCC/CP/2000/1/Add.1).

title: CALENDAR OF MEETINGS OF CONVENTION BODIES
abstract: On 25 November, COP-6 addressed the issue of the calendar of meetings of the Convention bodies, and agreed to add the sessional periods for 2004.

title: ADOPTION OF THE REPORT ON CREDENTIALS
abstract: COP-6 adopted the report on credentials (FCCC/CP/2000/4) on 25 November.

title: REPORTS OF THE SUBSIDIARY BODIES
topics: Adaptation|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The subsidiary bodies to the UNFCCC met from 13-18 November, resuming their thirteenth sessions, which began in September in Lyon, France (SB-13 Part I).

title: ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: On Monday, 13 November, SBI Chair Ashe introduced documents containing greenhouse gas inventory data from Annex I Parties for 1990-98, and on the progress of the in-depth reviews of Annex I Parties' second national communications (FCCC/SBI/2000/INF.14, FCCC/SBI/2000/14, FCCC/SBI/2000/11, and FCCC/SBI/2000/INF.13).

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: On 13 November, delegates addressed the provision of financial and technical support to non-Annex I Parties and considered a document on the financial support provided by the GEF for the preparation of national communications (FCCC/SBI/2000/INF.8) and the report of the second meeting of the Consultative Group of Experts (FCCC/SBI/2000/16).

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: The Ad Hoc Group on the Berlin Mandate, established by COP-1, met between 1995 and 1997 to reach agreement on a further step in efforts to combat climate change.

title: REPORT OF THE GEF AS THE FINANCIAL MECHANISM
abstract: During the first week of negotiations, delegates met several times in contact group meetings and 'informal informal' consultations co-chaired by SBI Chair John Ashe and Kerry Groves (Australia) to consider draft text on additional guidance to the GEF.

title: SB-13 Part II:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: In the SBI meeting on Monday, 13 November, Chair Ashe introduced documents containing a report of the GEF to COP-6 on its activities under the financial mechanism (FCCC/CP/2000/3), and a review by the GEF of its climate change enabling activities (FCCC/CP/2000/3/Add.1).

title: Cross-cutting Financial Issues:
abstract: Cross-cutting financial issues relating to capacity building, technology transfer, adverse effects and guidance to the GEF were addressed by a group on financial issues, which was convened on 17 and 18 November.

title: COP-6 High-level Informal Discussions:
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: On Monday, 20 November, President Pronk outlined the 'crunch' issues on which agreement had not been reached.

title: President's Note:
abstract: In an attempt to progress the negotiations on this issue, on Thursday evening, 23 November, President Pronk distributed a Note, which proposed creating an Adaptation Fund, a Convention Fund, and a Climate Resources Committee, as well as increasing resources for climate change funding. The Adaptation Fund would be a new fund under the GEF, created as a trust fund, with special consideration given to the needs of the LDCs and SIDS.

title: Conclusion of COP-6 Part I:
abstract: Ministerial negotiations on President Pronk's Note took place throughout Friday and into Saturday.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING
abstract: During the first week of negotiations, delegates discussed issues related to capacity building in a contact group that divided into two sub-groups: one on countries with economies in transition (EITs) and one on developing countries.

title: SB-13 Part II:
abstract: During the opening SBI/SBSTA meeting on Monday, 13 November, SBSTA Chair Dovland recalled that the subsidiary bodies had agreed at a previous session to continue considering capacity building on the basis of two draft decisions, one for countries with economies in transition and one for developing countries.

title: Capacity Building in Countries with Economies in Transition:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: On Tuesday, 14 November, this contact group took up the draft decision and annexed draft framework on capacity building in EITs.

title: Capacity Building in Developing Countries:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation
abstract: Delegates began considering the Co-Chairs' paper containing a proposal for a draft decision and an annex outlining a capacity-building framework in developing countries in 'informal informal' meetings on 15 and 16 November.

title: THE BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION
abstract: The Fourth Conference of the Parties (COP-4) met in Buenos Aires, Argentina, in November 1998, to set out a work schedule for reaching agreement on the operational details of the Protocol and for strengthening implementation of the UNFCCC itself.

title: COP-6 High-level Informal Discussions:
abstract: During the informal high- level Plenary meetings held during the COP, this matter was considered under 'Box A' issues, as identified by President Pronk, which also included adverse effects and technology transfer.

title: President's Note:
abstract: Since the ministers were unable to reach agreement, President Pronk proposed in his Note to establish a framework to guide capacity-building activities related to UNFCCC and Protocol implementation, in order to assist non-Annex I Parties, as elaborated in the two draft decisions.

title: DEVELOPMENT AND TRANSFER OF TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: During the first week of negotiations, delegates met six times in contact group meetings as well as in 'informal informal' consultations, to consider the Co- Chairs' revised text on a draft framework to enhance meaningful and effective actions under UNFCCC Article 4.5 (development and transfer of technology).

title: SB-13 Part II:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer
abstract: At its first meeting on 13 November, SBSTA decided to reconvene the contact group co-chaired by Jean Cooper (Canada) and Oladapo Afolabi (Nigeria) established in Lyon.

title: COP-6 High-level Informal Discussions:
abstract: This issue was considered during the informal high-level Plenary meetings under President Pronk's 'Box A' cluster of issues, together with capacity building, adverse effects and the financial issues.

title: President's Note:
abstract: In his Note, President Pronk proposed the establishment of an intergovernmental consultative group of technical and scientific experts under SBSTA on the basis of equal geographical distribution.

title: ADVERSE EFFECTS
topics: Compliance and Enforcement|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: Implementation of Article 4.8 and 4.9 of the UNFCCC and matters relating to Protocol Article 3.14 were considered by delegates in relation to both the review of implementation of UNFCCC commitments and preparations for COP/MOP- 1.

title: SB-13 Part II:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: On Monday, 13 November, the joint SBI/SBSTA delegates considered reports of recent intersessional consultations and agreed to reconvene the contact group on this issue co-chaired by Bo Kjellén (Sweden) and Mohamad Reza Salamat (Iran) to continue consideration on the text of the draft decision(s). On Tuesday, 14 November, Co-Chair Salamat introduced to the contact group a draft proposal on the special considerations for LDCs, which he said could possibly replace the third section of the entirely bracketed draft decision(s) on adverse effects being considered in this contact group.

title: COP-6 High-level Informal Discussions:
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: On Monday, 20 November, President Pronk announced, in an informal high-level Plenary, that adverse effects was one of the 'crunch issues' for which agreement had not been reached on all elements.

title: President's Note:
topics: Compliance and Enforcement|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: On Thursday evening, COP-6 President Pronk presented a Note outlining proposals for a compromise agreement on the key unresolved issues.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR COP-6
abstract: COP-6 was preceded by numerous formal and informal meetings and consultations held during 1999 and 2000.

title: Conclusion of COP-6 Part I:
abstract: On Saturday, 25 November, the COP noted that no agreement had been reached and deferred consideration of this issue to its resumed session (FCCC/CP/2000/CRP.5).

title: ACTIVITIES IMPLEMENTED JOINTLY (AIJ)
abstract: At the joint SBI/SBSTA meeting on Monday, 13 November, SBSTA Chair Dovland said Parties had agreed, at a previous session, to defer consideration of the draft revised uniform reporting format to SB-14.

title: PROPOSAL TO AMEND UNFCCC ANNEXES I AND II
abstract: During the formal Plenary meeting on Monday, 20 November, Turkey, an observer State, called for its removal from the group of Annex II Parties and requested to be considered an Annex I Party with special circumstances.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLES 5, 7 AND 8
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Compliance and Enforcement|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Delegates considered guidelines under Protocol Articles 5 (methodological issues), 7 (communication of information) and 8 (review of information) in SBSTA meetings and a contact group co-chaired by Helen Plume (New Zealand) and Newton Paciornik (Brazil) that met during the first week.

title: LAND USE, LAND-USE CHANGE AND FORESTRY (LULUCF)
actors: Group of 77 and China|European Union|Environmental Integrity Group|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Post-Kyoto Agreements|forests|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: Text for decisions on LULUCF were considered during SBSTA-13 Part II in a contact group co-chaired by Halldor Thorgeirsson (Iceland) and Philip Gwage (Uganda) that convened five times during the first week, as well as in an informal Friends of the Chair group that met on 17 and 18 November.

title: MECHANISMS
actors: African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement|Flexibility Mechanims|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: During the first week, delegates discussed issues related to the Protocol mechanisms in three contact group meetings chaired by Kok Kee Chow (Malaysia), and in numerous closed 'informal informals.

title: COMPLIANCE
actors: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
countries: Canada|Tanzania|United States|Switzerland|New Zealand|Norway|Argentina|Saudi Arabia|Australia|Samoa|United Arab Emirates|India|China|Russian Federation|Japan|Poland
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Compliance and Enforcement|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: During SB-13 Part II, compliance under the Protocol was considered by joint SBSTA/SBI meetings on Monday, 13, and Saturday, 18 November, and several times by the Joint Working Group on Compliance (JWG) from Tuesday, 14, to Friday, 17 November.

title: IMPACT OF SINGLE PROJECTS ON EMISSIONS IN THE COMMITMENT PERIOD
abstract: During the first joint SBI/SBSTA session on Monday, 13 November, SBSTA Chair Dovland reminded delegates of the draft decision proposed by Iceland at COP-4 and said further consultations would be conducted by Ole Plougmann (Denmark) during the week.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL MATTERS
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: SBI considered the report on administrative and financial matters on Monday, 13 November.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: On Saturday, 25 November, COP-6 adopted a resolution forwarded for its consideration by SB-12, whereby it expresses solidarity with Mozambique and other countries in Southern Africa following the devastation caused by Cyclone Eline (FCCC/SBI/2000/5, Annex II).

title: SB-12
abstract: Work resumed at a formal level with the twelfth sessions of the UNFCCC subsidiary bodies (SB-12), held from 12-16 June 2000, in Bonn, and preceded by one week of informal meetings.

title: Statements by elected Heads of Government:
abstract: On Monday, 20 November, delegates in the COP-6 Plenary heard statements by Wim Kok, Prime Minister of the Netherlands, and Jacques Chirac, President of France.

title: Statements by other Parties:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation|Technology Transfer
abstract: On Tuesday, 22 November and Wednesday, 23 November, over 100 senior government representatives outlined their policies and positions on the climate change negotiations and issues related to the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol.

title: STATEMENTS BY OBSERVER STATES, INTERGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS AND UN BODIES
abstract: During a COP-6 Plenary session held on Monday afternoon, 21 November, delegates heard statements from 12 UN bodies, specialized agencies and related organizations, four intergovernmental organizations, 13 non-governmental organizations and one observer State.

title: STATEMENTS BY YOUTH REPRESENTATIVES
abstract: On Tuesday, 21 November, youth representatives from Kenya and the UK reported to COP-6 on the International Youth Conference held the previous week, which was attended by 118 young people from 61 countries, and urged all delegates to read and address the Youth Declaration.

title: HIGH-LEVEL SEGMENT - FORMAL STATEMENTS
abstract: From 20-24 November, delegates to COP-6 heard statements in Plenary from high-level representatives of more than 100 Parties, including three elected Heads of Government, four Vice Presidents, two Deputy Prime Ministers, and 63 Ministers.

title: INFORMAL HIGH-LEVEL PLENARY
abstract: At 2:00 pm on Saturday afternoon, 25 November, delegates met for the closing informal high-level Plenary.

title: FORMAL PLENARY
abstract: Following the informal high-level Plenary, President Pronk opened the formal closing Plenary of COP-6 Part I at 4:30 pm.

title: LULUCF
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: On the most visible issue - LULUCF - two 'crunch' questions in particular stalled progress: the inclusion within the first commitment period of additional activities under Protocol Articles 3.4 (seen by many Umbrella Group Parties as a precondition for ratifying the Protocol, and considered with great caution by the EU and G-77/China); and the issue of sinks in the CDM (on which there was fundamental division between the Umbrella Group and the EU, as well as among members of the G-77/China).

title: MECHANISMS
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: Another prominent source of disagreement relates to the operating rules and procedures on the Protocol mechanisms, with unresolved differences remaining particularly on supplementarity, CDM project eligibility, and modalities and rules for trading.

title: SB-13 PART I
abstract: Informal consultations and workshops were held during July and August 2000, followed by the first part of the thirteenth sessions of the subsidiary bodies (SB-13), held from 11-15 September 2000 in Lyon, France, and again preceded by a week of informal meetings.

title: FINANCE
abstract: Much of the media's coverage on the collapse of the talks has focused on the apparent inability of the EU and US to reach a compromise on sinks and supplementarity.

title: COMPLIANCE
abstract: On the issue of compliance, while the majority of Parties had expressed support for a 'strong' compliance system, the translation of this objective into legal and technical terms revealed divergent positions on issues such as: differentiating treatment of compliance for Annex I and non-Annex I Parties; enforcement consequences; the method of adoption of a compliance regime; and the composition of the compliance bodies.

title: WHAT SUNK THE COP?
abstract: If there was one word that dominated discussions at the Hague it was 'sinks' (known to climate change cognoscenti as 'LULUCF').

title: DRAWING A LINE IN THE SAND
abstract: In an attempt to secure political agreement on these key issues, Pronk produced a President's Note, on Thursday, 23 November, in which he proposed a 'balanced package' aimed at facilitating ratification of the Protocol, without unduly affecting its environmental integrity.

title: AT THE HELM IN THIS 'TITANIC ENDEAVOUR'
abstract: In what was perhaps an unfortunate mix of metaphors, a delegate speaking during negotiations on the mechanisms expressed confidence in Pronk's ability to successfully manage the 'Titanic endeavor' of 'navigating delegates through a sea of brackets.

title: CONCLUSION - 'THERE IS NO TIME TO LOSE'
abstract: For many observers, one of the lasting images from The Hague will be that of the Head of the US delegation, Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs Frank Loy, wiping cake from his face following an assault by a young activist.

title: INTERSESSIONAL CONSULTATIONS AFTER SB-13 PART I
abstract: Several informal meetings and consultations were held following SB-13.

title: COP-6 REPORT
actors: Least Developed Countries|Group of 77 and China|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Environmental Integrity Group
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: The Sixth Conference of the Parties (COP-6) to the UNFCCC officially opened on Monday morning, 13 November 2000.

title: STATUS OF RATIFICATION
abstract: On Monday, 13 November, the COP-6 Plenary received a report from the Secretariat on the status of ratification of the Convention and the Kyoto Protocol, and noted that the UNFCCC now had 183 Parties, and would have 185 Parties as of 6 December 2000.

title: VULNERABILITY AND ADAPTATION ASSESSMENT
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Yeshey Penjor (Bhutan) spoke on V&A assessments.

title: GREENHOUSE GAS ABATEMENT ISSUES
abstract: Kadio Ahossane (Côte d'Ivoire) discussed greenhouse gas abatement issues.

title: FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT
topics: Pre-Kyoto|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Emilio Sempris (Panama) described his country's work on inventories, V&A and mitigation options.

title: OVERVIEW OF IPCC TAR REPORT
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Graham Sem (UNFCCC) presented an overview of the IPCC Working Group II (Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability) TAR, explaining that the report used observations and model projections on global surface temperature increase and sea level rise, warming variation by region, with increases and decreases in precipitation and changes in variability of climate.

title: OVERVIEW OF REPORTS FROM REGIONAL WORKSHOPS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Philip Weech (The Bahamas) presented a report on the methodological, analytical and technical issues related to the greenhouse gas inventory identified in the CGE regional workshops held in 2000 in Mexico City, Bangkok and Nairobi.

title: GREENHOUSE GAS INVENTORIES
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Ayite-Lo Ajavon (Togo), Chair of the CGE, discussed national greenhouse gas inventories.

title: IMPACTS, VULNERABILITY AND ADAPTATION ASSESSMENTS
topics: Reasons for Concern|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Isabelle Niang- Diop (Senegal) described the achievements in the initial national communications under the theme of V&A assessment.

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: The Ad Hoc Group on the Berlin Mandate, established by COP-1, met between 1995 and 1997 to reach agreement on a further step in efforts to combat climate change.

title: GREENHOUSE GAS ABATEMENT ISSUES
abstract: Vute Wangwacharakul (Thailand) presented an overview of the reported greenhouse gas abatement options.

title: EDUCATION, PUBLIC AWARENESS AND RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Julia Martinez (Mexico) discussed the reported information on education, public awareness and research and systematic observation.

title: CROSS CUTTING ISSUES
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Networking and Information: Philip Weech (The Bahamas) presented on cross-cutting issues raised in the regional workshops.

title: GREENHOUSE GAS INVENTORY WORKING GROUP
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: This working group was chaired by Ayite-Lo Ajavon, Chair of the CGE.

title: ADAPTATION AND VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT WORKING GROUP
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Compliance and Enforcement|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The V&A assessment working group was chaired by Isabelle Niang-Diop.

title: GREENHOUSE GAS ABATEMENT WORKING GROUP
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: This working group was chaired by Vute Wangwacharakul.

title: CROSS-CUTTING ISSUES WORKING GROUP
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The working group on cross- cutting issues was chaired Julia Martinez (Mexico).

title: THE BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION
abstract: The Fourth Conference of the Parties (COP-4) met in Buenos Aires, Argentina, in November 1998, to set out a work schedule for reaching agreement on the operational details of the Protocol and for strengthening implementation of the UNFCCC itself.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR COP-6
abstract: COP-6 was preceded by numerous formal and informal meetings and consultations held during 1999 and 2000.

title: SB-13 PART I
abstract: Informal consultations and workshops were held during July and August 2000, followed by the first part of the thirteenth sessions of the subsidiary bodies (SB-13), held from 11-15 September 2000 in Lyon, France, and again preceded by a week of informal meetings.

title: INTERSESSIONAL CONSULTATIONS AFTER SB-13 PART I
abstract: Several informal meetings and consultations were held following SB-13.

title: COP-6
abstract: COP-6 met in The Hague, the Netherlands, from 13-25 November 2000.

title: GREENHOUSE GAS INVENTORIES
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Clifford Mahlung (Jamaica) presented Jamaica's experience in preparing its national greenhouse gas inventory.

title: Decision 1:
abstract: Several participants noted that the decision on the continuation of comprehensive assessments and special reports can be regarded as one, and that both types of reports are needed, and that a balance should be maintained between the different sets of reports.

title: Decision 2:
abstract: On the intervals between the comprehensive assessments, some countries favored longer intervals in order to have more new information to build on.

title: Decision 3:
abstract: The issue of whether the working groups should be staggered is an item for the new Bureau to decide.

title: Decision 4:
abstract: Many participants supported shorter reports and SPMs.

title: Decision 5:
abstract: Participants underscored that uncertainties identified in the preparation of the assessment reports could be addressed by focused special reports.

title: Decision 6:
topics: IPCC Governance|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: On the management and approval process for special reports, several delegates preferred the option used most frequently to date, which involved the reports being assigned to the most appropriate working group co-chairs and associated Technical Support Units, with approval in a plenary session of the working group.

title: Decision 7:
abstract: The fact that the IPCC had been requested to prepare a technical paper for a convention other than the UNFCCC was considered to indicate the success of the IPCC, and also to provide a challenge for the IPCC.

title: Decision 8:
abstract: On whether current procedures should apply for all special reports, or that exceptions be made to respond to the short-term needs of the Parties to the UNFCCC and the Kyoto Protocol, one delegate said that rules may need to be reconsidered with regard to methodological guidelines, especially if the Task Force on National Greenhouse Gas Inventories becomes a new working group.

title: Decision 9:
abstract: On the structure of the three working groups, one delegate said their work should be better integrated, and that lessons could be learned from work on cross-cutting issues under the TAR.

title: Decision 10:
abstract: Several delegates supported the continuation of the current structure of the Bureau.

title: KEY IPCC REPORTS
abstract: The IPCC completed its first comprehensive assessment of climate change compiled in the First Assessment Report (FAR) in 1990, and its Second Assessment Report (SAR) in 1995.

title: Conclusion:
abstract: In concluding, Chair Watson summarized the views expressed by participants.

title: Consideration of a Request for a technical paper on the interlinkages between climate change and biological diversity:
abstract: This agenda item was addressed on Wednesday, 4 April.

title: IPCC Work Programme and Budget for 2002-2004:
abstract: Leo Meyer, Co-Chair of the Financial Task Team, introduced the agenda item on the budget on Friday, 6 April.

title: Task Force on Climate Scenarios for Impact Assessment:
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: This agenda item was considered on Friday morning, 6 April.

title: LULUCF in National Greenhouse Gas Inventories, including terms of reference for the Task Force:
abstract: This item was considered on Friday, 6 April.

title: IPCC Communication Strategy:
abstract: This agenda item was addressed at the end of the day on Thursday, 5 April.

title: Scoping for a special report on key interactions between climate change and sustainable development:
abstract: On Thursday evening, 5 April, a proposal was introduced for a special report on climate change and sustainable development addressing key interactions, as well as a proposal for a scoping/expert meeting to prepare the ground for this special report.

title: Critical areas of priority for future IPCC work:
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: A one-hour discussion on this topic was held on Friday, 6 April.

title: IPCC-UNFCCC Interaction:
abstract: Reporting on the outcome of a joint working group session between the IPCC and the UNFCCC, Chair Watson noted that several issues that were of interest to the IPCC had been identified, some of which required inputs from the IPCC.

title: THIRD ASSESSMENT REPORT
abstract: The Third Assessment Report (TAR) addresses policy-relevant scientific, technical, and socio- economic dimensions of climate change.

title: ADOPTION OF THE REPORTS OF THE TAR
topics: Reasons for Concern|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Working Group I: Working Group I met from 17-20 January 2001, in Shanghai, China, to finalize and adopt its part of the TAR.

title: INTRODUCTION TO THE UNFCCC
topics: Reasons for Concern|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Climate change is considered one of the most serious threats to the sustainability of the world's environment, human health and well-being, and the global economy.

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: In 1995, the Ad Hoc Group on the Berlin Mandate was established by COP-1 to reach agreement on a further step in efforts to combat climate change.

title: THE BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION
abstract: COP-4 met in Buenos Aires, Argentina, in November 1998, to set out a work schedule for reaching agreement on the operational details of the Protocol and for strengthening implementation of the UNFCCC itself.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR COP-6
abstract: Numerous formal and informal meetings and consultations were held during 1999 and 2000 to help lay the foundations for an agreement at COP-6.

title: COP-6 PART I
abstract: COP-6 and the resumed thirteenth sessions of the UNFCCC's subsidiary bodies were held in The Hague, the Netherlands, from 13-25 November 2000.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR COP-6 PART II
abstract: A number of meetings and consultations have taken place since COP-6 Part I in an effort to get negotiations back on track.

title: RECENT DEVELOPMENTS
abstract: In March 2001, the US administration declared its opposition to the Protocol, stating that it believed it to be 'fatally flawed', as it would damage its economy and exempted developing countries from fully participating. Since the US announcement, the EU has sent diplomatic missions to several Parties, including Japan, Australia, Canada, the Russian Federation and Iran, in an effort to maintain support for the Protocol and its entry into force by 2002.

title: NEGOTIATING TEXTS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: Negotiations will be held on the basis of negotiating texts carried over from COP-6 Part I (see FCCC/CP/2000/5/Add.3, 'Part Three: Texts forwarded to resumed sixth session by the COP at the first part of its 6th Session', Volumes I - V).

title: LULUCF
abstract: The text outlines a complex 'compromise' package, including text on accounting rules for eligible activities under Protocol Article 3.4 (additional human activities such as forest management and agricultural land management) that involve: compensation of possible Article 3.3 (afforestation, reforestation and deforestation) debits through accounting for forest management of up to 8.2 megatons of carbon annually per Party, with no discount applied to Article 3.4 credits up to this level; an 85 percent discount on forest management activities beyond the first tier; and 'net-net accounting' for agricultural management. Compliance: The consolidated text tackles issues such as the respective roles of the enforcement and compliance branches, as well as the legally binding consequences of non-compliance.

title: OPENING PLENARY
abstract: COP-6 President Jan Pronk opened the resumed COP-6, noting that participants are meeting to resolve outstanding issues from the first part of COP-6 in The Hague in November 2000.

title: LULUCF
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Environmental Integrity Group
abstract: Co-Chair Dovland encouraged the LULUCF negotiating group to exchange views on Protocol Article 3.4 (additional activities).

title: FINANCIAL ISSUES
actors: Least Developed Countries|European Union|Group of 77 and China
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds 1|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adaptation|Technology Transfer
abstract: The negotiating group on financial issues, including capacity building, technology transfer, adaptation, UNFCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 and Protocol Articles 2.3 and 3.14 (adverse effects), met in the afternoon to consider the negotiating text on capacity building and the text on guidance to the financial mechanism.

title: MECHANISMS
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims|Technology Transfer
abstract: The mechanisms group met in the evening, to discuss text on the modalities and procedures for the CDM.

title: COMPLIANCE
topics: Compliance and Enforcement|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: Co-Chair Slade suggested that delegates focus on five issues: consequences applied by the enforcement branch; composition; appeal; relationship between the Compliance Committee and the COP/MOP; and principles.

title: MECHANISMS
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: The negotiating group on mechanisms met in the morning, and completed its first consideration of the negotiating texts.

title: LULUCF
abstract: This group met in afternoon and evening sessions.

title: FINANCIAL ISSUES
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: This group met in afternoon and evening sessions.

title: MECHANISMS
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: The mechanisms group met in the morning and afternoon to identify and discuss the unresolved technical and political issues.

title: COMPLIANCE
topics: Compliance and Enforcement|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: On Wednesday afternoon, delegates heard a report from Chair Romero of the working group on consequences applied under the enforcement branch and the related issue of the legal basis for adoption.

title: FINANCIAL ISSUES
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: This group met in morning and evening sessions.

title: LULUCF
abstract: Delegates discussed Principles governing LULUCF activities.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
abstract: Delegates met in a morning Plenary session to address organizational matters and hear the reports from the Co-Chairs of the four negotiating groups.

title: REPORTS OF THE NEGOTIATING GROUPS
abstract: The Co-Chairs of the negotiating groups then presented their reports.

title: Finance:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: Co-Chair Ashe reported on the status of the work on capacity building, technology transfer, guidance to the GEF, and funding issues.

title: Land use, land-use change and forestry (LULUCF):
abstract: Co-Chair Gwage reported that the group had identified and made progress on three technical issues.

title: Mechanisms:
abstract: Co-Chair Estrada presented a list of technical and political issues that need to be resolved.

title: Compliance:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: Co-Chair Slade said the compliance report identified six outstanding issues.

title: HIGH-LEVEL SEGMENT
actors: Group of 77 and China|European Union|Environmental Integrity Group|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Pre-Kyoto|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Compliance and Enforcement|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: COP-6 President Pronk welcomed participants to the ceremonial opening of the High-Level Segment of the conference.

title: INFORMAL HIGH-LEVEL PLENARY
abstract: President Pronk opened the first meeting of the Informal High- Level Plenary on Thursday evening, stressing that participants are here to resolve the political issues related to the BAPA.

title: PLENARY
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Environmental Integrity Group|Group of 77 and China
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: Delegates met late morning in a Plenary session to receive information on the process for the high-level segment.

title: MAIN NEGOTIATING GROUP
abstract: The main negotiating group of ministers and other high-level officials began their work early afternoon, discussing the options for key issues set out under the Note by the Co-Chairs of the negotiating groups.

title: FINANCE
abstract: Participants began by discussing the finance section of the Co-Chairs' Note.

title: MECHANISMS
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement|Mitigation|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: Negotiations commenced mid-afternoon on the fourteen issues relating to mechanisms outlined in the Co-Chairs' Note.

title: LULUCF
abstract: Delegates began discussing this issue Friday evening.

title: LATE NIGHT PLENARY
abstract: Shortly after midnight Friday night, President Pronk reported back to participants, noting that some good work had been done during the day's ministerial negotiations.

title: INFORMAL DRAFTING GROUP ON CDM TECHNICAL ISSUES
abstract: The informal drafting group on CDM technical issues, chaired by Jose Domingos Gonzales Miguez (Brazil), completed its discussions Friday.

title: SATURDAY - FIRST MEETING
topics: Compliance and Enforcement|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Compliance and Enforcement|Technology Transfer
abstract: In a mid-afternoon meeting of the President's Group - a single, main plenary of Ministers and other senior officials - President Pronk updated participants on progress in consultations held earlier Saturday on the issues of finance, mechanisms, LULUCF and compliance. Secretary of State Philippe Roch (Switzerland) reported on the consultations on finance.

title: SATURDAY - SECOND MEETING
abstract: Late evening Saturday, President Pronk reported again to the Group, observing 'increasing consensus' following high-level substantive discussions held Friday and Saturday.

title: SUNDAY MEETING
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Environmental Integrity Group|Group of 77 and China
abstract: In a briefing to the Group held at 5:00 pm Sunday, President Pronk stated that, in spite of numerous expressions of concern, the EU, the Transcaucasian Group, CG-11, and the Environmental Integrity Group had expressed their willingness to accept the proposal as it stands, provisional on other countries not demanding amendments. President Pronk noted that several members of the Umbrella Group had expressed concerns, particularly on finance-related issues and compliance.

title: MONDAY MEETING
abstract: At 12:30 am Monday, 23 July, President Pronk reconvened the Group.

title: PLENARY
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Environmental Integrity Group
topics: Adaptation|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: At 11:55 am Monday, 23 July, delegates reconvened in a Plenary session of the COP.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
abstract: The SBI adopted its agenda and the list of NGOs recommended to participate in its work as observers.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL MATTERS
topics: UNFCCC Functioning|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: On administrative and financial matters, SBI first considered the financial performance for 2000-2001.

title: REPORTS ON INTER-SESSIONAL ACTIVITIES
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: On reports on inter- sessional activities, SBI considered the work of the Consultative Group of Experts (CGE) on National Communications from Parties not included in Annex I.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
abstract: Delegates adopted the SBSTA agenda.

title: COOPERATION WITH RELEVANT INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS
abstract: Chair Dovland noted ongoing initiatives between the UNFCCC and the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), including: a CBD discussion note and responses submitted by the UNFCCC Parties; a CBD Ad Hoc Technical Expert Group to carry out a pilot assessment on advice to integrate biodiversity into UNFCCC implementation; and a proposed joint liaison group between the two Secretariats.

title: REPORTS ON INTER-SESSIONAL ACTIVITIES
abstract: On emissions resulting from fuel used in international transportation, the Secretariat highlighted inter-sessional work as contained in a joint report with the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and the International Maritime Organization.

title: BRAZILIAN PROPOSAL
abstract: On Brazil's proposal on reductions toward an overall emission ceiling for Annex I Parties allocated on the basis of each Party's relative share of responsibility for climate change, Chair Dovland said a workshop had been held to identify scientific and methodological aspects of the proposal.

title: POLICIES AND MEASURES
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: On 'best practices' in policies and measures among Annex I Parties, Chair Dovland noted Party views submitted on a proposed workshop's Terms of Reference (TOR), which will be determined at the current SBSTA session.

title: PLENARY
abstract: In a late-afternoon Plenary, COP-6 President Pronk explained that the remaining negotiations at the resumed COP-6 would be based on The Hague text and the consolidated negotiating text (the 'Pronk text'), while incorporating the political agreements reached by the Ministers on Monday, 23 July.

title: PLENARY
abstract: Delegates convened in a delayed Plenary session late afternoon, following intensive closed negotiations throughout the day between President Pronk and various delegations to resolve outstanding issues relating to the adoption of the political decision, and organizational matters.

title: ADOPTION OF THE POLITICAL DECISION
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Environmental Integrity Group
abstract: President Pronk presented the political decision on Implementation of the Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA) (FCCC/CP/2001/L.7) for formal adoption by the COP.

title: ORGANIZATION OF WORK
abstract: President Pronk proposed that delegates proceed with their remaining work in the previously established negotiating groups on finance, LULUCF, mechanisms, compliance and Protocol Articles 5 (methodological issues), 7 (communication of information) and 8 (review of information).

title: FINANCE
abstract: The negotiating group on finance met in the evening to discuss a revised version of the informal paper on implementation of UNFCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 (adverse effects).

title: MECHANISMS
abstract: The mechanisms negotiating group, co-chaired by Raul Estrada and Kok Kee Chow, met in the evening to hear feedback from the two informal technical sub-groups established on Wednesday, 18 July, and to consider a consolidated text on the CDM.

title: COMPLIANCE
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: Negotiating group Co-Chair Neroni Slade said the Co- Chairs had prepared a non-paper, under the authority of President Pronk, that they hoped would assist delegates in their further work.

title: LULUCF
abstract: Co-Chair Harald Dovland informed delegates that the task ahead for the negotiating group was the development of decisions on LULUCF, and noted the limited time available.

title: INFORMAL CONSULTATIONS
abstract: Delegates met in a contact group convened under the SBI to consider the programme budget for the biennium 2002-2003.

title: MECHANISMS
abstract: This group met in the morning to consider the Co- Chairs' non-paper, which is a consolidation of the political decision, The Hague text, the Pronk text, and text agreed in the technical working groups.

title: FINANCE
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: The negotiating group on finance met in several sessions throughout Thursday to address outstanding text for draft decisions on UNFCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 and Protocol Article 3.14 (adverse effects), technology transfer and funding.

title: Adverse Effects:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: In the morning, Co-Chair Tsering introduced the informal paper on Article 4.8 and 4.9.

title: Funding:
abstract: Parties met in an informal group Thursday afternoon and evening to draft decisions on funding under the GEF and under the special climate change fund, the adaptation fund, and other bilateral and multilateral sources.

title: Technology Transfer:
abstract: The informal group concluded its work, clearing all remaining brackets.

title: COMPLIANCE
topics: Compliance and Enforcement|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: During a morning meeting, Co-Chair Slade suggested that delegates proceed through the Co-Chairs' non-paper on procedures and mechanisms on compliance under the Protocol.

title: LULUCF
abstract: The negotiating group met in afternoon and evening sessions, with a smaller drafting group convening throughout the day.

title: COOPERATION WITH RELEVANT INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS
abstract: A contact group convened in the afternoon to discuss and approve draft conclusions on cooperation with relevant international organizations, focusing on text regarding cooperation with other conventions.

title: CONSULTATIVE GROUP OF EXPERTS
abstract: Delegates convened in the afternoon for a Friends of the SBI Chair meeting to consider information contained in a preliminary report of the Consultative Group of Experts.

title: ELECTION OF OFFICERS OTHER THAN THE PRESIDENT
topics: IPCC Governance|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The COP elected its Bureau members during COP-6 Part I, with the exception of a second Vice-President to be nominated by the Asian Group.

title: ADOPTION OF THE REPORT ON CREDENTIALS
abstract: The resumed COP-6 adopted the report on credentials of representatives (FCCC/CP/2001/3) on Friday, 27 July.

title: AN OVERVIEW OF NEGOTIATIONS ON THE KEY ISSUES
abstract: From 16-18 July, delegates met in closed negotiating groups, which aimed to identify the key political issues to be resolved by ministers and high-level officials.

title: High-level Segment (19-23 July):
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: On Thursday, 19 July, the high- level segment of COP-6 Part II began, with ministers and other senior government officials in attendance.

title: Bonn Agreement:
abstract: The political decision was approved by ministers in a plenary session held Monday, and formally adopted by the COP on Wednesday evening, 25 July (FCCC/CP/2001/L.7), after disputes relating to 'technical' and 'editorial' changes made to the text Monday night had been resolved.

title: Political Declaration:
abstract: Discussion over the weekend also resulted in a Political Declaration by the EU, Canada, Iceland, Norway, New Zealand and Switzerland on funding for developing countries.

title: Post-Bonn Agreement Negotiations:
abstract: During the remainder of the second week, delegates agreed to resume in their negotiating groups in an attempt to clear the remaining brackets in all outstanding texts held over from The Hague, so as to reflect the Bonn Agreement.

title: FINANCIAL ISSUES
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer
abstract: The negotiations on financial issues addressed capacity building, technology transfer, adaptation, UNFCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 and Protocol Articles 2.3 and 3.14 (adverse effects), and funding.

title: Bonn Agreement:
abstract: The political decision agreed on Monday, 23 July, and formally adopted by the COP on Wednesday, 25 July, contains five sections related to the financial issues.

title: Funding under the UNFCCC:
abstract: The COP agrees that Annex II Parties, and other Annex I Parties that are in a position to do so, should provide funding to meet the commitments under UNFCCC Article 4.1 (commitments), 4.3 (funding), 4.4 (adaptation), 4.5 (technology transfer), 4.8 and 4.9 (adverse effects) through the GEF replenishment, the proposed special climate change fund, and bilateral and multilateral channels.

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: In 1995, the Ad Hoc Group on the Berlin Mandate was established by COP-1 to reach agreement on a further step in efforts to combat climate change.

title: Funding under the Kyoto Protocol:
abstract: The COP agrees that appropriate modalities for burden sharing need to be developed.

title: Development and Transfer of Technologies:
abstract: The COP agrees to establish an Expert Group on Technology Transfer comprised of 20 experts: three from each region of non-Annex I Parties; one from the Small Island Developing States (SIDS); seven from Annex I Parties; and three from relevant international organizations.

title: Implementation of UNFCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 and Protocol Articles 2.3 and 3.14:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: The COP agrees that the implementation of identified activities in response to adverse effects of climate change be supported through the GEF, the proposed special climate change fund, and other bilateral and multilateral sources.

title: Matters relating to Protocol Article 3.14:
abstract: The COP recognizes that minimizing the impact of the implementation of Protocol Article 3.1 (quantitative emissions commitments) is a development concern affecting both developed and developing countries.

title: Post-Bonn Agreement Negotiations:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: Based on the political guidance provided by the Bonn Agreement, the negotiating group on finance resumed its work on the draft decisions forwarded from The Hague to address outstanding text for draft decisions on adverse effects, technology transfer and funding.

title: Draft Decisions forwarded to COP-7:
abstract: The eight draft decisions completed on financial issues were the only ones of the four main negotiating groups on which consensus had been achieved.

title: Capacity Building:
abstract: The draft decision on capacity building in developing countries (FCCC/CP/2001/L.2) requests the GEF to report on its progress in support of the implementation of the capacity- building framework, and urges an operating entity of the financial mechanism to adopt a streamlined and expedited approach in financing activities of the framework.

title: Guidance to the GEF:
abstract: This draft decision (FCCC/CP/2001/L.4/Rev.1) states that the GEF should provide financial resources to developing country Parties, in particular to the LDCs and SIDS, including for implementing Stage II adaptation activities and establishing pilot or demonstration projects to show how adaptation planning and assessment can be translated into projects.

title: Development and Transfer of Technologies:
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Technology Transfer
abstract: The draft decision (FCCC/CP/2001/L.10) establishes an expert group on technology transfer and requests the GEF to provide financial support through the special climate change fund for the implementation of the framework annexed to the draft decision.

title: Adverse Effects:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Parties agreed to separate decisions on UNFCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9, and Protocol Article 3.14 (adverse effects).

title: THE BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION
abstract: COP-4 met in Buenos Aires, Argentina, in November 1998, to set out a schedule for reaching agreement on the operational details of the Protocol and for strengthening implementation of the UNFCCC itself.

title: Funding:
abstract: The draft decision on funding under the UNFCCC (FCCC/CP/2001/L.14) states that: there is a need for funding that is new and additional to GEF and multilateral and bilateral funding; predictable funding should be available to non-Annex I Parties; and a special climate change fund should be established.

title: MECHANISMS
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: Delegates met from 16-18 July in a closed negotiating group chaired by Raúl Estrada-Oyuela (Argentina) and Kok Kee Chow (Malaysia).

title: Bonn Agreement:
abstract: The political agreement on mechanisms addresses: principles, nature and scope; JI; CDM; and emissions trading.

title: Principles, Nature and Scope:
abstract: The text on principles, nature and scope provides for, inter alia, issues relating to equity, supplementarity, share of proceeds and eligibility.

title: JI and the CDM:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Extension of the Kyoto protocol|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: The COP agrees that it is the host Party's prerogative to confirm whether JI/CDM project activities assist in achieving sustainable development, and that Annex I Parties 'refrain' from using Emission Reduction Units (ERUs)/CERs generated from nuclear facilities to meet Article 3.1 commitments.

title: Emissions Trading:
abstract: On emissions trading, the COP agrees to recommend to the COP/MOP that each Annex I Party shall maintain in its national registry a commitment period reserve that should not drop below 90% of the Party's assigned amount, calculated in terms of Protocol Article 3.7 (individual assigned amounts) and 3.8 (base-year) or 100% of five times its most recently reviewed inventory, whichever is lowest.

title: Post-Bonn Agreement Negotiations:
abstract: Following approval of the political agreement on mechanisms, the negotiating group on mechanisms reconvened on Wednesday and Thursday, 25-26 July, to address the remaining technical issues.

title: Draft Decisions forwarded to COP-7:
abstract: The draft decisions to be considered further at COP-7 include: a draft decision on principles, nature and scope of the mechanisms pursuant to Articles 6, 12 and 17; a draft decision on guidelines for the implementation of Article 6, including an annex setting out the guidelines; a draft decision on modalities and procedures for a clean development mechanism, as defined in Article 12, including an annex setting out these modalities and procedures, and several appendices; and a draft decision on modalities, rules and guidelines for emissions trading, including an annex.

title: LAND USE, LAND-USE CHANGE AND FORESTRY (LULUCF)
abstract: LULUCF was considered in a closed negotiating group co-chaired by Harald Dovland (Norway) and Philip Gwage (Uganda) from 16-18 July.

title: Bonn Agreement:
abstract: The section on LULUCF includes a paragraph affirming eight governing principles for the treatment of LULUCF activities: treatment on the basis of sound science; use of consistent methodologies over time for estimation and reporting of activities; consistency with the aim of Protocol Article 3.1 (quantified emissions commitments); non-inclusion in accounting of 'mere presence' of carbon stocks; contribution to biodiversity conservation and sustainable use of natural resources; accounting that does not imply transfer of commitments to a future commitment period; accounting at the appropriate time for the reversal of a removal of carbon from the atmosphere; and exclusion of windfall effects from accounting. The decision on LULUCF proposes that the Protocol Article 3.3 definitions of 'forest,' 'afforestation,' 'reforestation' and 'deforestation' are based on changes in land use.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR COP-6
abstract: Numerous formal and informal meetings and consultations were held during 1999 and 2000 to help lay the foundations for an agreement at COP-6.

title: Draft decisions forwarded to COP-7:
abstract: The draft decisions on LULUCF (FCCC/CP/2001/L.11/Rev.1) incorporate the Bonn Agreement and comprise a decision, which, inter alia: requests SBSTA to investigate possible biome-specific forest definitions and to develop definitions and modalities for including LULUCF activities under the CDM; and invites the IPCC to elaborate methods to estimate, measure, monitor and report changes in carbon stocks as relevant to Articles 3.3 and 3.4 and LULUCF under Articles 6 and 12, and to prepare a report on good practice guidance and uncertainty management. The draft decisions on LULUCF also include a COP/MOP-1 decision.

title: COMPLIANCE
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: Delegates met on Tuesday and Wednesday, 17-18 July, in a closed negotiating group co-chaired by Harald Dovland (Norway) and Tuiloma Neroni Slade (Samoa).

title: Bonn Agreement:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: The Bonn Agreement covers eight aspects of the compliance system.

title: Draft Decision forwarded to COP-7:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Compliance and Enforcement|Technology Transfer
abstract: The draft decision contains a draft COP decision, including a draft COP/MOP-1 decision, and an annex. The draft COP decision: decides to adopt the procedures and mechanisms on compliance under the Protocol annexed thereto; recommends that COP/MOP-1 adopt such procedures and mechanisms in terms of Protocol Article 18; and recommends that COP/MOP-1 adopt the following draft decision: COP/MOP-1 confirms the COP decision and brings the procedures and mechanisms on compliance under the Protocol into operation. The annex constitutes the procedures and mechanisms on compliance under the Protocol and includes the elements of the Bonn Agreement on compliance outlined above.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLES 5, 7 AND 8
abstract: Due to time constraints, issues relating to national systems, adjustments and guidelines under Protocol Articles 5 (methodological issues), 7 (communication of information) and 8 (review of information) were formally only addressed in the context of the COP's organizational matters.

title: Draft Decisions forwarded to COP-7:
abstract: During the final Plenary, the COP took note of the draft decisions on national systems, adjustments and guidelines under Articles 5, 7 and 8 (CP/2000/5/ Add.3 (Vol.

title: ACTIVITIES IMPLEMENTED JOINTLY (AIJ)
abstract: This issue was supposed to be taken up by the SBSTA and the COP.

title: Draft Decision forwarded to COP-7:
abstract: The draft decision takes note of the fourth synthesis report on AIJ and of the draft revised uniform reporting format.

title: POLICIES AND MEASURES
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This matter was taken up by the SBSTA on Tuesday, 24 July.

title: Draft Decision forwarded to COP-7:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: During its final Plenary, the COP further agreed on a draft decision (FCCC/CP/2001/2/Add.5) to be forwarded to COP-7 for adoption in its current format.

title: COP-6 PART I
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Compliance and Enforcement|Technology Transfer
abstract: COP-6 and the resumed thirteenth sessions of the UNFCCC's subsidiary bodies were held in The Hague, the Netherlands, from 13-25 November 2000.

title: IMPACT OF SINGLE PROJECTS ON EMISSIONS IN THE COMMITMENT PERIOD
abstract: Due to time constraints, this issue was not discussed in-depth during SBSTA.

title: Draft Decision forwarded to COP-7:
abstract: The draft decision defines a single project and sets the guidelines for reporting CO2 emissions from a single project that has come into operation since 1990.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR COP/MOP-1 AND REVIEW OF UNFCCC COMMITMENTS AND PROVISIONS
topics: National Communications and Inventories|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: The critical issues addressed during the resumed Sixth Conference of the Parties related to two agenda items: review of the implementation of commitments and of other provisions of the UNFCCC; and preparations for the first session of the Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol (COP/MOP-1).

title: Final Decision:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Implementation|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The decision (FCCC/CP/2001/L.8) was adopted by the COP on Friday, 27 July.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL MATTERS
abstract: Delegates took up the matter of the institutional linkage of the UNFCCC Secretariat to the United Nations in the SBI on 24 and 27 July, and agreed to recommend to the COP a draft decision on this matter based on a Note by the Executive Secretary.

title: Final Conclusion:
abstract: The text, as adopted, recognizes that cleaner or less greenhouse gas emitting energy, particularly renewables, hydro, geothermal and natural gas, can promote environmental benefits to meet the objects of the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol, and optimize the uptake of cleaner or less greenhouse gas emitting energy.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: During the COP Plenary held Friday, 27 July, the COP considered draft conclusions proposed by Canada (FCCC/CP/2001/CRP.13) relating to its offer to hold an informal meeting on optimizing the uptake of cleaner or less greenhouse gas emitting energy, and inviting the Secretariat to convene a workshop on this issue prior to COP-8, and SBSTA-16 to develop recommendations for COP-8 to consider. Several countries, including Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Algeria, expressed concern at the lack of time to consider the proposal, and suggested considering the Canadian proposal at COP-7.

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR IMPLEMENTATION
abstract: On Tuesday, 24 July, the SBI, chaired by John Ashe (Antigua and Barbuda), adopted its agenda.

title: Reports on Inter-sessional Activities:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Delegates considered reports on inter-sessional activities on 24 and 27 July (FCCC/SBI/2001/L.1).

title: Administrative and Financial Matters:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: SBI considered the financial performance for 2000-2001 on 24 and 27 July.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR COP-6 PART II
abstract: A number of meetings and consultations were convened after COP-6 Part I in an effort to get negotiations back on track.

title: Other Matters:
abstract: The SBI took note of a proposed workshop on adaptation planned for the last quarter of 2001, to be convened by AOSIS.

title: Adoption of the Report:
abstract: The SBI adopted the report on its fourteenth session on Friday morning, 27 July (FCCC/SBI/2001/L.1).

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL ADVICE
abstract: The fourteenth session of the SBSTA began its work on Tuesday, 24 July, chaired by Harald Dovland (Norway).

title: Reports on Inter-sessional Activities:
abstract: Delegates considered this issue on 24 and 27 July, and took note of, or adopted conclusions on: emissions resulting from fuel use in international transportation; methods and tools to evaluate impacts and adaptation; issues related to emissions from forest harvesting and wood products; progress related to a technology information system; and UNFCCC Article 6 (education, training and public awareness) (FCCC/SBSTA/2001/L.1). On emissions resulting from fuel used in international transportation, the Secretariat highlighted inter-sessional work, as contained in a joint report with the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and the International Maritime Organization.

title: Scientific and Methodological Aspects of the Proposal by Brazil:
abstract: The SBSTA took up this matter on 24 July.

title: Cooperation with Relevant International Organizations:
abstract: At the SBSTA meeting on 24 July, Chair Dovland noted ongoing initiatives between the UNFCCC and the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), including: a CBD discussion note and responses submitted by the UNFCCC Parties; a CBD Ad Hoc Technical Expert Group to carry out a pilot assessment on advice to integrate biodiversity into UNFCCC implementation; and a proposed joint liaison group between the two Secretariats.

title: Adoption of the Report:
abstract: The SBSTA adopted the report on its fourteenth session on Friday afternoon, 27 July (FCCC/SBSTA/2001/L.1).

title: REPORTS OF THE SUBSIDIARY BODIES
abstract: The subsidiary bodies to the UNFCCC met for their fourteenth sessions from 24-27 July.

title: CLOSING PLENARY
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Compliance and Enforcement|Technology Transfer
abstract: The closing Plenary took place on Friday evening, 27 July 2001.

title: REPORT OF COP-6 PART II
actors: Group of 77 and China|European Union|Environmental Integrity Group|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Compliance and Enforcement|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: The resumed Sixth Conference of the Parties (COP-6 Part II) to the UNFCCC opened on Monday morning, 16 July 2001.

title: 'THE ONLY GAME IN TOWN'
abstract: Notwithstanding these concerns, the achievement of the last two weeks should not be underestimated.

title: Finance:
abstract: While the financial issues group was the only one to approve all of its draft decisions, there were diverging views on the final outcome.

title: LULUCF
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: The collapse of The Hague negotiations was attributed by many observers to disagreements over LULUCF issues: 'It was sinks that sunk The Hague.

title: Mechanisms:
abstract: Clarifying the nature and scope of the Kyoto mechanisms has always been one of the key determinants for ratification of the Kyoto Protocol by Annex I Parties.

title: Compliance:
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: For seasoned observers of the compliance negotiations, developments in Bonn were unexpected.

title: 'KYOTO LITE' - TAKING THE FIRST STEP
abstract: COP 6 Part II will be remembered primarily for having produced the 'Bonn Agreement,' a political commitment on a package of issues that has facilitated ratification of the Kyoto Protocol.

title: 'PLAY IT, (UNCLE) SAM'
abstract: As climate change observers look ahead to COP-7 in Morocco - a country synonymous to many with Bogart, Bergman and Casablanca - a question uppermost on the minds of many is the extent to which the US will be persuaded to join the climate caravan.

title: THE BONN AGREEMENT: THE BEGINNING OF A BEAUTIFUL FRIENDSHIP?
abstract: Despite the significant achievement in reaching political consensus, it became apparent towards the end of the Bonn meeting that not all Parties were 'maintaining the spirit of Monday's historic agreement.

title: STATUS OF RATIFICATION
abstract: Delegates met on Thursday morning, 19 July, in a plenary session to address organizational matters.

title: ADMISSION OF ORGANIZATIONS AS OBSERVERS
abstract: On the admission of observers, the COP approved the list of organizations recommended by the Bureau on 19 July (FCCC/CP/2001/L.1).

title: Question 2:
abstract: This question addressed the evidence for, and causes and consequences of, changes in the Earth's climate since the pre- industrial era. Views differed over whether to include additional proposed text highlighting differences between satellite and surface temperature measurements.

title: Approved Answer:
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: The approved answer states that the Earth's climate system has demonstrably changed on both global and regional scales since the pre-industrial era, with some of these changes attributable to human activities.

title: Question 3:
topics: Reasons for Concern|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: This question addressed the regional and global climatic, environmental, and socioeconomic consequences in the next 25, 50 and 100 years associated with a range of greenhouse gas emissions arising from scenarios used in the TAR. Regarding human health, several delegates noted the existence of positive effects of climate change on human health and the small number of studies on vector-borne diseases. Concerning crop yields, delegates debated whether reference to the level of warming projected to increase food prices globally should be quantified more precisely than 'a few degrees Celsius.

title: Approved Answer:
topics: Reasons for Concern|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
