title: OPENING
abstract: COP-10 President González García urged delegates to recall the magnitude of the climate change problem and to redouble efforts to deliver outcomes expected from COP-10.

title: STATEMENTS FROM UN BODIES AND SPECIALIZED AGENCIES
abstract: Michel Jarraud, WMO Secretary-General, outlined his organizations contributions to climate change processes, underlining the value of climate observation, monitoring and early warning activities. Noting the 2005 review of progress of the implementation of the Millennium Declaration, Klaus Töpfer, UNEP Executive Director, stressed the impacts of climate change on vulnerable countries and described UNEPs role in promoting sustainable development and changing consumption and production patterns. Rajendra Pachauri, IPCC Chair, stated that the Synthesis Report of the IPCCs Fourth Assessment Report (AR4) will be available in October 2007, and suggested that COP-13 be moved back three to four weeks to allow Parties to have time to review the AR4. Zépherin Diabré, UNDP Associate Administrator, emphasized that entry into force of the Protocol is a key first step on the path to a lower greenhouse gas-intensive society.

title: STATEMENTS FROM REGIONAL GROUPS
abstract: The REPUBLIC OF KOREA, for the Environmental Integrity Group, urged developing and developed countries to make efforts within their own capabilities and explore new and flexible mechanisms to address climate change. EL SALVADOR, for Central American countries, highlighted the vulnerability of her region, noting that it has recently suffered severe weather events.

title: PANEL 1 - 'THE UNFCCC AFTER 10 YEARS
abstract: ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND FUTURE CHALLENGES:' The high-level panel discussion was moderated by Sonia Tschorne Berestesky, Minister of Housing and Urban Development, Chile.

title: Panel statements
abstract: Jiang Liu, Vice-Minister of the State Development and Reform Commission, China, said COP-10 provides the opportunity for a shift from negotiations and rule-making to implementation and concrete action.

title: Discussion
topics: Pre-Kyoto|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|Adaptation|Technology Transfer
abstract: QATAR said the pressing needs of developing countries should be met through full implementation of commitments by Annex I Parties, including on capacity building, technology transfer and financial support.

title: EXCHANGE OF VIEWS ON UNFCCC ACTIVITIES RELEVANT TO OTHER INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This contact group was chaired by José Romero (Switzerland).

title: HIGH-LEVEL SEGMENT
abstract: The high-level panel discussions heard statements from panelists on three topics, each followed by comments from Parties.

title: Discussion
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: PERU, for the Andean Community, highlighted the synergies between action on climate change, biodiversity, disaster reduction and desertification.

title: EXCHANGE OF VIEWS ON UNFCCC ACTIVITIES RELEVANT TO OTHER INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: On reporting the activities of the ten-year review of the Barbados Programme of Action (BPOA+10), the World Conference on Disaster Reduction (WCDR) and CSD processes to the UNFCCC, the US suggested only reporting to SBSTA-23 and only on CSD activities.

title: PANEL 2 - 'IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, ADAPTATION MEASURES AND SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT
abstract: ' This panel was moderated by Ambassador Enele Sopoaga, Tuvalu.

title: Panel statements
abstract: Ian Campbell, Minister of Environment, Australia, stressed that engaging in adaptation must not be seen as an excuse for avoiding mitigation.

title: Discussion
topics: Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Flexibility Mechanims|Technology Transfer
abstract: UKRAINE and OMAN noted their recent ratifications of the Protocol.

title: PANEL 3 - 'TECHNOLOGY AND CLIMATE CHANGE
abstract: ' This panel was moderated by Eduardo Campos, Minister of Science and Technology, Brazil, who noted that climate action should promote sustainable development and poverty eradication.

title: Panel statements
abstract: Moritz Leuenberger, Federal Councillor and Head of the Federal Department for Environment, Switzerland, said sustainable development is the backbone of sustainable climate policy.

title: Discussion
abstract: JAPAN said the CDM promotes technology transfer and that institutional arrangements are necessary to develop the CDM further.

title: PANEL 4 - 'MITIGATION OF CLIMATE CHANGE
abstract: POLICIES AND THEIR IMPACTS:' Cristina Narbona, Minister of Environment, Spain, moderated the panel, stressing the equitable dimension of efforts to transform the current global energy model into a sustainable one.

title: Panel statements
abstract: Sandra del Rosario Suárez Pérez, Minister of Environment, Colombia, said her country offers numerous high-quality CDM projects, is vulnerable both to climate change and to the impacts of response measures, and called for ambitious emissions reductions commitments that are consistent with the best science and the UNFCCCs ultimate objective. Serge Lepeltier, Minister of Environment and Development, France, emphasized that tackling climate change provides economic opportunities and stated that inaction can be more costly than prevention. Stephen Kolonzo Musyoka, Minister of Environment and Natural Resources, Kenya, underscored that, for Africa, 'adaptation is the only way,' and that technology transfer is crucial. Pete Hodgson, Minister of Energy, Transport, Research, Science and Technology, New Zealand, acknowledged that mitigation has not accomplished much so far and that emissions are still increasing.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.27), SBSTA, inter alia, agrees to continue focusing its work on exchanging information and sharing experiences and views among Parties on practical opportunities and solutions to facilitate implementation of the UNFCCC.

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: forests|Compliance and Enforcement|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Good practice guidance for LULUCF activities under the Protocol, harvested wood products (HWP) and other issues relating to LULUCF: This issue was first addressed in the SBSTA plenary on Monday, 6 December, and subsequently in a contact group co-chaired by Audun Rosland (Norway) and William Kojo Agyemang-Bonsu (Ghana), which met five times from 6-13 December.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions on LULUCF (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.26), SBSTA takes note of the information contained in the document relating to LULUCF projects under Protocol Article 6 (joint implementation).

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision on LULUCF (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.26/Add.1), the COP, inter alia, encourages Annex I Parties that have ratified the Protocol to submit, on a voluntary basis, estimates of greenhouse gas emissions by sources and removals by sinks, using the common reporting format. Small-scale afforestation and reforestation project activities under the CDM: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Monday, 6 December, and subsequently in a contact group co-chaired by Thelma Krug (Brazil) and Jim Penman (UK), which met four times between 7-13 December, Informal consultations were also held in an effort to draft conclusions and negotiate a draft decision for adoption at COP-10. The contact group considered a bracketed annex to the draft conclusions forwarded from SBSTA-20.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.20), SBSTA notes that the Executive Secretary provided Parties with an indication of administrative and budgetary implications of the draft decision.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.26/Add.1), the COP decides, inter alia: to adopt simplified modalities and procedures for small-scale A&R CDM project activities in the first commitment period; to limit small-scale A&R projects to net anthropogenic greenhouse gas removals by sinks less than eight kilotonnes of carbon dioxide per year if the average projected net anthropogenic GHG removals by sinks for each verification period do not exceed eight kilotonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent per year; if a small-scale project results in excess removals of eight kilotonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent per year, excess removals will not be eligible for the issuance of temporary or long-term certified emissions reductions; and to exempt small-scale project activities from the share of proceeds to be used to assist developing countries that are particularly vulnerable to adverse impacts of climate change and shall be entitled to a reduced level of the non-reimbursable fee for requesting registration and a reduced rate of the proceeds to cover administrative expenses of the CDM. The COP also requests, inter alia, that: the CDM EB develop, for consideration by COP/MOP-1, default factors for assessing the existing carbon stocks and for simplified baseline methodologies for small-scale A&R projects, taking into account, if appropriate, types of soil, lifetime of project and climatic conditions.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.18), SBSTA takes note of the continuing work of ICAO and IMO, and the ongoing cooperation among the secretariats of the UNFCCC, ICAO, IMO and IPCC on the issue of emissions from international aviation and maritime transport.

title: Issues relating to greenhouse gas inventories
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Tuesday, 7 December, and subsequently in informal consultations facilitated by Branca Americano (Brazil) and Helen Plume (New Zealand).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.17), SBSTA notes the substantial and steady improvement in the timeliness and quality of submissions of greenhouse gas inventories, urges Parties to continue to improve their reporting, and notes the benefits, in terms of capacity building, provided to experts who participate in the greenhouse gas inventory review process.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.30), SBSTA considers a proposal for a standard electronic format for reporting: supplementary information on emissions reduction units; certified emissions reductions, including temporary and long-term certified emissions reductions; assigned amount units; and removal units.

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: In December 1997, delegates met at COP-3 in Kyoto, Japan, and agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries making the transition to a market economy (EITs) to achieve quantified emissions reduction targets.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.30/Add.1), the COP, inter alia: requests the Secretariat to develop a compilation and accounting database in coordination with the development of the international transaction log (ITL) and to report progress to SBSTA; and to consult with administrators of registry systems to facilitate the review of national inventories and assigned amount information under Protocol Article 8.

title: Issues relating to registry systems under Protocol Article 7.4
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Tuesday, 7 December, and subsequently in the contact group chaired by Murray Ward.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.29), SBSTA takes note on work relating to registry systems and the intersessional consultations on registry systems.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.29/Add.1), the COP requests Parties to inform the Secretariat of the organizations designated as administrators of national registries or supplementary transaction logs by May 2005.

title: Emissions projections from Annex I Parties
abstract: The issue was first taken up by SBSTA in plenary on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.23), SBSTA takes note of the report of the workshop on emissions projections from Annex I Parties held in September 2004.

title: DEVELOPMENT AND TRANSFER OF TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.28), SBSTA, inter alia: endorses the EGTT 2005 work programme; welcomes the report prepared by the Secretariat on the outcomes of the workshop in September 2004 on innovative options for financing the development and transfer of technologies; welcomes the handbook on Conducting Technology Needs Assessments for Climate Change prepared by UNDP; takes note of the resource implications of maintaining and further developing TT:CLEAR; requests the EGTT to take into consideration elements for meaningful public and/or private partnerships to enhance the implementation of Article 4.5 when preparing the terms of reference for the practitioners guide; and requests the Secretariat, subject to availability of resources, to: prepare a synthesis report based on the preliminary analysis of the available technology needs assessments compiled by UNDP as foreseen in the EGTT 2005 work programme; organize a special meeting of the EGTT; and prepare a technical paper on applications of environmentally sound technologies for adaptation to climate change to be considered by SBSTA-24.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/CP/2004/L.8), the COP, inter alia: urges Annex II Parties to continue to provide support for the development of endogenous technologies in developing countries; requests the EGTT to make recommendations for enhancing the implementation of Article 4.5, with a view toward the EGTT review by COP-12; and urges the Secretariat to continue its pilot project on networking between TT:CLEAR and national and regional technology information centers.

title: 'GOOD PRACTICES' IN P&MS AMONG ANNEX I PARTIES
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Tuesday, 7 December, and subsequently in informal consultations facilitated by Tony Surridge (South Africa) and Michael Young (Ireland). In the SBSTA plenary on Tuesday, 14 December, Facilitator Surridge reported on the informal consultations and noted that Parties had been unable to reach agreement.

title: THE BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION
abstract: The Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA) was negotiated at COP-4 in 1998, in order to set out a process for taking forward the provisions of the Protocol.

title: Draft SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the draft conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.25), SBSTA considers the use of information on P&Ms used by Annex I Parties that address, inter alia, the use of information from international and intergovernmental organizations such as the Organization of Oil Producing Countries (OPEC) and the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD).

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Monday, 6 December.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.24), SBSTA, inter alia: welcomes the 'Implementation Plan for the Global Observing System for Climate in Support of the UNFCCC'; invites the GCOS Secretariat to prepare a synthesis report on how actions identified in the implementation plan have been incorporated in GCOS sponsoring agencies own plans and actions; and welcomes the progress made in the programme of the GCOS regional workshops made by the ad hoc Group on Earth Observations to develop a 10-year implementation plan for a Global Earth Observation System of Systems.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/CP/2004/L6), the COP, inter alia, encourages Parties to implement the priority elements in the regional action plans relating to the global observing systems for climate.

title: COOPERATION WITH RELEVANT INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Tuesday, 7 December, and subsequently in informal consultations facilitated by Outi Berghäll (Finland) and Marcela Main (Chile).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.22), SBSTA, inter alia, notes the paper on options for enhanced cooperation among the three Rio Conventions and requests the Secretariat to make the outcome of the consideration of the JLGs paper available to the first SBSTA session following the JLGs meeting.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: Issues relating to cleaner or less-greenhouse-gas- emitting energy: This agenda item was withdrawn in the opening COP plenary on Monday, 6 December, after Canada withdrew its proposal on cleaner energy exports.

title: Issues relating to Protocol Article 2.3
abstract: The issue of Protocol Article 2.3 (adverse effects of P&Ms) was discussed by SBSTA on Thursday, 9 December.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.19), SBSTA notes that it did not complete its consideration of issues relating to Protocol Article 2.3 and agrees to continue consideration of these issues at SBSTA-22. Any other matters: Activities implemented jointly under the pilot phase: In plenary on Tuesday, 14 December, SBSTA adopted conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.21) without amendment, recommending a draft decision for adoption by the COP.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.21/Add.1), the COP decides to continue the pilot phase for activities implemented jointly and that the deadline for submission of reports on these activities shall be 1 June 2006.

title: THE MARRAKESH ACCORDS
abstract: Delegates continued discussions on the Bonn Agreements at COP-7 in October/November 2001.

title: IN-SESSION WORKSHOPS
abstract: Impacts of, and vulnerability and adaptation to, climate change: On Wednesday, 8 December, Parties convened in a SBSTA in-session workshop to hear presentations and engage in discussions on impacts of, and vulnerability and adaptation to, climate change.

title: REPORT ON THE SESSION
abstract: On early Wednesday morning, 15 December, Chair Benrageb presented the report on the session (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/L.16), which Parties adopted.

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR IMPLEMENTATION
abstract: SBI Chair Daniela Stoycheva (Bulgaria) opened SBI-21 on Monday, 6 December.

title: ANNEX I NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBI in plenary on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.17), SBI, inter alia, emphasizes the importance of timely submission of the national communications due by 1 January 2006, and recalls the need to include supplementary information necessary to demonstrate compliance under Protocol Article 7.2.

title: NON-ANNEX I NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds 1|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Submission of second and, where appropriate, third national communications: This issue was first addressed by SBI in plenary on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.18), SBI notes the importance of developing training materials for hands-on training workshops and welcomes the decision of the CGE to develop a joint work plan with the UNDP/UNEP/GEF National Communications Support Programme.

title: Provision of financial and technical support
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: This issue was addressed by SBI on Tuesday, 7 December, and Chair Stoycheva prepared draft conclusions.

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.1), SBI welcomes the submission of initial national communications by 120 non-Annex I Parties and the submission of second national communications by three non-Annex I Parties.

title: Compilation and synthesis of initial national communications
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: This issue was addressed by SBI in plenary on Tuesday, 7 December, and Chair Stoycheva prepared conclusions.

title: MOVE TOWARD IMPLEMENTATION
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: Delegates met at COP-8 in October/November 2002, and again at COP-9 in December 2003 to negotiate decisions for implementing the Marrakesh Accords.

title: UNFCCC FINANCIAL MECHANISM
actors: African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Special Climate Change Fund: This issue was first addressed by the SBI on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.24), SBI invites Parties and intergovernmental organizations to submit to the Secretariat, by 15 October 2005, information on their experiences regarding the effectiveness of the financial mechanism.

title: COP Decision
abstract: The decision (FCCC/CP/2004/L.10) states that the report on the assessment of funding necessary to assist developing countries in fulfilling their commitments under the UNFCCC shall constitute an input of the COP to the fourth replenishment negotiations of the GEF Trust Fund.

title: Additional guidance to the GEF
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBI on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/CP/2004/L.17), the COP requests the GEF to, inter alia, report on the support of activities identified in the Buenos Aires Programme of Work on Adaptation and Response Measures and continue to fund activities relating to UNFCCC Article 6 (education, training and public awareness).

title: Report of the GEF to the COP
abstract: SBI first addressed this issue on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/CP/2004/L.4), SBI welcomes the efforts by the GEF to support projects on energy efficiency, assist LDCs in the preparation of NAPAs, assist Parties in the preparation of their national communications, and obtain pledges to the SCCF.

title: UNFCCC ARTICLE 6
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBI on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.16), SBI welcomes progress in implementing activities within the scope of the New Delhi work programme on Article 6, reaffirms that regional, subregional and national workshops are valuable fora, welcomes offers of Uruguay and Japan to host regional workshops, and recognizes that the particular needs of SIDS could be addressed by organizing a pre-sessional workshop in conjunction with SBI-23.

title: COP Decision
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.16/Add.1), the COP invites Parties and international organizations to support workshops and the development and implementation of the information network clearing house.

title: COP-10 REPORT
actors: African Group|Group of 77 and China|European Union|Environmental Integrity Group|Alliance of Small Island States
countries: Turkey|Qatar|Netherlands|Pakistan|Denmark|Tanzania|Romania|Micronesia|United States|Hungary|Switzerland|Burkina Faso|Bulgaria|Jamaica|Saudi Arabia|Tuvalu|Lesotho|China|United Arab Emirates|Russian Federation|Kenya|Poland|Barbados
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Reasons for Concern|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: On Monday, 6 December 2004, COP-9 Vice President Mamadou Honadia (Burkina Faso), on behalf of COP-9 President Miklós Persányi (Hungary), introduced Ginés González García, Argentine Minister of Health and the Environment, who was elected President of COP-10 by acclamation.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBI on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: COP Decision
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: s: In the final decision on capacity building for EITs (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.22/Add.1), the COP, inter alia, invites the GEF, Annex II Parties and multilateral and bilateral organizations to provide information regarding opportunities for technical and financial support and encourages EITs to strengthen national institutions to build capacity through training, public education and awareness programmes.

title: IMPLEMENTATION OF UNFCCC ARTICLE 4.8 AND 4.9
abstract: Progress on the implementation of activities under decision 5/CP.7: This issue was first addressed by SBI on Monday, 6 December.

title: COP Decision
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The decision (FCCC/CP/2004/L.16), entitled the Buenos Aires Programme of Work on Adaptation and Response Measures, is divided into four parts: adverse effects of climate change; impact of the implementation of response measures; further multilateral work relating to activities under decision 5/CP.7; and the SBSTA programme of work on impacts, vulnerability, and adaptation to climate change. On adverse effects of climate change, the COP decides to further implementation of actions under decision 5/CP.7 on information and methodologies, and vulnerability and adaptation.

title: Matters relating to the LDCs
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: This issue was first addressed by the SBI, on Monday 6, December.

title: COP Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions on the status of implementation of Article 4.9 (FCCC/CP/2004/L.14), the COP notes appreciation for the progress made in the development of NAPAs, and requests the Secretariat to ensure that the issue of risk assessment and micro-insurance for LDCs in the context of extreme weather events is covered in the workshops referred to in the Buenos Aires Programme of Work on Adaptation and Response Measures.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision on the work of the LEG (FCCC/CP/2004/L.13), the COP requests the LEG to prepare a mandate with possible elements to be considered at SBI-23 on the role of the LEG in support of the implementation of NAPAs, and potential technical and financial difficulties that LDCs may have in the implementation of NAPAs.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL MATTERS
abstract: Audited financial statements for the biennium 2002-3: This issue was first addressed by the SBI on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision, (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.15/Add.1) the COP takes note of the audited financial statements.

title: Budget performance for the biennium 2004-5
abstract: This issue was first considered by SBI on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL ADVICE
abstract: SBSTA Chair Abdullatif Benrageb (Libya) opened SBSTA-21 on Monday, 6 December, noting that Arther Rolle (Bahamas) will continue to serve as SBSTA Vice-Chair and Ibrahim Al-Ajmi (Oman) as Rapporteur.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.15/Add.1), the COP, inter alia, requests the Executive Secretary to submit to SBI the proposed budget for 2006-7, and to explore options to protect funds of the UNFCCC and the Protocol against the adverse effects of exchange-rate fluctuations and to report on this issue to SBI-22.

title: CONTINUING REVIEW OF THE FUNCTIONS AND OPERATIONS OF THE SECRETARIAT
abstract: This matter was first addressed by SBI on Tuesday, 7 December.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.14), SBI notes the lack of sufficient and predictable funding given to the Secretariat for organizing workshops and notes the lack of predictable funding as the main reason for delays in the organization of workshops.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: Level of emissions for the base year of Croatia: This issue was taken up by SBI on Monday, 6 December.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.21), SBI agrees to continue its consideration of the level of emissions for the base year of Croatia at the next session.

title: IN-SESSION WORKSHOP
abstract: Organization of the intergovernmental process: An SBI in-session workshop on the organization of the intergovernmental process was held on Saturday, 11 December.

title: REPORT ON THE SESSION
abstract: SBI considered the report on early Wednesday morning, 15 December.

title: SECOND REVIEW OF ADEQUACY OF UNFCCC ARTICLE 4.2(A) AND (B)
abstract: The issue of the second review of the adequacy of Annex I commitments under UNFCCC Article 4.2(a) and (b) was taken up by the COP on Monday, 6 December.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR COP/MOP-1
abstract: Preparatory work relating to Protocol Article 6: This issue was taken up by the COP on Wednesday, 8 December.

title: COP Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/CP/2004/L.3), the COP invites Annex I Parties to make contributions to the UNFCCC Trust Fund for Supplementary Activities in order to facilitate preparatory work by the Secretariat in 2005 and draws attention to the need to make nominations to the Article 6 Supervisory Committee so that COP/MOP-1 will be in a position to elect its members and alternate members.

title: SCIENTIFIC, TECHNICAL AND SOCIOECONOMIC ASPECTS OF IMPACTS OF, AND VULNERABILITY AND ADAPTATION TO, CLIMATE CHANGE
topics: Reasons for Concern|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA on Thursday, 9 December.

title: REPORT OF THE CDM EB
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: This issue was first addressed by the COP on Monday, 6 December, and again on Wednesday, 8 December.

title: COP Decision
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/CP/2004/L.2), the COP: encourages the EB to continue to assess existing and new ways to ensure transparency; recalls that the use of the 'tool for the demonstration and assessment of additionality' is not mandatory for project participants; and requests SBSTA, in collaboration with the EB, to develop a recommendation to COP/MOP-1 relating to the implications of the implementation of CDM project activities for the achievement of the objectives of other environmental conventions and protocols, in particular the Montreal Protocol. The COP also encourages CDM project participants to make proposals for new baseline and monitoring methodologies for types of project activities in sectors not yet covered by approved methodologies, including transportation and energy efficiency, and to intensify its work to ensure the proper functioning of the CDM, by, inter alia, developing a management plan.

title: EXCHANGE OF VIEWS ON UNFCCC ACTIVITIES RELEVANT TO OTHER INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
abstract: The COP first addressed this issue on Monday, 6 December.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/CP/2004/L.2), the COP notes that Parties held an exchange of views on UNFCCC activities relevant to other intergovernmental meetings and requested the Secretariat to report on these agreed activities to the BPOA+10, WCDR, and CSD-14 meetings.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL MATTERS
abstract: Procedure for the appointment of an Executive Secretary: In the COP Plenary on Friday, 17 December, President González García said he would continue to undertake consultations on this matter at a future session.

title: HIGH-LEVEL SEGMENT
abstract: The COP-10 high-level segment began on Wednesday, 15 December.

title: PANEL DISCUSSIONS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds 1|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Following opening statements, four panel discussions were held. Panel 1 - The Convention after 10 Years: accomplishments and future challenges: This high-level panel took place on Wednesday, 15 December.

title: Panel 3 - Technology and climate change
abstract: This high-level panel took place on Thursday, 16 December.

title: STATEMENTS
actors: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries|Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Statements by UN bodies and specialized agencies and regional groups were heard on Wednesday, 15 December.

title: CLOSING PLENARY
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Closed consultations continued past the scheduled closing of the COP.

title: SCIENTIFIC, TECHNICAL AND SOCIOECONOMIC ASPECTS OF MITIGATION
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA on Friday, 10 December, and subsequently in three contact group meetings co-chaired by Kok Seng Yap (Malaysia) and Toshiyuki Sakamoto (Japan).

title: CLIMATE CHANGE ARCHITECTURE
abstract: The year 2004 was a significant one for the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and its Kyoto Protocol.

title: THE BRICKS AND MORTAR
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: COP-10 provided an opportunity for delegates to reinforce the two main building blocks of the policy response to climate change: mitigation and adaptation.

title: CRACKS IN THE ROOF
actors: Least Developed Countries|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Least developed countries - some of the most vulnerable to the impacts of climate change - failed for the second consecutive year to secure a decision for full-cost funding of adaptation through the Global Environment Facility (GEF).

title: BLUE PRINT FOR POST-2012
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The recently released report of the UN High-Level Panel on Threats, Challenges and Change underlines that countries must take action and commence negotiations for long-term strategy to address climate change.

title: CONCLUSIONS
abstract: Until the 11th hour, many remained pessimistic about the potential for a deal at COP-10.

title: Norway
abstract: Harald Dovland underscored that 2012 is only seven years away, a very short time given the long planning periods needed for many sectors.

title: European Commission
abstract: Artur Runge-Metzger outlined the EUs progress in achieving the Kyoto targets, stressing its emphasis on cost-effective policies, a multi-stakeholder approach, and the use of market-based instruments, regulations and standards, labeling and voluntary measures.

title: United States
abstract: Harlan Watson outlined his countrys policies to address climate change, stressing its commitment to the UNFCCC and the need for sustained efforts by all nations across generations.

title: DISCUSSION
abstract: Responding to a question from Luxembourg about existing technologies, Harlan Watson agreed that these had an important role.

title: Tuvalu:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Ian Fry said Annex B countries should focus on energy efficiency and renewable energy and that countries that are not Parties to the Kyoto Protocol should reduce their emissions levels.

title: Albania
abstract: Ermira Fida said Albanias First National Communication has been used to mainstream climate change into national policies, including the development of the national energy strategy and identifying ways to meet technology needs.

title: Republic of Korea
abstract: Boo Nam Shin noted that energy demand is projected to grow both in the Republic of Korea and globally.

title: The Netherlands
abstract: Yvo de Boer speaking for the EU, focused on policy integration, noting increasing energy consumption.

title: DISCUSSION
abstract: In the subsequent discussion, India asked for clarification on the new approaches to differentiation among Parties, and Yvo de Boer said these should be built on the UNFCCC framework.

title: Canada:
abstract: Norine Smith reported on Project Green, which sets out steps to ensure that Canada can meet its Kyoto commitments.

title: Japan
abstract: Mutsuyoshi Nishimura drew attention to Japans new plan to implement its Kyoto commitments, describing it as a 'huge package' of measures involving various stakeholders.

title: Morocco
abstract: Taha Balafrej highlighted Moroccos vulnerability to climate change, including its impact on precipitation and water supply.

title: India
abstract: Surya P. Sethi stated that emissions in Annex I countries are rising and that their reductions have not resulted from new climate policies and measures but from 'one time' events such as the economic transition in Eastern Europe, and the shift from coal to gas in the UK.

title: DISCUSSION
abstract: Responding to questions from various participants concerning technology transfer, Surya P. Sethi highlighted that the transfer of certain technologies should be moved to the public domain, as the speed of commercially-driven technology transfer will be insufficient to affect climate change in any meaningful way, due to the lack of resources in developing countries.

title: Papua New Guinea:
abstract: Robert G. Aisi underscored that the Kyoto Protocol excludes action by developing countries to avoid deforestation.

title: Mexico
abstract: Fernando Tudela said a signal should be given to the markets on the future of the climate regime, and raised the possibility of a 'Montreal Mandate' at COP-11/MOP-1.

title: Australia
abstract: Jan Adams said the major emitters should take action to reduce emissions and identified the growing global energy demand as a major challenge.

title: China:
abstract: Feng Gao drew attention to Chinas current reliance on coal, stressed the need to improve energy efficiency, and outlined Chinas efforts to optimize its energy structure.

title: France
abstract: Paul Watkinson, on behalf of the EU, focused on the investment challenge.

title: DISCUSSION
abstract: In the ensuing discussion, Monaco said per capita emissions should be a relevant consideration in determining future commitments.

title: New Zealand
abstract: Helen Plume noted her countrys responses to climate change, including a carbon tax to be introduced in 2007.

title: Germany
abstract: Karsten Sach, on behalf of the EU, spoke about technology and innovation.

title: Argentina
abstract: Vicente R. Barros acknowledged warnings about the 2?C global warming threshold, and noted that warming is expected to be greater in some tropical and sub-tropical areas, with impacts on, inter alia, precipitation, water supplies, hydro power and agriculture.

title: Finland
abstract: Outi Berghäll stressed the urgency of adaptation, and called for the integration of climate change and adaptation into development policies, as well as into national and subnational decision-making.

title: DISCUSSION
abstract: Responding to a question from Hungary on long-term goals, Helen Plume indicated that New Zealand has not adopted a long-term global warming target, but accepted that international consensus on such a target would provide greater certainty for the business sector.

title: Brazil
abstract: André Corrêa do Lago urged cooperation to ensure the success of the UNFCCC, Kyoto Protocol and the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) beyond 2012.

title: Peru:
abstract: María Paz Cigarán focused on practical action to address climate change at the national level.

title: Saudi Arabia
abstract: Fareed Al-Asaly said Annex I Parties are not fulfilling their commitments under the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol, particularly in reducing emissions or providing assistance and technology transfer.

title: DISCUSSION
abstract: Namibia, Burkina Faso, Togo and others expressed interest in Malis experiences with national monitoring plans and meteorological information systems, and raised the idea of turning them into a regional programme.

title: ADAPTATION
abstract: Participants were then asked to discuss adaptation issues.

title: India
abstract: emphasized that adaptation measures should not attempt to replicate mitigation models, such as incremental costs.

title: MITIGATION
abstract: On mitigation, the Republic of Korea highlighted common but differentiated responsibilities and noted that, given the current global reliance on fossil fuels, it was time to look at the nuclear energy option more positively.

title: Saudi Arabia
abstract: said the UNFCCC has set out a clear approach on mitigation and Parties should meet their obligations.

title: CLOSING REMARKS
abstract: Responding to questions about the outcome of the Seminar, UNFCCC Executive Secretary Joke Waller-Hunter noted that COP-10 had invited the Secretariat to make the proceedings of the Seminar available.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: On technology transfer, participants commented on how to increase the flow of technology transfer and improve the effectiveness of the Kyoto Mechanisms.

title: Switzerland
abstract: Beat Nobs recognized the need to increase efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions after 2012.

title: United Kingdom
abstract: David Warrilow, on behalf of the European Union (EU), underscored positive feedback and possible catastrophic impacts as drivers for the EUs proposal to limit warming to less than 2?C, emphasizing that the challenge is to meet growing demand for energy while reducing emissions.

title: DISCUSSION
abstract: Japan welcomed Chinas emphasis on energy savings and efficiency, asked for details on how China plans to achieve these, and offered technology cooperation.

title: South Africa
abstract: Alf Wills said the future should involve a strengthened Kyoto Protocol that includes all countries and recognizes their common but differentiated responsibilities.

title: THIRD EARTH OBSERVATION SUMMIT
abstract: This Summit, held in Brussels, Belgium, on 16 February 2005, resulted in governments endorsing a 10-year implementation plan for the development of a Global Earth Observation System of Systems (GEOSS).

title: G8 ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT MINISTERS MEETING
abstract: The Environment and Development Ministers of the G8 countries met from 17-18 March 2005, in Derbyshire, UK.

title: UNFCCC MEETINGS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: A number of UNFCCC events have taken place since COP-10, including a regional workshop for Latin America and the Caribbean on education, training and public awareness (30 March to 1 April 2005, Montevideo, Uruguay); a workshop on national systems (11-12 April 2005, Bonn, Germany); a meeting of the Consultative Group of Experts on National Communications from Non-Annex I Parties (14-15 April 2005, Maputo, Mozambique); and two meetings of the Executive Board of the CDM (23-25 February and 11-13 May 2005, Bonn).

title: SEMINAR OF GOVERNMENTAL EXPERTS
abstract: A Seminar of Governmental Experts was also held prior to SB-22, on 16-17 May 2005, in Bonn.

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP-3 in Kyoto, Japan, agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries making the transition to a market economy (EITs) to achieve quantified emissions reduction targets.

title: THE BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION
abstract: The Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA) was negotiated at COP-4 in 1998, to set out a process for taking forward the provisions of the Protocol.

title: THE MARRAKESH ACCORDS
abstract: Delegates continued discussions on the Bonn Agreements at COP-7 in October/November 2001.

title: COP-8 & COP-9
abstract: Delegates met at COP-8 in October/November 2002, and again at COP-9 in December 2003, to negotiate decisions for implementing the Marrakesh Accords.

title: SB-20
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: In June 2004, delegates met in Bonn at the twentieth sessions of SBI and SBSTA.

title: COP-10
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: COP-10 was held in Buenos Aires, Argentina, from 6-18 December 2004.

title: WORLD CONFERENCE ON DISASTER REDUCTION
abstract: The World Conference on Disaster Reduction was held from 18-22 January 2005, in Kobe, Japan.

title: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON THE STABILIZATION OF GREENHOUSE GASES
abstract: This symposium, held from 1-3 February 2005, in Exeter, UK, sought to advance scientific understanding of and encourage scientific debate on the long-term implications of climate change, the relevance of stabilization goals, and technological options to reach such goals.

title: OPENING OF THE SESSION
actors: European Union|Least Developed Countries|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: UNFCCC Executive Secretary Joke Waller-Hunter welcomed delegates and conveyed SBSTA Chair Abdullatif Benragebs regrets that he was unable to attend.

title: Global Climate Observing System
abstract: Chair Abdulla said he would draft conclusions on the Global Climate Observing System (GCOS) for SBSTAs consideration.

title: ADJUSTMENTS FOR LULUCF
abstract: On Thursday evening, the Contact Group on technical guidance on methodologies for adjustments under the Protocol convened.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: William Kojo Agyemang-Bonsu (Ghana) and Holger Liptow (Germany) convened a Contact Group to advance discussion on terms of reference to guide EGTT recommendations on enhancing its framework for implementation of a technology transfer framework pursuant to COP decision 6/CP.10.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China
abstract: Chair Amjad Abdulla introduced the agenda (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/1).

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: Emissions from Fuel Used for International Aviation and Maritime Transport: The UNFCCC Secretariat introduced its updated note on this matter (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/INF.2).

title: Registry Systems
abstract: Murray Ward (New Zealand) presented results from informal negotiations held prior to SBSTA-22 (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/Inf.3), and announced that the international transaction log (ITL) will not be operative before the second half of 2006.

title: COOPERATION WITH RELEVANT INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS
abstract: Special Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) on Safeguarding the Ozone Layer and Global Climate System - Issues Relating to HFCs and PFCs: Susan Solomon and Bert Metz, IPCC, presented the main findings of the new report.

title: DEVELOPMENT AND TRANSFER OF TECHNOLOGIES
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Post-Kyoto Agreements|Technology Transfer
abstract: Chair Abdulla reminded Parties that SBSTA-22 must provide clear guidance and terms of reference for the future work of the Expert Group on Technology Transfer (EGTT).

title: RESEARCH NEEDS RELATING TO THE CONVENTION
abstract: Introducing its synthesis of views on issues from the research event at SB-20 (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/3), the Secretariat cited its efforts to look across various agenda items to find relationships among them.

title: POLICIES AND MEASURES
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Chair Abdulla drew attention to a document prepared by the Secretariat on options for using web-based approaches to share experiences and exchange information on good practices in policies and measures (FCCC/SBSTA/2004/Inf.10). SAUDI ARABIA said he would provide input during the roundtable discussion scheduled for Tuesday morning, 24 May 2005.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: Issues Relating to the Implementation of Kyoto Protocol Article 2.3 (Adverse Effects of Policies and Measures): Chair Abdulla introduced this issue, noting that little progress had been made in previous discussions.

title: OPENING OF THE SESSION
abstract: SBI Chair Thomas Becker (Denmark) opened the session.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL MATTERS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: Budget Performance for the Biennium 2004-2005: The Secretariat presented on its financial situation (FCCC/SBI/2005/INF.4), underscoring a funding shortfall.

title: Programme Budget for the Biennium 2006-2007
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The EU, opposed by the US and JAPAN, supported the Secretariats proposal to compensate for US dollar depreciation by fixing the budget in Euros.

title: Implementation of the Headquarters Agreement
abstract: GERMANY and Joke Waller-Hunter reported on the Headquarters Agreement and progress on extending it to cover the Kyoto Protocol.

title: Internal Review of the Activities of the Secretariat
abstract: Joke Waller-Hunter reported on an interim review of the Secretariats activities (FCCC/SBI/2005/6), noting a lack of resources to meet demands, and inviting guidance from Parties.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: Level of Emissions for the Base Year of Croatia: Chair Becker noted that this issue had been on the agenda for several years, and hoped it could be resolved at this meeting.

title: Climate Neutral UNFCCC Meetings
abstract: The US and SAUDI ARABIA opposed a proposal to offset greenhouse gas emissions from UNFCCC meetings (FCCC/SBI/2005/9).

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM
abstract: Special Climate Change Fund (SCCF): On the SCCF (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.25), ARGENTINA, SAUDI ARABIA, SOUTH AFRICA and others expressed disappointment that the matter had not been resolved at COP 10.

title: UNFCCC ARTICLE 4.8 AND 4.9 (ADVERSE EFFECTS)
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: LDCs: On LDCs, Paul Desanker (Malawi) briefed delegates on the LDC Expert Groups April 2005 meeting, noting work on National Adaptation Programmes of Action (NAPAs) and its links with LDCs national communications.

title: RESEARCH NEEDS RELATING TO THE CONVENTION
abstract: Delegates stressed the IPCCs importance as an independent scientific body, while underscoring that scientific priorities differ from government research necessities, and the need for mechanisms to address the research gap.

title: CDM AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL TREATIES
abstract: Chair Georg Børsting (Norway) recalled statements made at SBSTA highlighting broad agreement on the need to address perverse incentives for new HCFC-22 plants.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
actors: Group of 77 and China|European Union|Environmental Integrity Group|Umbrella Group|African Group|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Delegates discussed the provisional agenda (FCCC/SBI/2005/1 and Add.1) in detail, particularly additions proposed by SAUDI ARABIA on implementation of UNFCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 (FCCC/SBI/2005/1/Add.2), and the G-77/CHINAs proposed agenda item on capacity building. The EU, CENTRAL GROUP and ENVIRONMENTAL INTEGRITY GROUP supported the agenda without amendments, while the AFRICA GROUP and AOSIS supported adding an item on capacity building.

title: ADJUSTMENTS FOR LULUCF
abstract: Co-Chair Newton Paciornik (Brazil) reported on an informal group meeting in which delegates had reviewed the 'conservativeness factor' tables.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: Delegates met informally to present and exchange views on the main negotiating groups written contributions for draft conclusions and EGTT terms of reference.

title: SAFEGUARDING THE OZONE LAYER AND CLIMATE CHANGE - HFCS AND PFCS
abstract: Chair Darren Goetze (Canada) invited comments on the joint report of the IPCC and Technology and Economic Assessment Panel (TEAP).

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Submission of Second and, Where Appropriate, Third National Communications: The Secretariat explained that talks held during SBI 21 and COP 10 on timelines for the preparation of national communications from non-Annex I Parties were not conclusive, and that a draft text (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.27) had been referred to SBI 22.

title: Compilation and Synthesis of Initial National Communications
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The Secretariat noted inconclusive discussions at SBI 21 and COP 10 on guidance to the GEF on this issue (FCCC/SBI/2005/INF.2 and FCCC/SBI/2004/L.23).

title: Provision of Financial and Technical Support
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The Secretariat briefed Parties on this issue (FCCC/SBI/2005/INF.1 and INF.3).

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
abstract: COP 11 and COP/MOP I: Secretary of the COP Richard Kinley briefed delegates on preparations for COP 11 and COP/MOP I in Montreal (FCCC/SBI/2005/4 and Corr.1).

title: Future Sessional Periods
abstract: Richard Kinley noted an IPCC request to postpone COP 13 for three or four weeks to avoid it occurring too soon after the Fourth Assessment Report is finalized.

title: Organization of the Intergovernmental Process
abstract: Richard Kinley noted a recent workshop on ways to improve the organization of the intergovernmental process (FCCC/SBI/2005/2).

title: Observer Organizations in the Convention Process
abstract: Richard Kinley noted ongoing work in the UN on the involvement of civil society.

actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
countries: Canada|United Kingdom|Saudi Arabia|Australia|Bangladesh|South Africa|United States|Switzerland|China|Uganda|Russian Federation|Japan|New Zealand|Mauritius|Argentina
topics: Adaptation|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Philip Gwage (Uganda) and David Warrilow (UK) co-chaired the in-session workshop, which addressed the development of a SBSTA five-year work programme on adaptation, as required by the Buenos Aires Programme on Adaptation (1/CP.10). Delegates heard presentations from keynote speaker Ian Burton, University of Toronto, and 15 country representatives.

title: ADJUSTMENTS FOR LULUCF
abstract: Co-Chair Rosland presented an amended version of the annex to the draft COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 decision on technical guidance for methodologies for adjustments for LULUCF (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/2), and delegates engaged in paragraph-by- paragraph discussions.

title: INTERNAL REVIEW OF SECRETARIAT ACTIVITIES
abstract: Harald Dovland (Norway) convened the first meeting of a contact group on the internal review of the activities of the UNFCCC Secretariat.

title: SPECIAL CLIMATE CHANGE FUND
abstract: The SBI contact group on the SCCF convened in the afternoon, with Co-Chair Ojoo-Massawa noting that the aim was to finish negotiations on draft SBI conclusions for a COP decision (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.25).

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
abstract: Chair Sach convened the contact group in the afternoon.

title: PROGRAMME BUDGET FOR THE BIENNIUM 2006-7
abstract: Delegates met in the morning to ask substantive questions about the proposed budget, and informally in the afternoon to discuss draft SBI and COP/MOP 1 decisions from the Chair.

title: RESEARCH NEEDS RELATING TO THE CONVENTION
abstract: Delegates met informally to exchange views on a draft decision prepared by Co-Chairs Castellari and Cigarán.

title: MATTERS RELATING TO THE LEAST DEVELOPED COUNTRIES
abstract: Delegates stressed the need to finally conclude this item, and agreed that the pre-session consultations and decision 6/CP.9 were the starting points for deliberations.

title: OZONE AND CLIMATE ISSUES - HFCS AND PFCS
abstract: Chair Goetze presented draft conclusions.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: Co-Chairs Liptow and Agyemang-Bonsu introduced their compilation of submissions for draft conclusions and terms of reference for the EGTT, which was welcomed by parties as a good basis for negotiations.

title: MITIGATION WORKSHOP
abstract: Kok Seng Yap (Malaysia) and Toshiyuki Sakamoto (Japan) facilitated this in-session SBSTA workshop, which focused on factors that affect technology innovation, deployment and diffusion, and socioeconomic aspects of mitigation, including poverty reduction and economic impacts. Richard Bradley, International Energy Agency, noted that stabilizing emissions while addressing electricity deprivation will require a change in capital structures and the deployment of all available energy technologies.

title: RESEARCH NEEDS RELATING TO THE CONVENTION
abstract: Consultations resumed on Monday, with delegates working on draft conclusions.

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
abstract: This contact group reconvened on Monday afternoon.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Co-Chairs Sok Appadu and Turesson facilitated informal consultations on timing of submissions of second and, where appropriate, third national communications.

actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Co-Chair Shevlin proposed initiating an exchange of views based on the SBSTA Chairs summary of the workshop.

title: ADJUSTMENTS FOR LULUCF
abstract: During an evening meeting of the contact group, Co-Chair Paciornik presented revised draft text.

title: EMISSIONS FROM AVIATION AND MARITIME TRANSPORT
abstract: Informal discussions extended until 10:00 pm, with strong disagreements persisting and draft text remaining bracketed.

abstract: On Monday afternoon, SBSTA reconvened to address its agenda item on the scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of adaptation, and Chair Abdulla presented his summary of the workshop.

title: MITIGATION
abstract: Delegates took up scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of mitigation.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
abstract: Following further debate on Saudi Arabias proposal to add agenda items on implementation of UNFCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 (FCCC/SBI/2005/1/Add.2), Chair Becker proposed that those items and a G-77/China proposed item on capacity building be included under Other Matters.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: Following a statement by Tanzania, for the G-77/CHINA, referencing decisions 2/CP.7 and 2/CP.10 on capacity building, the Chair noted the importance of commitments to review the capacity building framework and receive a report from GEF at the next session.

title: REVIEW OF THE SECRETARIATS ACTIVITIES
abstract: The contact group on the internal review of Secretariat activities reconvened on Monday morning.

title: PROGRAMME BUDGET FOR THE BIENNIUM 2006-2007
abstract: Delegates discussed new draft proposals from the Chair and the Secretariats proposed budget.

title: LEAST DEVELOPED COUNTRIES
abstract: Delegates considered draft SBI conclusions and a draft COP 11 decision on LDCs.

title: REGISTRY SYSTEMS UNDER THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: Murray Ward (New Zealand) chaired informal consultations on Monday, with delegates considering short draft conclusions.

title: SBSTA

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: Delegates met informally in the morning, afternoon and evening to consider Co-Chairs' draft Terms of Reference for EGTT and draft conclusions.

title: SMALL ISLAND DEVELOPING STATES
abstract: Informal consultations facilitated by SBSTA Vice-Chair Amjah Abdulla were held Tuesday afternoon.

title: ADAPTATION
abstract: Delegates met in a contact group to discuss scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of impacts of, and vulnerability and adaptation to, climate change.

title: MITIGATION
abstract: In a contact group meeting co-chaired by Kok Seng Yap and Tashiyuki Sakamoto, delegates focused on reporting on 'lessons learned from the mitigation workshopsand any future steps under this agenda item,' and on how to report the outcomes.

title: CDM AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL TREATIES
abstract: Chair Georg Børsting presented draft conclusions.

abstract: Delegates at the contact group agreed on the importance of ensuring equitable access to the LDC Fund.

title: DOMESTIC ASPECTS OF ANNEX I POLICIES AND MEASURES
abstract: Artur Runge-Metzger, European Commission, stressed the EU climate programmes focus on cost-effective measures to meet the Kyoto targets, and cooperation with stakeholders.

title: INTERNATIONAL ASPECTS OF ANNEX I POLICIES AND MEASURES
abstract: Presentations: David Fuss, Natural Resources Canada, presented on Canadas P&Ms, emphasizing flexibility and fungibility of trading schemes.

title: CROSS-CUTTING ISSUES
abstract: Participants discussed Annex I Parties efforts to implement P&Ms in such a way as to minimize the adverse effects on non-Annex I Parties.

abstract: At this SBI contact group, delegates discussed Chair Ashes revised draft SB 22 conclusions and COP 11/MOP 1 decisions.

title: INTERNAL REVIEW OF THE SECRETARIATS ACTIVITIES
abstract: Chair Dovland convened this contact group on the internal review of the activities of the Secretariat (FCCC/2005/6) to review his revised draft.

actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This contact group considered the Chairs revised draft conclusions, including a number of items in brackets.

abstract: Informal consultations on national communications from non-Annex I Parties (FCCC/SBI/2004/L.27) were convened in the morning and evening to discuss a draft decision.

abstract: During informal consultations on this issue, delegates agreed to a draft decision based on conclusions from SBSTA 17 and 20.

title: SPECIAL CLIMATE CHANGE FUND (SCCF)
abstract: Following agreement on the SBI Chairs request not to propose new language but rather to work from the existing text, delegates discussed ways to remove the remaining brackets on priority and focal areas for the Fund.

title: CDM AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL TREATIES
abstract: Draft conclusions were finalized by Chair Børsting on the implications of project activities under the CDM for the achievement of objectives of other environmental conventions and protocols, as no further comments were received by Wednesday midday.

abstract: Informal consultations on national communications from non-Annex I Parties convened in the morning.

abstract: In the morning, delegates met in informal consultations to draft SBSTA conclusions and COP decisions, which were later presented to the contact group.

title: MATTERS RELATING TO THE LEAST DEVELOPED COUNTRIES
abstract: Delegates continued informal discussions on draft COP 11/MOP 1 decisions in the morning.

title: ADAPTATION
abstract: Delegates met for informal consultations in the morning and afternoon on the five-year programme of work on the scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of impacts of, and vulnerability and adaptation to, climate change.

title: MITIGATION
abstract: Delegates met informally to consider the Co-Chairs draft conclusions.

abstract: Informal consultations were facilitated by José Romero (Switzerland), with delegates considering draft conclusions.

abstract: Delegates met throughout the day in two informal sessions and in a small group setting.

title: SMALL ISLAND DEVELOPING STATES
abstract: Informal consultations continued, with delegates considering text on how SBSTA, SBI and/or the COP might address the issue of further implementation of the Mauritius Strategy for the Further Implementation of the Programme of Action for the Sustainable Development of Small Island Developing States.

title: SBI
abstract: SBI Chair Thomas Becker (Denmark) opened the meeting on Thursday evening, indicating that he wanted to conclude agreement on all outstanding issues.

abstract: Chair Becker noted that a contact group had developed draft conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.6 and L.6/Add.1).

title: MATTERS RELATING TO THE LEAST DEVELOPED COUNTRIES
abstract: Following lengthy negotiations throughout the day (see the 'Contact Groups and Informal Consultations' section, below), SBI adopted the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.14) and agreed to recommend the draft decision to COP 11 (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.14/Add.1).

title: PROGRAMME BUDGET FOR THE BIENNIUM 2006-2007
abstract: At 12:35 am Friday morning, Chair Becker announced that a final agreement on the budget for 2006-2007 had still not been reached.

title: IPCC REPORT ON SAFEGUARDING THE OZONE LAYER AND GLOBAL CLIMATE SYSTEM
abstract: At a SBSTA contact group held in the morning, delegates agreed on the draft conclusions presented by Chair Goetze, which will be forwarded to SBSTA for adoption.

title: ADAPTATION
abstract: Delegates met Thursday morning for ongoing consultations on the SBSTA programme of work on impacts, vulnerability and adaptation to climate change, and in the afternoon and evening to consider draft SBSTA conclusions and a draft COP decision.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: After lengthy negotiations throughout the day and into the evening, delegates reached agreement on the terms of reference for the EGTT and on draft conclusions.

title: MITIGATION
abstract: Delegates consulted informally and in a contact group to continue discussions on an appropriate forum for parties to present their views on lessons learned from the mitigation workshops and future steps under this agenda item.

title: EMISSIONS FROM INTERNATIONAL AVIATION AND MARITIME TRANSPORT
abstract: Informal consultations on this issue focused on whether to set out a process, which the EU and others supported, but SAUDI ARABIA and a number of other developing countries opposed.

title: SMALL ISLAND DEVELOPING STATES (SIDS)
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Delegates were unable to agree on text on this matter during consultations held earlier in the day.

title: PROGRAMME BUDGET FOR THE BIENNIUM 2006-2007
abstract: Following lengthy informal consultations, contact group Chair John Ashe introduced SBI draft conclusions to the contact group containing draft COP 11 decisions on the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol budgets for 2006-2007.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: On the Submission of second and, where appropriate, third national communications from Parties not included in Annex I to the Convention (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.9), the Co-Chairs of the informal consultations, Soobaraj Nayroo Sok Appadu (Mauritius) and Anders Turesson (Sweden), reported agreement.

title: MATTERS RELATING TO THE LEAST DEVELOPED COUNTRIES
abstract: SBI Chair Becker chaired this contact group meeting, presented draft SBI conclusions and COP 11/MOP 1 decisions, and proposed two revisions: that full-cost funding from the LDC Fund shall be to meet the 'agreed' costs of activities to adapt to the adverse effects of climate change as identified and prioritized in the NAPAs; and that adaptation to climate change is the reason for such funding rather than the 'sole' reason.

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
abstract: Karsten Sach (Germany) reported on contact group discussions and introduced draft conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.4), which addressed arrangements for COP 11 and COP/MOP 1, future sessional periods, organization of the intergovernmental process, and observer organizations in the Convention process.

title: SPECIAL CLIMATE CHANGE FUND (SCCF)
abstract: Contact group Co-Chairs Emily Ojoo-Massawa (Kenya) and Jozef Buys (Belgium) reported that, despite some progress, delegates had been unable to reach agreement.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: Level of Emissions for the Base Year of Croatia: Jim Penman (UK) reported that informal consultations had resulted in agreement on this matter (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.3).

title: Climate Neutral UNFCCC Meetings
abstract: Chair Becker explained that he had consulted informally and prepared draft conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.12).

title: Issues Relating to the Implementation of Decision 1/CP.10
abstract: Chair Becker also noted that three submissions had been made at SB 22 on Decision 1/CP.10 (Buenos Aires Programme of Work on Adaptation and Response Measures).

abstract: Budget Performance for the Biennium 2004-2005: SBI adopted conclusions on this sub-item (FCC/SBI/2005/L.5). Implementation of Paragraph 7(c) of the Financial Procedures of the Convention Concerning Financial Support for Participation in the UNFCCC Process: SBI adopted conclusions on this sub-item (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.10) following textual amendments proposed by Australia.

abstract: SBI adopted conclusions on this issue without comment (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.2).

abstract: The scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of impacts of, and vulnerability and adaptation to, climate change, were first taken up by SBSTA 22 on Thursday, 19 May.

abstract: SBSTA 22 took up a range of methodological issues, including emissions from fuel used for international aviation and maritime transport, technical guidance on methodologies for adjustments under the Protocol, and registry systems under the Protocol.

abstract: This issue was taken up at SBSTA 22 in plenary on Thursday, 19 May, when the UNFCCC Secretariat introduced an updated note (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/INF.2) on the topic.

abstract: With no agreement reached, SBSTA adopted brief revised conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.11/Rev.1), noting that SBSTA 22 did not complete its consideration of this issue, and will resume discussions at SBSTA 23.

abstract: This issue was first addressed in SBSTA plenary on Thursday, 19 May, and in two contact group meetings on Friday, 20 May, and Tuesday, 24 May.
