title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP 3 in Kyoto, Japan, agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries making the transition to a market economy (EITs) to achieve quantified emissions reduction targets.

title: TECHNICAL GUIDANCE ON METHODOLOGIES FOR ADJUSTMENTS UNDER THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Thursday, 19 May, and subsequently in four contact group meetings and in during informal consultations.

title: SBSTA Conclusions and Draft COP and COP/MOP Decisions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.2), SBSTA notes that it has considered the technical paper prepared by the Secretariat, and recommends a draft COP decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.2/Add.1), which includes a draft COP/MOP decision and an annex containing the technical guidance on methodologies for adjustments under LULUCF.

title: REGISTRY SYSTEMS UNDER THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: This item was first taken up on Thursday, 19 May, in SBSTAs opening plenary, when Murray Ward (New Zealand) presented the results of informal consultations held before SB 22.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.7), SBSTA takes note of the report on intersessional consultations on registry systems.

title: DEVELOPMENT AND TRANSFER OF TECHNOLOGIES
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: The development and transfer of technologies was first addressed at SBSTA 22 in plenary on Thursday, 19 May.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.13), SBSTA agrees on terms of reference to guide the EGTT in preparing recommendations for enhancing the implementation of the framework for meaningful and effective actions to enhance the implementation of UNFCCC Article 4.5 (technology transfer).

title: POLICIES AND MEASURES
abstract: The agenda item on 'good practices' in P&Ms among Annex I Parties was first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Thursday, 19 May.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.4), SBSTA notes that it has considered document FCCC/SBSTA/2004/INF.10 containing options for using web-based approaches for sharing information and experiences on 'good practices' among Annex I Parties.

title: RESEARCH NEEDS RELATING TO THE CONVENTION
abstract: This issue was first addressed in SBSTA plenary on Thursday, 19 May, and then in two contact group meetings co-chaired by María Paz Cigarán (Peru) and Sergio Castellari (Italy).

title: SBSTA Conclusions and Draft COP Decision
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.6), SBSTA welcomes the efforts of national, regional and international global change research programmes, and the endorsement of the 10-year Implementation Plan at the third Earth Observation Summit, which established the Global Earth Observation System of Systems.

title: THE BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION
abstract: The Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA) was negotiated at COP 4 in 1998, to set out a process for taking forward the provisions of the Protocol.

title: IPCC REPORT ON SAFEGUARDING THE OZONE LAYER AND GLOBAL CLIMATE SYSTEM: HYDROFLUOROCARBONS AND PERFLUOROCARBONS
abstract: This matter was first taken up by SBSTA on Thursday, 19 May, when Susan Solomon and Bert Metz of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) presented the main findings of the new IPCC special report that examines the alternatives to ozone-depleting substances that affect the global climate system.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.8), SBSTA thanks the IPCC and the Montreal Protocols Technology and Economic Assessment Panel for completing the Special Report on Safeguarding the Ozone Layer and the Global Climate System: Issues Related to Hydrofluorocarbons and Perfluorocarbons.

title: INTERNATIONAL MEETING TO REVIEW THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROGRAMME OF ACTION FOR SIDS
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer
abstract: This issue was taken up by SBSTA on Thursday, 19 May, when Tuvalu, for AOSIS, noted that the UN General Assembly will consider the Mauritius Strategy during its upcoming session, and proposed that SBSTA consider the Strategy at SBSTA 23.

title: GLOBAL CLIMATE OBSERVING SYSTEM
abstract: SBSTA considered this matter briefly on Thursday, 19 May, when Vice-Chair Abdulla said he would draft conclusions on the Global Climate Observing System (GCOS), and noted concerns voiced by Argentina about territorial water issues and drifting buoys.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.9), SBSTA welcomes the report on progress towards implementing the initial ocean climate observing system, prepared by the GCOS Secretariat (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/MISC/5).

title: IMPLEMENTATION OF KYOTO PROTOCOL ARTICLE 2.3
abstract: Issues relating to the implementation of Protocol Article 2.3 (adverse effects of P&Ms) were first addressed by SBSTA in plenary on Thursday, 19 May.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.5), SBSTA notes that it did not complete its consideration of issues relating to Protocol Article 2.3, and agrees to continue consideration of these issues at SBSTA 23.

title: CLOSING PLENARY
abstract: On Friday, 27 May, SBSTA 22 held its closing plenary meeting.

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR IMPLEMENTATION
actors: Group of 77 and China|European Union|Environmental Integrity Group|Umbrella Group|African Group|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: SBI Chair Thomas Becker (Denmark) opened the session on Friday morning, 20 May.

title: NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS FROM NON-ANNEX I PARTIES
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: After remaining unresolved since COP 9, timeframes for non-Annex I Parties submissions of second and, where appropriate, third national communications and related issues were finally resolved at SBI 22 following a series of informal consultations held from 23-25 May.

title: THE MARRAKESH ACCORDS
abstract: Delegates continued discussions on the Bonn Agreements at COP 7 in October/November 2001.

title: SBI Conclusions and Draft COP Decision
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.9), the SBI agrees to include a draft decision recommended for adoption by COP 11, stating that non-Annex I Parties shall make all efforts to submit second and, where appropriate, third national communications, within four years of initial disbursement for the actual preparation of the national communication, on an agreed full-cost basis. In the draft COP decision, the COP notes that Parties, if necessary and based on their national circumstances, may use an extension of up to one year for submission, after informing the Secretariat; and that any extensions shall not imply additional financial resources from the GEF.

title: COMPILATION AND SYNTHESIS OF INITIAL NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Draft conclusions on the compilation and synthesis of initial national communications were drawn up by SBI Chair Becker, and adopted by SBI on Thursday evening, 26 May.

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: UNFCCC Functioning|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.8), SBI notes its consideration of document FCCC/SBI/2005/INF.2 containing the list of projects submitted by non-Annex I Parties in accordance with UNFCCC Article 12.4 (projects proposed by developing countries).

title: WORK OF THE CONSULTATIVE GROUP OF EXPERTS ON NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS FROM NON-ANNEX I PARTIES
topics: UNFCCC Functioning|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: This issue was first raised at an SBI plenary session on Friday, 20 May, when Emily Ojoo-Massawa (Kenya), Chair of the Consultative Group of Experts on non-Annex I national communications (CGE), made an oral presentation based on a progress report on the CGEs work (FCCC/SBI/2005/7), including a meeting in Mozambique, and CGE hands-on training workshops for the Asia and Africa regions.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.11), the SBI notes the oral report of the Chair of the CGE and the outcomes of CGE hands-on training workshops.

title: PROVISION OF FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: After being briefly considered in plenary on Friday, 20 May, draft conclusions on the provision of financial and technical support provided by GEF for the preparation of initial and subsequent national communications were drawn up by SBI Chair Becker.

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds 1|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.7), SBI welcomes information by the GEF Secretariat on financial support made available for the preparation of initial and subsequent national communications (FCCC/SBI/2005/INF.1).

title: SPECIAL CLIMATE CHANGE FUND
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBI on Friday, 20 May.

title: MATTERS RELATING TO THE LEAST DEVELOPED COUNTRIES
abstract: This issue was first addressed by the SBI, on Friday, 20 May, when delegates were briefed by LDC Expert Group (LEG) Chair Paul Desanker (Malawi) on the LEGs April 2005 meeting, and by Ricardo Moita (Portugal) and Richard Muyungi (Tanzania) on pre-sessional activities involving representatives from a number of Annex II Parties, LDCs, the GEF and implementing agencies.

title: SBI Conclusions and Draft COP Decision
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: The SBI conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.14/Add.1) contain a draft COP decision, in which the COP states that the operation of the LDC Fund should be consistent with the following principles: a country-driven approach, supporting the implementation of urgent and immediate activities identified in NAPAs, as a way of enhancing adaptive capacity; support for implementation of activities identified in NAPAs and of other elements of the LDC work programme as identified in decision 5/CP.7, to promote the integration of adaptation measures in national development and poverty reduction strategies, plans or policies, with a view to increasing resilience to the adverse effects of climate change; and support for a learning-by-doing approach. Also included in the draft decision are: a decision that full-cost funding shall be provided by the LDC Fund to meet the additional costs - defined as 'the costs imposed on vulnerable countries to meet their immediate adaptation need' - of activities to adopt to the adverse effects of climate change as identified and prioritized in the NAPAs; a request that GEF develop a co-financing scale for supporting activities identified in the NAPAs, taking into account the circumstances of LDCs; a decision that activities identified in NAPAs that are not supported through full-cost funding as described above will be co-financed through the co-financing scale; a request that SBI 23 review experience gained from the implementation of NAPAs, including those in accessing funds from the LDC Fund; and a decision that COP 14 is to assess progress and consider the adoption of further guidance, as appropriate.

title: COP 8 AND COP 9
abstract: Delegates met at COP 8 in October/November 2002, and again at COP 9 in December 2003, to negotiate decisions for implementing the Marrakesh Accords.

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
abstract: The agenda item on arrangements for intergovernmental meetings was first taken up by SBI in plenary on Friday, 20 May, when COP Secretary Richard Kinley briefed delegates on the sub-items under this agenda, namely, preparations for COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 in Montreal (FCCC/SBI/2005/4 and Corr.1), future sessional periods, organization of the intergovernmental process, and observer organizations in the UNFCCC process. On future sessional periods, Richard Kinley noted an IPCC request to postpone COP 13 for three or four weeks to avoid it occurring too soon after the finalization of the synthesis report of the IPCCs Fourth Assessment Report.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: The conclusions, (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.4) address arrangements relating to COP 11 and COP/MOP 1, future sessional periods, organization of the intergovernmental process, and observer organizations in the Convention process. On COP 11 and COP/MOP 1, the SBI thanks the Government of Canada for offering to host the event, and requests the host country to facilitate the issuance of visas to ensure Parties effective participation.

title: BUDGET PERFORMANCE FOR THE BIENNIUM 2004-2005
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: This issue was first addressed by SBI in plenary on Friday, 20 May.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.5), SBI takes note of the interim financial statements (FCCC/SBI/2005/INF.4), expresses concern over the considerable amount of outstanding contributions, and urges Parties that have not yet made their contributions to do so as soon as possible.

title: PROGRAMME BUDGET FOR THE BIENNIUM 2006-2007
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: This issue was first addressed by the SBI on Friday, 20 May.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.15/Rev.1), SBI decides to: recommend that COP 11 approve the core programme budget for the biennium 2006-2007; propose a contingency budget for conference services of US$7,828, 611; authorize the Executive Secretary to notify Parties of their 2006 contributions; and requests the Executive Secretary to prepare a revision of document FCCC/SBI/2005/8/Add.1 that will contain the mandates for the activities reflected therein.

title: FINANCIAL PROCEDURES CONCERNING SUPPORT FOR PARTICIPATION IN THE UNFCCC PROCESS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: Implementation of paragraph 7(c) of the UNFCCCs Financial Procedures (financial support for participation) was first addressed by SBI in plenary on Friday, 20 May.

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.10), SBI takes note of document FCCC/SBI/2005/3 regarding the suspension of this practice, decides that more time is required to determine the financial implications of the suspension and decides to maintain the status quo through 31 December 2007.

title: IMPLEMENTATION OF THE HEADQUARTERS AGREEMENT
abstract: This issue was taken up briefly in SBI plenary on Friday, 20 May, when Germany and Executive Secretary Joke Waller-Hunter reported on the Headquarters Agreement and on progress on extending it to cover the Protocol.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.2), the SBI takes note of the statements of the host government and the Executive Secretary at SBI 22, requests the Executive Secretary to inform SBI of any new developments, and invites the host government to report on further progress with implementing the Headquarters Agreement at SBI 24.

title: SB 20
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: In June 2004, delegates met in Bonn at the twentieth sessions of SBI and SBSTA.

title: INTERNAL REVIEW OF THE ACTIVITIES OF THE SECRETARIAT
abstract: The internal review of the Secretariats activities was taken up by SBI in plenary on Friday, 20 May, when Joke Waller-Hunter reported on an interim review (FCCC/SBI/2005/6), noting a lack of resources to meet demands, and inviting guidance from Parties.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions on this matter (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.6), SBI notes the volume and scope of the Secretariats activities, and encourages the Executive Secretary to address challenges faced and implement initiatives set out in her report (FCCC/SBI/2005/6, Annex I).

title: LEVEL OF EMISSIONS FOR THE BASE YEAR OF CROATIA
abstract: SBI Chair Becker introduced this issue on Friday, 20 May, noting that it had been on the agenda for several years, and expressing hope that it could be resolved at this meeting.

title: SBI Conclusions and Draft COP Decision
abstract: The SBI conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.3) on flexibility for Croatia under UNFCCC Article 4.6 (flexibility for EIT Annex I Parties) contain a draft decision for COP 11.

title: CLIMATE NEUTRAL UNFCCC MEETINGS
abstract: This item was first taken on Friday, 20 May, when SBI considered a report on making UNFCCC meetings 'climate neutral' (FCCC/SBI/2005/9).

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.12), SBI welcomes Canadas statement that it intends to make COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 climate neutral.

title: ISSUES RELATING TO THE IMPLEMENTATION OF DECISION 1/CP.10
abstract: On Friday, 27 May, SBI Chair Becker noted in plenary that three submissions had been made at SB 22 on decision 1/CP.10 (Buenos Aires Programme of Work on Adaptation and Response Measures).

title: CLOSING PLENARY
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: On Friday, 27 May, Executive Secretary Joke Waller-Hunter made a statement in which she noted that SBI had completed work on some longstanding issues, labeling this a 'major success.

title: GROWING PAINS AND THE NEW CARBON MARKET
abstract: It is widely believed that, given the current discussions on the post-2012 scenario, the COP/MOP must - at the very least - send out a strong signal of forward-looking confidence and durability to the world, to governments and, not least, to the markets where carbon has now been established by the climate change regime as a viable commodity.

title: COP 10
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: COP 10 was held in Buenos Aires, Argentina, from 6-18 December 2004.

title: CDM 'COULD DO MORE'
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims|Technology Transfer
abstract: Some experts have suggested that the price is now approaching a level that will encourage energy market players and utilities to switch to cleaner forms of power generation, thus underlining the importance of debates around the G-8 and at the SOGE on long-range decisions on technology investment and deployment. There was much discussion - inside the negotiating rooms and in the corridors - about the future management of the CDM, as companies and countries have grown impatient over the three years it has taken to establish national and international level CDM-related institutions and approve the first projects.

title: SOME ISSUES TO LOOK OUT FOR AT COP 11 AND COP/MOP 1
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: There are few expectations that Parties will emerge from the COP/MOP with a 'Montreal Mandate' (as mooted by South Africa at the SOGE), that actually establishes the post-2012 framework.

title: A COMPLIANCE MECHANISM
abstract: While a legally-binding compliance mechanism is recognized as an essential component of domestic legal regimes, the Kyoto Protocol compliance mechanism will break new ground in its scope and complexity.

title: ADAPTATION AND LIABILITY
abstract: Adaptation was another issue where deliberations at the SOGE spilled over into deliberations at SB 22, with the development of a five-year 'skeleton' programme of work the focus of discussion, in response to an important COP 10 decision.

title: STORMS AHEAD - THE LONG RANGE WEATHER FORECAST
actors: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: There were already signs of the jockeying and positioning that will happen at Montreal, given that the process is about to enter new and uncharted waters.

title: UNFCCC SEMINAR OF GOVERNMENTAL EXPERTS
abstract: The Seminar of Governmental Experts (SOGE) was held from 16-17 May 2005, in Bonn.

title: SB 22 REPORT
actors: Least Developed Countries|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: During SB 22, the Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice (SBSTA) convened five times in plenary, as well as in a number of contact groups and informal consultations, to make progress on the items on its agenda.

title: METHODOLOGIES FOR TECHNICAL NEEDS ASSESSMENTS
topics: Reasons for Concern|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: Yamil Bonduki, United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), presented the UNDP handbook for conducting TNAs and preliminary results of UNDP analysis of TNA reports.

title: Discussion
abstract: In the ensuing discussion, participants highlighted a number of issues, including: the voluntary basis for submitting TNAs to the Secretariat; the importance of national development policies to inform the elaboration of TNAs; the synergies between Least Developed Countries (LDC) National Adaptation Programme of Actions (NAPAs) and TNAs to implement climate change measures; and TNA limitations regarding ways to identify technologies that can be adjusted to national circumstances.

title: NEEDS FOR TECHNOLOGIES
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Florin Vladu presented needs for adaptation technologies as expressed in TNAs, national communications and other national reports, summarizing results from the Annex I Parties third national communications.

title: Discussion
abstract: Participants addressed issues, including: the limitation of technology options available; the challenges of implementing TNAs; ways to identify and prioritize technologies under the climate change framework; the use of the APF to select adaptation projects at country level; and ways to access funding windows within the GEF for projects under the Convention. One participant underscored the need to start elaborating the national development policy before carrying out TNAs.

title: Discussion
topics: Reasons for Concern|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: On water resources and agriculture in West Africa, one participant asked whether the technologies studied were autonomously adopted or introduced.

title: FINANCING THE TRANSFER OF TECHNOLOGIES FOR ADAPTATION TO CLIMATE CHANGE
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: On Wednesday morning, delegates heard presentations and discussed opportunities for financing the transfer of technologies for adaptation.

title: Discussion
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: In the ensuing discussion, participants addressed opportunities for financing the transfer of adaptation technology.

title: LESSONS LEARNED AND POSSIBLE SYNERGY WITH ONGOING ACTIVITIES
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Markus Lehmann, Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), summarized the CBD objectives: conservation of biodiversity; sustainable use of its components; and fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resources.

title: Discussion
abstract: One participant pointed to inconsistencies between transfer of technology in the CBD and the Agreement on Trade- Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS).

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: Technology transfer is considered a key element in combating climate change under the UNFCCC.

title: Discussion
abstract: In the ensuing discussion, one participant highlighted the complexity of managing an integrated assessment that combines numerous elements. Answering a question on regional cooperation and transfer of technology, Alam said that at the moment there is no cooperation regarding the issue.

title: ADAPTATION
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: Adaptation is a cross-cutting theme of the UNFCCC and is referred to in different articles.

title: BACKGROUND AND CONTEXT
topics: Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: Wanna Tanunchaiwatana, UNFCCC Secretariat, presented the background and context for the seminar.

title: SEMINAR EXPECTATIONS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: A number of participants presented comments and inputs regarding seminar expectations.

title: Discussion
topics: Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: Several developing countries highlighted the need for: focusing on the means to transfer technology from developed countries to developing countries; providing concrete examples of transferring adaptation technology; promoting stakeholder participation; and defining technological needs for adaptation in national assessments.

title: IPCC WORKSHOP ON EMISSION SCENARIOS
abstract: At this meeting, held from 29 June to 1 July 2005, in Laxenburg, Austria, participants investigated the possible roles that the IPCC could play in the development and assessment of new emission scenarios in the period after AR4 by identifying: various user needs and requirements; scenarios for meeting those needs; and options for the IPCC with regard to the development of such scenarios.

title: KEY IPCC PRODUCTS
abstract: The IPCC completed its initial comprehensive assessments of climate change in the First Assessment Report in 1990 and the Second Assessment Report in 1995.

title: NINETEENTH SESSION
abstract: Beginning at its nineteenth session, held from 17-20 April 2002, in Geneva, Switzerland, the IPCC began work on the AR4.

title: TWENTIETH SESSION
abstract: IPCC-20 was held from 19-21 February 2003, in Paris, France.

title: TWENTY-FIRST SESSION
abstract: At IPCC-21, held from 3-7 November 2003, in Vienna, Austria, participants reviewed the outlines of the proposed Working Group contributions to the AR4 and the Chairs proposal for an AR4 Synthesis Report.

title: TWENTY-SECOND SESSION
abstract: IPCC-22 convened from 9-11 November 2004, in New Delhi, India.

title: TWENTY-THIRD SESSION
abstract: IPCC-23 was convened on 8 April 2005, in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to consider the joint activities of Working Groups I and II on the Special Report on Safeguarding the Ozone Layer and the Global Climate System.

title: IPCC EXPERT MEETING ON EMISSION ESTIMATION OF AEROSOLS RELEVANT TO CLIMATE CHANGE
abstract: This expert meeting, organized by the Task Force on National Greenhouse Gas Inventories with the assistance of WGI, was held from 2-4 May 2005, in Geneva, Switzerland, to conduct a preliminary assessment of issues related to developing estimates for anthropogenic emissions of aerosols and to discuss methodological approaches.

title: TWENTY-SECOND SESSIONS OF THE SUBSIDIARY BODIES TO THE UNFCCC
abstract: At SB-22, held from 19-27 May 2005, in Bonn, Germany, the UNFCCCs Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice (SBSTA) considered the Special Report on Safeguarding the Ozone Layer and the Global Climate System prepared by the IPCC and the Technology and Assessment Panel of the Montreal Protocol.

title: What is the current status of CCS technology?
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Reasons for Concern|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Pre-Kyoto|Flexibility Mechanims|Technology Transfer
abstract: BELGIUM said that a figure representing capture systems was unclear and proposed using a figure from the Special Report instead.

title: What are the local health, safety and environmental risks of CCS?
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Flexibility Mechanims|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: On local risks associated with carbon dioxide pipeline transport, ZAMBIA sought clarification of a statement that the risks are possibly lower than comparable hydrocarbon pipelines.

title: What are the Gaps in Knowledge?
abstract: AUSTRIA, with support from GERMANY, BELGIUM, and others, proposed the addition of a new section in the SPM, which notes that there are gaps in knowledge regarding some aspects of CCS, and that increasing knowledge and experience would reduce uncertainties and facilitate decision making.
HUNGARY, AUSTRALIA, AUSTRIA, CANADA, NORWARY and the NETHERLANDS noted the importance of outreach on the CCS Special Report.
IPCC Secretary Christ outlined outreach activities on the CCS Special Report already underway.
During the lunch break, the Financial Task Team, co-chaired by Marc Gillet (France) and Zhenlin Chen (China), convened consultations on this issue.

title: Working Group II
abstract: Osvaldo Canziani (Argentina), WG II Co-Chair, said progress included the submission of the WG II first order draft and the commencement of its expert review, and the initial drafting of the Technical Summary and the Summary for Policy Makers.

title: Working Group III
abstract: WG III Co-Chair Metz presented the WG III progress report, and said the CCS Special Report should be ready by the end of 2005.

title: AR4 Synthesis Report
abstract: Chair Pachauri informed delegates of: the arrangements for management of the AR4 Synthesis Report; the results of a meeting of the IPCC Bureau Co-Chairs and Heads of the TSU in Baarn, the Netherlands; and the budgetary implications of the AR4 Synthesis Report, estimated at SF 634,000.

title: Task Group on Data and Scenario Support for Impact and Climate Assessment
abstract: TGICA Co-Chair Richard Moss (US) highlighted the problems posed by lack of data in specific regions or sectors, and by the need for training and capacity building in developing countries.
Chair Pachauri referred to the work scheduled for IPCC-24, including consideration of a fifth assessment report.
FRANCE and GERMANY questioned whether work on aerosols is sufficiently advanced to give rise to work on inventories.

Along with the timing of the AR4 Synthesis Report, attention both in the corridors and in plenary shifted to consideration of election procedures, emission scenarios, aerosols, outreach and the budget.
Klaus Töpfer, UNEP Executive Director, emphasized the importance of the CCS Special Report, noting that CCS has an important role to play in addressing climate change.

Hong Yan, Deputy Secretary-General, WMO, highlighted the importance of the recent IPCC/TEAP Special Report on Safeguarding the Ozone Layer and the Global Climate System (Ozone Special Report), and encouraged the IPCC to work with WMO members to disseminate it.

Halldor Thorgeirsson, UNFCCC Secretariat, noted the relevance of the CCS Special Report, the Ozone Special Report, and the AR4 to policy making, and the importance of effective and balanced outreach activities.
Delegates approved the provisional agenda.

GERMANY, with support from many countries and GREENPEACE, and opposed by SAUDI ARABIA, proposed the development of a special report on renewable energy and energy efficiency technologies, and BELGIUM suggested inclusion of this issue on the agenda for IPCC-25.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text notes that the SPM considers CCS to be an option in the portfolio of mitigation actions for stabilization of atmospheric greenhouse gas emissions, and that the TAR indicates that no single technology option will provide all of the emission reductions needed to achieve stabilization, but that a portfolio of mitigation measures will be needed.

title: What are the characteristics of CCS?
abstract: Delegates considered this section of the SPM on Thursday.

title: What is the current status of CCS technology?
abstract: This question was addressed in plenary on Friday.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text describes types of CO2 capture systems; explains means of transporting CO2 according to the distance and amount to be transported; and notes relevant technologies for CO2 storage in both deep geological formations and in the ocean floor, noting that ocean storage and its ecological impacts are still in the research phase.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text states that large point sources of CO2 are concentrated close to major industrial and urban areas, many of them within 300 km of potential geological storage sites, and that preliminary research suggests that, globally, a small proportion of large point sources are close to potential ocean storage locations.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text: describes and elaborates on cost increases in electricity generation associated with the use of CCS in electricity production; explains that retrofitting existing plants with CO2 capture is expected to lead to higher costs and lower efficiencies than for newly built power plants with capture; states that in most CCS systems, the cost of capture is the largest cost component; and notes that energy and economic models indicate that the major contribution of CCS systems to climate change mitigation would come from deployment in the electricity sector, with most modeling suggesting that CCS systems start to deploy at a significant level when CO2 prices begin to reach approximately US$25-30 per ton of CO2. The text further notes that: it is likely that, worldwide, there is a technical potential of at least about 2,000 Gt CO2 of storage capacity in geological formations; the economic potential of CCS averaged over a range of baseline scenarios would mean that CCS contributes 15 to 55% to the cumulative mitigation effort worldwide until 2100, although uncertainties in these economic potential estimates are significant; and the role of CCS in mitigation portfolios increases and is found to reduce stabilization costs over the course of the century in most scenarios.

title: What are the local health, safety and environment risks of CCS?
abstract: Delegates took up this section of the SPM in plenary on Saturday.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text states, inter alia, that: the local risks associated with CO2 pipelines could be similar or lower than those posed by existing hydrocarbon pipelines; the risks of geological storage would be comparable to those of natural gas storage with the appropriate measures; the effects of CO2 on marine organisms will have ecosystem consequences; the chronic effects of CO2 injection into oceans have not yet been studied over large ocean areas and long time scales; and the environmental impacts of large-scale mineral carbonation would be a consequence of the required mining and disposal of the resulting products. Will physical leakage of stored CO2 compromise CCS as a climate mitigation option?

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text states, inter alia, that: the fraction of CO2 retained in appropriately selected and managed geological reservoirs is likely to exceed 99% over 1,000 years; the release of CO2 from ocean storage would be gradual over hundreds of years; and if continuous leakage of CO2 occurs, it could, at least in part, offset the benefits of CCS for mitigating climate change. What are the legal and regulatory issues for implementing CO2 storage?

title: KEY IPCC PRODUCTS
abstract: The IPCC completed its initial comprehensive assessments of climate change in the First Assessment Report in 1990 and the Second Assessment Report in 1995.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text: provides a non-exhaustive list of regulations for operations in the subsurface that may be applicable to geological storage; states that long-term liability issues associated with CO2 leakage and local environmental impacts are unresolved; notes that no formal interpretations exist on the compatibility of CO2 injection into the sub-seabed or ocean with certain provisions of international law; and states that several treaties, notably the London and OSPAR Conventions, are potentially applicable. What are the implications of CCS for emission inventories and accounting?

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text states that the current IPCC Guidelines do not provide specific methods for estimating emissions associated with CCS, and that such methods are expected to be provided in the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories.

title: What about public perception of CCS?
abstract: Delegates took up this section of the SPM in plenary on Saturday.

title: What are the gaps in knowledge?
abstract: Delegates considered this issue in plenary on Saturday.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text notes that there are gaps in knowledge on some aspects of CCS.

title: Final Decision
abstract: In addition to approving the programme and budget for 2006-08, the Panel also: took into account the carry over from 2004, noting that CHF5.5 million is estimated as the averaged yearly total of contributions needed for sufficient carry over to ensure transition to the next assessment period; adopted the revised budget for 2006; took note of the forecast budget for 2007 and of the indicative budgets for 2008; and invited governments that may be in a position to do so to contribute to the IPCC Trust Fund.

title: Privileges and Immunities
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: CDM Executive Board Chair Sushma Gera highlighted concerns among members and experts of constituted bodies under the Kyoto Protocol about the potential risks of legal action, noting that individuals are not covered by the relevant UN instruments, although the UNFCCC Headquarters Agreement with the German Government could afford protection, at least in Germany.

title: ARTICLE 3.9 OF THE PROTOCOL (FUTURE COMMITMENTS)
abstract: Co-Chair Drake presented a compilation of Conference Room Paper submissions by the G-77/China, EU and Japan.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE PROTOCOL
abstract: Co-Chair Turesson presented a new Co-Chairs draft decision based on a submission by the G-77/China on capacity building relating to the implementation of the Protocol in developing countries.

title: CDM EXECUTIVE BOARD REPORT
abstract: Two informal meetings were held on Saturday.

title: COMPLIANCE
abstract: Informal consultations continued on the adoption of the compliance mechanism and Saudi Arabias proposal to amend the Protocol to make the mechanism legally binding.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM
abstract: Adaptation Fund: Delegates met throughout Saturday in closed informal consultations in an attempt to make progress on the Adaptation Fund text.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSACTION LOG
abstract: Delegates concluded their work on a draft decision on the international transaction log relating to registry systems under Article 7.4 of the Kyoto Protocol.

title: ADAPTATION
abstract: Consultations convened by Helen Plume (New Zealand) and Kishan Kumarsingh (Trinidad and Tobago) resumed on the SBSTA five year programme of work on adaptation, with informal discussions still continuing as of 11:45 pm.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM
abstract: Informal consultations on the Adaptation Fund continued through the day, while the contact group reconvened in the evening to take up other outstanding items.

title: Adaptation Fund
abstract: Delegates engaged in line-by-line discussion of the Co-Chairs draft text.

title: GEF Report to the COP
abstract: Delegates agreed to revised draft SBI conclusions that are consistent with the contact groups previous decision that the conclusions should be short and focus on taking note of the report.

title: Special Climate Change Fund
abstract: SBI Chair Becker began informal consultations to resolve bracketed text.

title: Implementation of Decision 5/CP.8
abstract: Delegates agreed to the draft SBI conclusions that were considered at the previous meeting of the contact group.

title: Additional Guidance to the GEF
abstract: Delegates agreed to a draft COP decision that focuses on requesting the GEF to provide additional information on the impact of the RAF on the climate change focal area.

title: Application of the MOU between the COP and the GEF Council
abstract: The Co-Chairs introduced a draft decision, noting that while the decision would apply, mutatis mutandis, the MOU with respect to guidance to the entity entrusted with the operation of the financial mechanism of the Convention, it would not apply to the Adaptation Fund, as no decision has been taken on the operational entity for that fund.

title: JOINT IMPLEMENTATION (JI)
abstract: During informal consultations, Parties considered parts of a Chairs draft COP/MOP decision.

title: MITIGATION
abstract: The group met informally in the afternoon and late into the night.

title: REPORT OF THE CDM EXECUTIVE BOARD
abstract: Co-Chairs David Brackett (Canada) and André do Lago (Brazil) explained that five separate consultations had been held earlier on Monday with interested Parties on: administrative issues; additionality; carbon dioxide capture and storage under the CDM; share of proceeds to cover administrative expenses of the Executive Board; and whether local, national or regional policy standards and programmes can be considered CDM project activities.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS
abstract: Privileges and Immunities for Individuals Serving on Constituted Bodies under the Kyoto Protocol: Contact group Chair Masao Nakayama (Micronesia) requested comments from Parties.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: Co-Chair Holger Liptow (Germany) reported to the contact group that a draft decision had been approved during informal consultations late Saturday, pending an agreement on draft conclusions.

title: ARTICLE 3.9 (FUTURE COMMITMENTS)
abstract: Delegates convened in the evening for further informal consultations.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING
abstract: The group met informally in the afternoon and late into the night.

title: CDM IMPLICATIONS FOR OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL TREATIES
abstract: Parties agreed to a draft COP/MOP decision and draft SBSTA conclusions presented by Chair Georg Børsting (Norway) on the implications of the establishment of new HCFC-22 facilities seeking to obtain CERs for the destruction of HFC-23.

title: COMPLIANCE
abstract: Parties met for informal consultations on the adoption of the compliance mechanism and Saudi Arabias proposal to amend the Protocol.

title: DEFORESTATION IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Environmental Integrity Group
abstract: Chair Hernán Carlino (Argentina) presented draft conclusions.

title: DETERMINATION OF A QUANTIFIED EMISSION REDUCTION COMMITMENT FOR BELARUS
abstract: Informal consultations were convened by Andrej Kranjc (Slovenia).

title: EMISSIONS FROM INTERNATIONAL AVIATION AND MARITIME TRANSPORT
abstract: Bilateral and small-group consultations with interested Parties were convened by José Romero (Switzerland).

title: SBI
abstract: Chair Thomas Becker (Denmark) opened the session at 6:30 pm.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM
abstract: Adaptation Fund: Delegates considered financial issues in a contact group and informal discussions.

title: Guidance to the GEF
abstract: Delegates continued discussions in a contact group, considering a revised draft decision that would apply the current MOU between the COP and the GEF to the COP/MOP and GEF.

title: Special Climate Change Fund
abstract: With no agreement on his proposal to remove the remaining brackets in the draft conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.34), Chair Becker introduced new conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/CRP.4).

title: GEF Report to the COP
abstract: SBI adopted conclusions on this matter (FCCC/2005/SBI/L.30).

title: Implementation of Decision 5/CP.8
abstract: SBI adopted conclusions on this issue (FCCC/2005/SBI/L.28). Additional Guidance to an Operating Entity of the Financial Mechanism: SBI adopted the conclusions (FCCC/2005/SBI/L.29).

title: REPORT OF SBI 23
abstract: SBI agreed to the report of the session (FCCC/2005/SBI/L.16), and Chair Becker closed SBI 23 at 9:34 pm.

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES UNDER THE PROTOCOL
abstract: SBSTA adopted conclusions on criteria for cases of failure to submit information relating to estimates of greenhouse gas emissions and a draft COP/MOP decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.18 & Add.1).

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES UNDER THE CONVENTION
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: SBSTA adopted conclusions on harvested wood products (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.16) and conclusions and a draft COP decision on the common reporting format (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.19 & Add.1). Emissions from Fuel Used for International Aviation and Maritime Transport: José Romero (Switzerland) reported to SBSTA that no consensus had been reached in consultations.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSACTION LOG
abstract: SBSTA adopted conclusions and a draft COP/MOP decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.20 &Add.1).

title: SIDS
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Chair Benrageb proposed holding the agenda item on follow up to the International Meeting to Review the Implementation of the Programme of Action for the Sustainable Development of SIDS in abeyance.

title: ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: SBI agreed to streamline review procedures for Annex I national communications under the Convention during the period 2006-2007 (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.23) and to review processes for reporting required under the Protocol from Annex I Parties in 2006-2007 (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.24).

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: On development and transfer of technologies, SBSTA adopted conclusions on matters relating to the implementation of the framework (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.24) and the Work Programme of the EGTT for 2006 (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.23) and a draft COP decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.24/Add.1).

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION
abstract: SBSTA adopted conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.17).

title: COOPERATION WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS
abstract: Parties adopted conclusions, including text on carbon dioxide capture and storage (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.26).

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: SBSTA adopted conclusions on various progress reports (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.25).

title: MITIGATION
abstract: Consideration of this issue resumed in a morning contact group, following informal consultations that continued until late Monday night.

title: ADAPTATION
abstract: Following extensive consultations, SBSTA adopted conclusions and forwarded a bracketed draft decision to the COP for its consideration (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.30 & Add.1).

title: REPORT OF SBSTA 23
abstract: SBSTA agreed to the report of the session (FCCC/2005/SBSTA/L.15).

title: COMPLIANCE
abstract: Co-Chair Dovland noted that an agreement had not been possible even after several informal consultations.

title: JOINT IMPLEMENTATION (JI)
abstract: In the contact group, Chair Stoycheva explained that she had held 'Friends of the Chair' consultations late on Monday evening, and informal consultations earlier on Tuesday.

title: DEFORESTATION IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
abstract: Delegates resumed informal consultations and agreed to a draft COP decision inviting submissions from Parties and accredited observers by 31 March 2006 on relevant scientific, technical and methodological issues, and on the exchange of relevant information, including policy approaches and positive incentives.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: SBI adopted conclusions on the work of the Consultative Group of Experts on National Communications from non-Annex I Parties (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.27), compilation and synthesis of initial national communications (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.26), and financial and technical support (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.25/Rev.1).

title: CDM EXECUTIVE BOARD REPORT
abstract: Delegates met informally to consider outstanding issues in the Co-Chairs draft decision.

title: ARTICLE 3.9 (FUTURE COMMITMENTS)
abstract: Delegates continued to meet informally to consider future commitments under the Protocol.

title: UNFCCC ARTICLE 6
abstract: SBI adopted conclusions on education, training and public awareness (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.18).

title: IMPLEMENTATION OF UNFCCC ARTICLE 4.8 AND 4.9
abstract: On matters relating to LDCs, SBI adopted conclusions on a new mandate for the LDC Expert Group (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.17).

title: ADMINISTRATIVE AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS
abstract: Parties adopted conclusions and a draft COP decision on Budget performance with regard to the Convention for 2004-2005 (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.21 & Add.1), and conclusions and a draft COP/MOP decision on Budget performance with regard to the Protocol for 2004-2005 (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.22 & Add.1).

title: REVIEW OF THE SECRETARIAT
abstract: SBI adopted the relevant conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.20).

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE CONVENTION
abstract: SBI adopted conclusions on this issue (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.36).

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE PROTOCOL
abstract: SBI adopted conclusions and draft decisions on capacity building relating to implementation of the Kyoto Protocol in developing countries (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.35) and EIT countries (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.37).

title: OPENING OF THE MEETING
abstract: COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 President Stéphane Dion outlined progress on what he referred to as the 'three Is' of 'implementation, improvement, and innovation.

title: Post-2012
abstract: IRELAND, MALTA, REPUBLIC OF KOREA and others supported launching a process at this conference, and NORWAY supported more ambitious commitments.

title: Synergies and Cooperation
abstract: MALI emphasized the promotion of synergies between environmental conventions and proposed evaluating the contribution of environmental efforts to poverty reduction.

title: Technology Development and Transfer
abstract: NORWAY and AUSTRALIA highlighted the importance of technology.

title: REPORT OF THE CDM EXECUTIVE BOARD
abstract: After informal consultations, delegates agreed to forward a Co-Chairs draft decision to COP/MOP 1.

title: COMPLIANCE
abstract: Following informal consultations, Co-Chair Mamadou Honadia introduced a draft decision stating that Parties 'approve and adopt' the compliance mechanism as contained in Decision 24/CP.7.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.9
abstract: Informal consultations continued on future commitments under Protocol Article 3.9.

title: FUTURE ACTIONS UNDER THE UNFCCC
abstract: Discussions continued in a roundtable discussion on future actions under the Convention based on a proposal by President Dion (FCCC/CP/2005/CRP.1).

title: STATEMENTS FROM UN BODIES AND AGENCIES
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|IPCC Governance|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: The WORLD METEOROLOGICAL ORGANIZATION highlighted the value of climate monitoring and research that involves national meteorological services and developing countries.

title: COUNTRY STATEMENTS
abstract: Ministers and heads of delegation made statements highlighting issues such as adaptation, extreme weather events, CDM reform, funding and capacity building, commitments under the Kyoto Protocol, technology transfer, the post-2012 process, and the adoption of the Marrakesh Accords. In a video statement, French President Jacques Chirac stressed that the Kyoto Protocol was a first step to halving global emissions by 2050.

title: Adaptation
abstract: AUSTRALIA, MEXICO and PANAMA stressed the importance of adapting to the effects of climate change.

title: Extreme Weather Events
actors: Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Many speakers, including Jamaica, speaking for the G-77/CHINA, as well as GUATEMALA and the DOMINICAN REPUBLIC, noted the high toll from recent extreme weather events.

title: Flexible Mechanisms
abstract: Several Parties highlighted the need to improve or streamline the mechanisms.

title: Funding and Capacity Building
actors: Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Many speakers, including GHANA, JORDAN, MALI and GUINEA BISSAU, stressed the importance of adequate funding and capacity building.

title: Kyoto Protocol Commitments
abstract: Several Annex I Parties emphasized their commitment to meeting their targets.

title: Mitigation
abstract: Many speakers outlined their mitigation activities.

title: COUNTRY STATEMENTS
abstract: Ministers and heads of delegation highlighted issues such as adaptation, deforestation, extreme weather events, CDM reform, funding and capacity building, commitments under the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol, technology transfer, the post-2012 process, and the adoption of the Marrakesh Accords.

title: Post-2012
abstract: ROMANIA welcomed discussions on a post-2012 framework as an opportunity for 'intense cooperation among all governments.

title: Synergies and Cooperation
abstract: The CZECH REPUBLIC called for solidarity in combating climate change.

title: Technology Development and Transfer
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: BENIN, COTE DIVOIRE, PARAGUAY, EGYPT and ALGERIA highlighted the importance of technology transfer to address climate change.

title: CONSULTATIONS ON POST-2012
abstract: Consultations on how to move forward post-2012 took place throughout Thursday in numerous meetings focused both on the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol.

title: FUTURE ACTIONS UNDER THE UNFCCC
abstract: Informal discussions on future actions under the UNFCCC focused on President Dions revised proposal.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.9
abstract: Following meetings held throughout the day, Co-Chairs Alf Wills (South Africa) and David Drake (Canada) convened a contact group and introduced a bracketed draft containing two options with four sections each.

title: CONSULTATIONS ON ADAPTATION
abstract: Informal consultations were held throughout the day in an attempt to remove brackets from the draft COP decision.

title: Adaptation
abstract: BENIN and MAURITIUS highlighted the need to prioritize and implement adaptation projects.

title: Avoided Deforestation
abstract: PAPUA NEW GUINEA proposed to start, on voluntary basis, reductions of emissions through avoided deforestation.

title: Commitments
abstract: CROATIA requested consideration of its special circumstances to enable its ratification of the Protocol.

title: Extreme Weather Events
abstract: Many speakers, including MADAGASCAR, TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO, and URUGUAY, drew attention to recent extreme weather events.

title: Flexible Mechanisms
abstract: Highlighting the need to improve the CDMs administration and streamline the procedures, IRAN welcomed the draft decision on national programmes under the CDM.

title: Funding and Capacity Building
abstract: LIBYA, SAUDI ARABIA and NIGERIA called on Annex I Parties to honor commitments to developing countries, particularly those that are highly dependent on oil exports.

title: Mitigation
abstract: SWEDEN highlighted its success in decoupling economic growth from emissions and JAPAN reported on its domestic efforts to reduce emissions, including awareness raising activities.

title: Observation Systems
abstract: SENEGAL, CAMEROON and GABON proposed creating an observation system in Africa to develop indicators and monitor and reinforce operational capacity to evaluate carbon sequestration.

title: ADOPTION OF THE AGENDA
abstract: Parties then adopted the provisional agenda (FCCC/CP/2005/1), with the exception of the item on the second review of the adequacy of UNFCCC Article 4.2 (a) and (b) (policies and measures on emissions and removals from sinks).

title: Adaptation Fund
abstract: Preliminary discussion of this item was held in the contact group on 29 November.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: The COP/MOP decision (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.32) contains reference to the purpose of the Fund and guidance on its operating policies, programme priorities, and eligibility criteria for its operation, which will be adopted at COP MOP 2.

title: Guidance to the Global Environment Facility
abstract: This item was addressed at the contact group meetings on 29 November and 2 December.

title: Report of the GEF to the COP
abstract: This item was first addressed at the SBI plenary on 29 November, at which time the Philippines, for the G-77/China, raised concerns about the new GEF Resource Allocation Framework and GEF co-financing requirements.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In its decision (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.30), the COP/MOP, inter alia: considers the report of the Global Environment Facility (FCC/CP/2005/3) and takes note of information provided by the GEF on its support for project-related activities in the climate change focal area, the Resource Allocation Framework, and progress on the fourth replenishment of the GEF Trust Fund.

title: QUANTIFIED EMISSION REDUCTION COMMITMENT FOR BELARUS
abstract: A request by Belarus to be assigned an emissions target under the Kyoto Protocol was first communicated to the UNFCCC Secretariat in October 2005, and subsequently added to the COP/MOP 1 agenda.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In this decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/L.10), the COP/MOP acknowledges the intention of Belarus to be assigned a quantified emission limitation and reduction commitment under Protocol Article 3 for the period 2008 to 2012, and invites Belarus to submit text for a proposed amendment to Annex B.

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES UNDER THE PROTOCOL
abstract: Criteria for Cases of Failure to Submit Information under Article 3.3 and 3.4: Parties addressed this issue in SBSTA plenary on 29 November and in a contact group co-chaired by Newton Paciornik (Brazil) and Audun Rosland (Norway), as well as in informal consultations involving a smaller group of experts.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.18/Add.1), the COP/MOP agrees that an Annex I Party shall not issue removal units (RMUs) for a specific activity under Protocol Article 3.3 and 3.4, associated with the year of the commitment period if the magnitude of the adjustments to that activity, as defined in a mathematical equation in the annex to the decision, exceeds 9% for that year.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.27/Add.1), the COP/MOP: states that HCFC-22 used as feedstock in the manufacture of other chemicals is not controlled under the Montreal Protocol; defines 'new HCFC-22 facilities'; and recognizes that issuing CERs for HFC-23 destruction at new HCFC-22 facilities could lead to higher global production of HCFC-22 and/or HFC-23.

title: ELECTION OF THE COP BUREAU
abstract: On Friday, 9 December, the COP elected officers other than the President.

title: ITALYS ASSIGNED AMOUNT FOR FOREST MANAGEMENT
abstract: In the COP/MOP plenary on 30 November, the EU introduced a request by Italy to reconsider its assigned amount for forest management under Kyoto Protocol Article 3.4 (land use, land-use change and forestry).

title: COP/MOP Conclusions
abstract: The conclusions (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/L.4) note Italys submission on this matter (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/MISC.2), request SBSTA to consider the request and forward a draft decision for adoption at COP/MOP 2.

title: HIGH-LEVEL SEGMENT
abstract: The joint high-level segment of COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 began on 7 December and concluded on 9 December.

title: OPENING OF THE HIGH-LEVEL SEGMENT
abstract: COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 President Stéphane Dion outlined progress on what he referred to as the 'three Is' of 'implementation, improvement, and innovation.

title: COUNTRY STATEMENTS
abstract: Government speakers reflected on issues such as adaptation to climate change, avoided deforestation, extreme weather events, the Kyoto Protocols flexible mechanisms, reform of the CDM, funding and capacity building, commitments under the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol, funding and capacity building, mitigation, observation systems, the post-2012 process, synergies and cooperation, technology development and transfer, and the adoption of the Marrakesh Accords.

title: Adaptation
abstract: Many speakers, including Australia, Mexico and Panama, spoke about adapting to the effects of climate change.

title: Avoided Deforestation
abstract: Several parties discussed a proposal by Papua New Guinea to provide incentives to developing countries for avoided deforestation.

title: Commitments
abstract: Numerous speakers pledged to meet commitments under the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol.

title: Extreme Weather Events
actors: Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The impact of recent extreme weather events and linkages to climate change were discussed by many speakers, including Jamaica, speaking for the G-77/China, and Mauritius, on behalf of the Alliance of Small Island States.

title: Flexible Mechanisms
abstract: The CDM was a particular focus of discussions, with many highlighting the need to improve or streamline the CDM.

title: OFFER TO HOST COP 12 AND COP/MOP 2
abstract: During the closing session of COP 11, Kenya announced its offer to host COP 12 and COP/MOP 2.

title: Funding and Capacity Building
abstract: Many speakers, particularly those from developing countries, highlighted the importance of adequate funding and capacity building, and some urged Annex I Parties to honor their commitments.

title: Mitigation
abstract: Developed countries in particular reflected on their activities, with Sweden highlighting its success in decoupling economic growth from emissions and Japan reporting on its range of domestic efforts, including awareness raising activities.

title: Post-2012
abstract: Most participants commented on the issue of post-2012 action.

title: Technology Development and Transfer
abstract: Parties supported a strong focus on technology development and transfer.

title: STATEMENTS FROM UN BODIES AND AGENCIES
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|IPCC Governance|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: The World Meteorological Organization highlighted the value of climate monitoring and research that involves national meteorological services and developing countries.

title: STATEMENTS FROM OBSERVER ORGANIZATIONS
abstract: The International Energy Agency highlighted the importance of emissions trading mechanisms, energy efficiency, and technology development to transform the worlds energy systems.

title: CLOSING COP AND COP/MOP PLENARY
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: Early on Saturday morning, 10 December, after all-night negotiations on the package on future actions, President Dion convened the closing plenary.

title: IMPLEMENTATION
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Compliance and Enforcement
abstract: The most urgent objective in Montreal was to implement the Kyoto Protocol.

title: IMPROVEMENT
abstract: Heading into COP/MOP 1, adaptation and the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) had emerged for many as those items most in need of 'improvement': the former because its absence from the Convention has long been seen as a lacuna, and the latter because a more efficient CDM that can handle a large number of project proposals is viewed by many as a prerequisite for its success. When the UNFCCC was adopted in 1992, adaptation was largely seen as an afterthought to mitigation.

title: REVIEW OF IMPLEMENTATION OF COMMITMENTS AND OTHER PROVISIONS OF THE CONVENTION
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The agenda item on review of implementation of commitments and other provisions of the Convention involved consideration of several sub-items dealing with the financial mechanism, national communications from both Annex I and non-Annex I Parties, the development and transfer of technologies, capacity building under the Convention, and implementation of UNFCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 (adverse effects), which included consideration of the five-year programme of work on adaptation and matters relating to least developed countries (LDCs).

title: INNOVATION
abstract: By the time the last plenary sessions of the COP and COP/MOP began in the small hours of Saturday morning, some delegates were already giving the meeting an A grade.

title: EVALUATING SUCCESS
abstract: As the conference closed on Saturday morning, many delegates and civil society representatives appeared satisfied that they had overcome so many potential pitfalls and actually achieved consensus.

title: AN 'I' TO THE FUTURE
abstract: Even though the outcomes of COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 exceeded expectations, the future of the climate regime is still highly uncertain.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM (CONVENTION)
abstract: These items were first taken up in SBI plenary on 29 November, at which time they were forwarded to a contact group co-chaired by Rawleston Moore (Barbados) and Karsten Sach (Germany).

title: Special Climate Change Fund
abstract: The contact group discussed this issue from 30 November to 2 December, negotiating from the text forwarded by SBI 22 (FCCC/2005/SBI/10).

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: The SBI draft conclusions carried over from SBI 22 (FCCC/SBI/2005/10) include reference to the activities, programmes, and measures relating to climate change in the areas set out in paragraph 2(c) of Decision 7/CP.7 (funding under the Convention - Special Climate Change Fund) that are complementary to those funded by resources allocated to the climate change focal area of the GEF.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.28), SBI notes with appreciation the report from the Secretariat on the experience of international funds and multilateral financial institutions relevant to the investment needs of developing countries in meeting their commitments under the Convention (FCCC/SBI/2005/INF.7).

title: COP Decision
abstract: In its decision (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.29), the COP requests the GEF to include in its report to the COP information on the initial application of the RAF to resources allocated in the fourth replenishment and how the RAF is likely to affect funding available to developing countries for the implementation of their commitments under the Convention.

title: NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS: Annex I Parties:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: SBI considered Annex I national communications in plenary on 28 November, focusing on proposals for streamlining the review processes for 2006-2007 (FCCC/SBI/2005/16); and taking note of the report on national greenhouse gas inventory data from parties included in Annex I to the Convention for the period 1990-2003 (FCCC/SBI/2005/17), and of the status report on the review of third national communications (FCCC/SBI/2005/INF.9).

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP 3 in Kyoto, Japan, agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries making the transition to a market economy to achieve emissions reduction targets.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In its decision (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.23), the COP agrees to streamline review procedures for Annex I national communications under the Convention for the period 2006-2007.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In its decision (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.24), the COP/MOP agrees to review procedures for reporting required under the Protocol from Annex I Parties in 2006-2007.

title: Non-Annex I Parties
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: On 28 November, the SBI plenary considered non-Annex I national communications, focusing on compiled information on this issue (FCCC/SBI/2005/18 and Adds.

title: COP Decision
topics: Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The COP adopted a decision on submission of second, or third national communications (FCCC/SBI/2005/10/Add.1) deciding, inter alia, that non-Annex I Parties should apply for financing for their second or third national communications, whether or not they have completed their first national communications, and seek to submit them within four years of the disbursement of funds. They also adopted conclusions on the Consultative Group of Experts on National Communications from non-Annex I Parties (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.27), compilation and synthesis of initial national communications (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.26), and financial and technical support (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.25/Rev.1).

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer
abstract: Technology transfer was first addressed by the SBSTA in plenary on 29 November.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions on the EGTTs 2006 Work Programme (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.23), SBSTA, inter alia: endorses the proposed 2006 EGTT Work Programme; requests that the Secretariat organize a special working session of the EGTT; requests the EGTT to arrange a side event on transfer of public technologies; and further requests the EGTT to report to SBSTA 25. In the conclusions on implementation of the framework for meaningful and effective actions to enhance the implementation of Article 4.5 of the Convention (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.24), SBSTA, inter alia: takes note of a pilot project on networking between TT:CLEAR and regional technology information centers; looks forward to the Secretariats technical papers on innovative financing and adaptation technologies; and acknowledges that there are technology initiatives underway in other forums.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision on implementation of the framework for meaningful and effective actions to enhance the implementation of Article 4.5 of the Convention (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.24/Add.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE CONVENTION
abstract: This issue was initially addressed by SBI in plenary on 28 November, before being taken up in a contact group co-chaired by Joyceline Goco (Philippines) and Anders Turesson (Sweden), which met once and also held informal consultations.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In these conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.36), SBI reiterates the importance of capacity building for developing countries.

title: ARTICLE 4.8 AND 4.9 (ADVERSE EFFECTS)
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Implementation of the Buenos Aires Programme of Work on Adaptation and Response Measures: The scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of impacts of, and vulnerability and adaptation to, climate change, was first taken up in plenary on 28 November.

title: BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION
abstract: The process for finalizing the rules and operational details of the Protocol was agreed at COP 4 in 1998 in a document known as the Buenos Aires Plan of Action.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.30), SBSTA takes note of an indicative draft list of activities for the programme of work (contained in an annex), and agrees to further elaborate the list at SBSTA 24.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/CP/2005/L.3), the COP notes that adaptation to climate change and its adverse effects is of high priority for all countries, and that developing countries, especially LDCs and SIDS, are particularly vulnerable.

title: Least Developed Countries
abstract: On 29 November, Paul Desanker (Malawi) briefed SBI on the work of the LDC Expert Group and progress with the National Adaptation Programmes of Action (NAPAs).

title: COP Decision
abstract: In this decision (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.17), the COP decides to extend the mandate for the LDC Expert Group until 2007, with the task of developing a work programme that includes implementation of NAPAs for consideration at SBI 24.

title: EMISSIONS FROM DEFORESTATION IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This agenda item was first presented in the COP plenary on 30 November.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/CP/2005/L.2), the COP invites parties and accredited observers to submit, by 31 March 2006, their views on issues relating to reducing emissions from deforestation in developing countries, focusing on relevant scientific, technical and methodological issues, and the exchange of relevant information and experiences, including policy approaches and positive incentives and recommendations on any further process to consider these issues.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS
abstract: COP 11 took up various administrative, financial and institutional matters, including budget issues, the institutional linkage of the Secretariat to the UN, and the procedure for appointing an Executive Secretary for the UNFCCC.

title: BUDGET ISSUES
abstract: These items were first taken up in SBI plenary on 30 November.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.21 Add.1), the COP takes note of the interim financial statements, and the income and budget performance in the biennium 2004-2005; urges all parties that have not yet paid their contributions to do so without delay; and calls for more and continued contributions to the trust funds in order to ensure wider participation in the process and delivery of important outputs and results.

title: INSTITUTIONAL LINKAGE OF THE SECRETARIAT TO THE UN
abstract: SBI first addressed this issue on 29 November (FCCC/SBI/2005/15).

title: MARRAKESH ACCORDS
abstract: In late October and early November 2001 at COP 7, delegates resumed their discussions and reached agreement on the Marrakesh Accords.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.19), the COP approves the continuation of the current linkage and related administrative arrangements between the Secretariat and the UN; and invites the Secretary-General to seek endorsement by the General Assembly.

title: PROCEDURE FOR APPOINTING AN EXECUTIVE SECRETARY
abstract: This issue was first taken up by the COP on 30 November, when President Dion outlined the procedure for selecting a new UNFCCC Executive Secretary, as set out in recent correspondence with the UN Secretary-Generals office.

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES UNDER THE UNFCCC
abstract: The COP took up various methodological issues, including harvested wood products, the Common Reporting Format for LULUCF, and emissions from fuel used for international aviation and maritime transport.

title: HARVESTED WOOD PRODUCTS
abstract: This issue was taken up in SBSTA plenary on 28 November, and subsequently in informal consultations co-chaired by Nagmeldin Goutbi Elhassan (Sudan) and Peter Brisbane (Australia).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.16), SBSTA takes note of the submissions; notes with appreciation the IPCC report on progress made with respect to estimating and reporting harvested wood products in the context of the preparation of the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories; and decides to continue consideration of this issue at SBSTA 24.

title: LULUCF COMMON REPORTING FORMAT (CRF)
abstract: This issue was first addressed in SBSTA on 28 November, and in two contact groups co-chaired by Audun Rosland (Norway) and Newton Paciornik (Brazil).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.19), SBSTA agrees to consider at its twenty-fourth session, inter alia: how emissions and removals now covered in the LULUCF and agriculture sectors will be presented in the national totals; inventory issues associated with biomass burning and natural disturbances as they relate to reporting under the Convention; and the implications on reporting of the conversion to CO2 in the atmosphere of methane, carbon monoxide and non-methane volatile organic compounds emitted in association with carbon stock changes.

title: COP Decision
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In this decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.19/Add.1), the COP adopts the CRF tables contained in its annex, decides that each Annex I Party shall use these tables in their submissions of the annual inventory due in and after 2007, and requests the Secretariat to incorporate them into the Guidelines for the preparation of Annex I national communications in time for SBSTA 25.

title: EMISSIONS FROM FUEL USED FOR INTERNATIONAL AVIATION AND MARITIME TRANSPORT
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: On 28 November, Jane Hupe, International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), briefed SBSTA on ICAOs work on aviation emissions since SBSTA 22.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.28), SBSTA agrees to forward the issue to SBSTA 24 for its consideration.

title: COP 10
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: At COP 10 in Buenos Aires in December 2004, delegates agreed to the Buenos Aires Programme of Work on Adaptation and Response Measures.

title: REPORTS OF THE SUBSIDIARY BODIES
abstract: On 9 December, the COP adopted the reports of the twenty-third sessions of the Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/4 & Add.1 & Amend.1; FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.15) and the Subsidiary Body for Implementation (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.16).

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR IMPLEMENTATION
abstract: Issues addressed by SBI 23 related to the UNFCCC included education, training and public awareness, and a review of the Secretariat.

title: Education, Training and Public Awareness
abstract: Parties were briefed on UNFCCC Article 6 (education, training and public awareness) during an SBI plenary meeting on 29 November, which focused on: the new UNFCCC Climate Change Information Network (CC:iNet), an internet information clearing house; regional workshops (FCCC/SBI/2005/21 and FCCC/SBI/2005/14); and UNEPs work on Article 6.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions on UNFCCC Article 6 (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.18), SBI, inter alia, notes that the financial resources available are not sufficient to meet the needs and concerns identified by parties, and urges Annex I and Annex II parties, the GEF and other bilateral and multilateral agencies to continue to support financially the implementation of Article 6 activities.

title: Internal Review of the Activities of the Secretariat
abstract: This issue was first discussed by SBI on 29 November, at which time parties tasked the Secretariat with preparing conclusions, in consultation with interested parties.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2005/10 Add.

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL ADVICE
abstract: Issues addressed by SBSTA 23 that relate to the UNFCCC included mitigation of climate change, research and systematic observation, and cooperation with relevant international organizations.

title: Mitigation
