abstract: The scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of mitigation of climate change were first addressed by SBSTA on 28 November, when parties considered reports on the matter (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/INF.5, Misc.12 and Adds.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.29) SBSTA, inter alia: agrees to focus on exchanging information and sharing experiences; requests the Secretariat to organize pre- and in-session workshops on agriculture, forestry and rural development, urban planning and development, energy efficiency, power generation, and non-CO2 emissions; and states that each workshop should address currently available and emerging technologies, international cooperative efforts on technology, socioeconomic aspects of mitigation, and cross cutting aspects.

title: Research and Systematic Observation
abstract: This item was first addressed by SBSTA on 29 November, when delegates heard reports on the: Global Climate Observing System (GCOS) (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/Misc.14); Global Terrestrial Observing System (GTOS) (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/Misc.16); Committee on Earth Observation Satellites (CEOS) (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/Misc.17/Rev.1); views of parties on an ocean climate observing system (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/Misc.15 & Add.1); and collaboration between CEOS, GCOS and the Global Earth Observation System of Systems (GEOSS). Many delegates welcomed these reports and stressed collaboration between GCOS and GEOSS.

title: SEMINAR OF GOVERNMENTAL EXPERTS AND SB 22
abstract: This seminar took place in May 2005, in Bonn.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.17), SBSTA, inter alia: urges parties to further implement the GTOS implementation plan, particularly capacity building; urges parties to designate GCOS national coordinators and focal points; calls on the GTOS Secretariat to assess the status of development of standards for terrestrial observations; agrees to revise reporting guidelines on global observing systems; notes the importance of oceanic observations; reiterates the importance of data exchange; and invites support of international data centers.

title: Cooperation with Relevant International Organizations
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: SBSTA considered the issue of cooperation with relevant international organizations along with related items on the special report of the IPCC on carbon dioxide capture and storage, the Mauritius International meeting to review the implementation of the Programme of Action for the Sustainable Development of SIDS, and cooperation with other conventions, scientific organizations and United Nations bodies. These issues were first taken up in the SBSTA plenary on 28 November.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.26), SBSTA, inter alia: recognizes the valuable input from other organizations; notes that carbon dioxide capture and storage systems are in various stages of development; requests the Secretariat to organize an in-session workshop at SB 24 on carbon dioxide capture and storage; and encourages parties and the private sector to support related research, development, deployment and diffusion of such technologies.

title: FUTURE ACTION UNDER THE UNFCCC
abstract: The issue of future action and commitments beyond 2012 was first addressed by the COP/MOP on Wednesday, 30 November, under its agenda item on the consideration of Protocol Article 3.9 (Annex I Parties future commitments).

title: KYOTO PROTOCOL COP/MOP 1 REPORT
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: COP/MOP 1 President Stéphane Dion opened COP/MOP 1 on Monday, 28 November.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
abstract: The COP/MOP considered its provisional agenda for the meeting on 28 November.

title: ARTICLE 2.3 (RESPONSE MEASURES)
abstract: Article 2.3 was discussed again in SBSTA on 29 November, as it was also on the SBSTA agenda.

title: ADOPTION OF DECISIONS FORWARDED BY THE COP (MARRAKESH ACCORDS)
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: On 30 November, COP/MOP President Dion introduced a package of decisions forwarded by the COP to the COP/MOP under the terms of the Marrakesh Accords agreed at COP 7 in 2001.

title: COP/MOP Decision on LULUCF - Principles, Rules, and Guidelines
abstract: This decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.1) includes principles that govern the treatment of LULUCF activities, an annex establishing rules and guidelines for the first commitment period, and an appendix.

title: COP/MOP Decision
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: on Matters Relating to Article 3.14 (Minimizing Adverse Effects of Mitigation on Developing Countries): The decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.1) requests Annex I Parties to provide information as part of their annual inventory report on the minimization of adverse social, environmental and economic impacts on developing country parties, and requests the Secretariat to organize before COP/MOP 2 a workshop on reporting methodologies on ways to minimize adverse effects of mitigation activities on developing countries.

title: REPORT OF COP 11 AND COP/MOP 1
abstract: The eleventh Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and first Conference of the Parties serving as the Meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol opened on Monday, 28 November 2005.

title: COP/MOP Decision on Guidelines on National Systems
abstract: In its decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.2), the COP/MOP adopts guidelines included in its annex on national systems for the estimation of anthropogenic emissions by sources and removals by sinks of all greenhouse gases not controlled by the Montreal Protocol.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: on Guidelines on the Preparation of Information under Article 7 (Information on Compliance with Commitments): In its decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.2), the COP/MOP adopts guidelines included in its annex on the provision of information by Kyoto Protocol parties on compliance with their emission reduction targets and other commitments under the Protocol.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: on Standard Electronic Format for Reporting Kyoto Protocol Units: In this decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.2), the COP/MOP adopts the standard electronic format and an annex with general reporting instructions and model reporting tables.

title: COP/MOP Decision
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: s on Guidelines under Article 8 (Review of Information by Expert Teams): Four decisions were adopted on this issue, all contained in document FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.2: Conduction of Reviews: In this decision, the COP/MOP establishes the dates to commence periodic and annual reviews for Annex I Parties and includes an annex with guidelines for the conduction of reviews on national inventories, information on compliance with commitments, national systems, national registries, and information on minimizing adverse impacts on developing countries. Terms of Service for Lead Reviewers: In this decision, the COP/MOP establishes that reviewers will be based in their home countries. Training Programme: In this decision, the COP/MOP requests the Secretariat to develop a training programme for members of expert review teams including an annex on premises and courses for the training programme and an annex on criteria for the selection of lead reviewers. Confidential Information: This decision determines the possibility for expert review teams to recommend, on an exceptional basis, the retroactive application of an adjustment based on the access to relevant confidential information.

title: COP/MOP Decision on Principles, Nature and Scope of the Mechanisms
abstract: This decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.3) emphasizes environmental integrity and provides that mechanisms can only be used to supplement domestic action.

title: COP/MOP Decision on Guidelines for Article 6 (Joint Implementation)
abstract: This decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.3) defines the JI Supervisory Committee (JISC) and criteria for participating in JI.

title: COP/MOP Decision on Modalities, Rules and Guidelines for Emissions Trading
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: This decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.3) determines the eligibility criteria for trading AAUs.

title: COP/MOP Decision on modalities and procedures for CDM
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: This decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/3/Add.4) describes the roles of COP/MOP and the CDM Executive Board in administrating the CDM.

title: REPORT OF THE CDM EXECUTIVE BOARD
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Sushma Gera, Chair of the CDM Executive Board, presented the Boards 2004-2005 Report (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/4 & Add.1) at the COP/MOP plenary on 30 November.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In this decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/L.7), the COP/MOP recognizes the need to ensure the CDMs continuity beyond 2012.

title: UNFCCC COP 11 REPORT
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Group of 77 and China
abstract: COP 11 opened on Monday morning, 28 November, with a welcoming ceremony that involved presentations from Gerald Tremblay, Mayor of Montreal, and Jean Charest, Premier of Québec.

title: JOINT IMPLEMENTATION
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The agenda item on implementation of Article 6 of the Kyoto Protocol (joint implementation) was addressed by the COP/MOP plenary on 30 November, in two contact group meetings and several informal consultations chaired by Daniela Stoycheva (Bulgaria).

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In this decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/L.6), the COP/MOP establishes the JI Supervisory Committee and outlines its work programme.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSACTION LOG
abstract: The international transaction log, a system that performs automated checks to verify transactions of different carbon credits under the Kyoto Protocol, was first addressed by SBSTA on 29 November.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In this decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2005/L.20/Add.1) on guidance relating to registry systems, the COP/MOP notes that the international transaction log is essential to the implementation of the Kyoto Protocols flexible mechanisms.

title: ADOPTION OF A COMPLIANCE MECHANISM AND SAUDI ARABIAS PROPOSAL TO AMEND THE PROTOCOL
actors: European Union|African Group|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: These issues were first addressed by the COP/MOP on 30 November and subsequently in a contact group co-chaired by Harald Dovland (Norway) and Mamadou Honadia (Burkina Faso).

title: COP/MOP Decision
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Compliance and Enforcement|Extension of the Kyoto protocol|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: In the final decision (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/L.5), the COP/MOP 'approves and adopts' the compliance mechanism without prejudice to the outcome of the amendment process.

title: ELECTION OF THE COMPLIANCE COMMITTEE
abstract: This issue was addressed by COP/MOP plenary on 30 November, when parties were requested to make nominations for the compliance committee, and on 9 December, when the members were elected.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: The COP/MOP elected 10 members and 10 alternates for each of the compliance committees two branches.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE PROTOCOL
abstract: This issue was introduced during an SBI plenary by Janos Pasztor, UNFCCC Secretariat, on 29 November (FCCC/SBI/2005/Misc.3 & Add.1).

title: COP/MOP Decisions
abstract: In the decision on capacity building in developing countries (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.35), the COP/MOP decides that the capacity-building framework in Decision 2/CP.7 applies to the Protocols implementation.

title: ADOPTION OF THE RULES OF PROCEDURE
abstract: The COP then considered the draft rules of procedure and, noting lack of progress on draft rule 42 (voting), agreed to apply the draft rules of procedure, with the exception of draft rule 42.

title: ARTICLE 3.9 AND FUTURE ACTION
abstract: The issue of future action and commitments was first addressed in the COP/MOP plenary on 30 November, under the agenda item on Protocol Article 3.9 (consideration of Annex I commitments for subsequent periods).

title: INITIAL PROPOSALS
abstract: David Drake (Canada) and Alf Wills (South Africa) co-chaired a contact group and informal consultations, which met from 1 December through Friday night, 9 December.

title: THREE PARALLEL CONSULTATIONS
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Informal discussions on future action and commitments, which went very late into the night from 7-9 December, were held in three separate groups, one on Protocol Article 3.9 (future commitments), one on Protocol Article 9 (review of the Protocol), and one on President Dions proposal for action under the Convention.

title: COP Decision
abstract: In this decision on dialogue on long-term cooperative action to address climate change by enhancing implementation of the Convention (FCCC/CP/2005/L.4/Rev.1) the COP reaffirms that development and poverty eradication are the first and overriding priorities of developing country parties, and recognizes that there is a diversity of approaches to address climate change and the essential role of technology in addressing climate change.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In this decision on consideration of commitments for subsequent periods for parties included in Annex I to the Convention under Article 3.9 of the Kyoto Protocol: (FCCC/KP/CMP/2005/L.8/Rev.1), the COP/MOP, inter alia: decides to initiate without delay a process in an open-ended ad hoc group to consider further commitments by Annex I Parties beyond 2012; agrees that the group should aim to complete its work and have it adopted by the COP/MOP in time to ensure that there is no gap between commitment periods; and further agrees that the group will meet at SBSTA 24.

title: BUDGET ISSUES
abstract: These items were first taken up by SBI on 30 November.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In this decision, (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.22/Add.1), the COP/MOP: takes notes of the income and budget performance in the biennium 2004-2005; expresses concern about late payment to the Kyoto Protocol Interim Allocation; encourages all Parties that have not yet paid their contributions to do so without further delay; and calls for more and continued contributions to the Trust Fund, in particular to ensure continuation of work relating to the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS SERVING ON CONSTITUTED BODIES ESTABLISHED UNDER THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: This item was first taken up by SBI on 29 November, before being discussed in the same contact group as the institutional linkage of the Secretariat to the UN.

title: COP/MOP Decision
abstract: In the decision (FCCC/SBI/2005/L.31), the COP/MOP, inter alia, requests the SBI to consider this matter at SBI 24; invites parties to submit to the secretariat, by 13 February 2006, their views on this item for compilation; and requests the Executive Secretary to consult the UN Secretary- General and to report to SBI 24.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM (KYOTO PROTOCOL)
abstract: The series of sub-items under this agenda item were first taken up in the SBI plenary on 30 November and were forwarded to a contact group co-chaired by Rawleston Moore (Barbados) and Karsten Sach (Germany).

title: ELEVENTH SESSION OF THE TGICA
abstract: At the eleventh meeting of the TGICA, held in Cape Town, South Africa, from 7-9 February 2006, participants discussed matters that included management of the Data Distribution Center and the status of a TGICA initiative to build capacity and develop appropriate data products for use in developing countries and countries with economies in transition.

title: IPCC EXPERT MEETING ON NEW EMISSIONS SCENARIOS
abstract: At this meeting, held from 20-22 March 2006, in Seville, Spain, participants discussed proposals of the TGNES for developing emissions scenarios, including: possible IPCC coordination and facilitation with the scientific community; the process, timeline and deliverables of new emissions scenarios development; the organizational arrangements for the IPCCs own activities on scenarios; and the possibility of encouraging a wider family of non-climate scenarios that might include emissions scenarios.

title: KEY IPCC PRODUCTS
abstract: The IPCC completed its initial comprehensive assessments of climate change in the First Assessment Report in 1990 and the Second Assessment Report in 1995.

title: NINETEENTH SESSION
abstract: At IPCC-19, held from 17-20 April 2002, in Geneva, Switzerland, the IPCC began work on the AR4.

title: TWENTIETH SESSION
abstract: IPCC-20 was held from 19-21 February 2003, in Paris, France.

title: TWENTY-FIRST SESSION
abstract: At IPCC-21, held from 3-7 November 2003, in Vienna, Austria, delegates reviewed the outlines of the proposed Working Group contributions to the AR4 and the Chairs proposal for an AR4 Synthesis Report.

title: TWENTY-SECOND SESSION
abstract: IPCC-22 convened from 9-11 November 2004, in New Delhi, India.

title: TWENTY-THIRD SESSION
abstract: At IPCC-23, which convened on 8 April 2005, in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, delegates considered the joint activities of Working Groups I and II on the Special Report on Safeguarding the Ozone Layer and the Global Climate System.

title: TWENTY-FOURTH SESSION
topics: IPCC Governance|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System
abstract: IPCC-24 was held from 26-28 September 2005, in Montreal, Canada.

title: ELEVENTH CONFERENCE OF THE PARTIES TO THE UNFCCC AND FIRST MEETING OF THE PARTIES TO THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: The eleventh Conference of the Parties to the UNFCCC (COP 11) and the first Conference of the Parties serving as the Meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol (COP/MOP 1) took place in Montreal, Canada, from 28 November to 10 December 2005.

title: EFDB
abstract: TGICA Co-Chair Taka Hiraishi (Japan) updated the Panel on the proposed membership of the EFDB Editorial Board (IPCC-XXV/Doc.

title: Working Group I:
abstract: Susan Solomon (US), Working Group I Co-Chair, presented on progress towards the AR4 (IPCC-XXV/Doc.

title: Working Group II:
abstract: Presenting on progress towards the AR4 (IPCC- XXV/Doc.

title: Working Group III
abstract: Working Group III Co-Chair Ogunlade Davidson (Sierra Leone) presented on progress towards the AR4 (IPCC- XXV/Doc.

title: AR4 Synthesis Report
abstract: Chair Pachauri informed the Panel that the core writing team for the AR4 Synthesis Report (IPCC-XXV/INF.

title: TGICA
abstract: TGICA Co-Chair Jose Marengo (Brazil) provided a progress report on TGICA (IPCC-XXV/Doc.

title: Final Decision
abstract: In the decision on the budget, the Panel: thanks the IPCC Chair and the IPCC Secretary for their efforts to improve the presentation of the programme and budget; encourages the Secretariat to continue to make improvements by providing more detail in the presentation of its past and projected expenses, and to examine the issue of constant over- estimation in the budget and work towards accurate forecasting; adopts the budget for 2007; notes the forecast budget for 2008 and the indicative budget for 2009; thanks the US government for its special contribution to the translation and publication of the 2006 Guidelines into the five UN languages other than English; recognizes that a certain amount of carry over is necessary to ensure continuation of the IPCC programme of work and the transition to the next assessment period, and that the carry over may vary from year to year, due to the cyclical nature of the assessment; and invites governments that may be in a position to do so to contribute to the IPCC Trust Fund.

title: Final Outcome
abstract: The Overview Chapter to the 2006 Guidelines adopted by the Panel includes five sections: introduction; coverage of the 2006 Guidelines; approach to developing the 2006 Guidelines; structure of the 2006 Guidelines; specific developments in the 2006 Guidelines; and relevance of the 2006 Guidelines. The 2006 Guidelines accepted by the Panel comprise five volumes, one of which provides general guidance on reporting, and four of which focus on different sectors of economy: energy; industrial processes and product use; AFOLU; and waste.

title: How to address further work on emission scenarios
abstract: The UK suggested that a new task group could be created to start liaising with other bodies, to consider the regionalization of scenarios and to decide how best to engage developing country experts.

title: Technical Paper
abstract: Discussions also addressed the possibility of a Technical Paper for consideration at IPCC-26 in May 2007.

title: Developing country participation
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System
abstract: China, Peru and others expressed concerns about whether the incorporation of developing country experts in the process of new emission scenarios development could be ensured.

title: Final Outcome
abstract: On further work on emission scenarios, the Panel agreed to: recognize that the development of scenarios for a fifth assessment report would be undertaken by the scientific community and that the IPCC may catalyze such work; call for the IPCC Chair, assisted by the Working Group Co-Chairs, to prepare a scoping document for a Technical Paper following the release of the AR4; request that the IPCC Chair form a steering committee to organize an IPCC meeting in 2007, to be attended by members of the TGICA and the former TGNES, and the Co-Chairs of the three Working Groups or their representatives; hold a meeting in 2007 to consider: the desirable and feasible characteristics of emission scenarios including consistency, comparability, transparency, and the enhancement of developing country involvement; information exchange on plans for developing scenarios and coordinating activities among the scientific community; enhancing the involvement of developing countries and countries with economies in transition in scenario development; and relevant issues for the assessment of scenarios; and request the IPCC Chair send a letter one year before the meeting in 2007 to groups involved in the development of scenarios inviting them to provide information on plans and activities supporting coordination.

title: KEY IPCC PRODUCTS
abstract: The IPCC completed its initial comprehensive assessments of climate change in the First Assessment Report in 1990 and the Second Assessment Report in 1995.

title: Final Outcome
abstract: The rules of procedures for the election of the IPCC Bureau and any Task Force Bureau adopted by the Panel include rules relating to: the composition of the IPCC Bureau and any Task Force Bureau, including composition with regard to geographical representation; terms of appointment; general principles of elections; nominations; voting procedures; and amendments and suspensions.

title: Final Outcome
abstract: The policy for admitting observer organizations adopted by the Panel provides that, inter alia: organizations that already have obtained observer status in the WMO, UNEP or the UNFCCC are not required to submit additional documentation and are considered observers of the IPCC, subject to acceptance by the Panel, if they so request; observer organizations need to be non-profit and/or tax- exempt organizations; and observer status does not imply admission or invitation to workshops, expert meetings or other closed meetings. The process for admitting observer organizations adopted by the Panel provides that, inter alia: groups interested in observer status should post a letter of application with copies of: documents describing the mandate of the organization; evidence of non-profit and/or tax-exempt status; other information supporting the organizations competence in matters related to the IPCC; information on the affiliation with other non-government organizations or institutions involved in climate change activities; and contact information; a body is admitted as an observer organization by the Panel by consensus; no funding will be available for observer organizations; and an organizations status as an observer can be suspended by the IPCC Chair, pending ratification by the Panel at its next session.

title: Final Outcome
abstract: Delegates agreed that: they will support the proposal on the future TFI work programme, which includes a meeting of inventory experts in the second half of 2006, that will involve 60 experts and the TFB members; the output from the meeting will be a draft workplan, agreed by the TFB, for consideration by the Panel; the topics to be discussed at the meeting will not be limited to those outlined in the future workplan; and Chair Pachauri will write to the Government of Japan noting its appreciation of Japans support for the work of the TFI.

title: Final Outcome
abstract: The IPCC agreed to hold a scoping meeting on a possible Special Report on Renewable Energy Sources in late 2007.

title: MATTERS RELATED TO the UNFCCC
abstract: This item was discussed in plenary on Friday.

title: NINETEENTH SESSION
abstract: At IPCC-19, held from 17-20 April 2002, in Geneva, Switzerland, the IPCC began work on the AR4.

title: Working Group I
abstract: Working Group I Co-Chair Solomon presented on progress towards the AR4 (IPCC-XXV/Doc.

title: Working Group II
abstract: Martin Parry (UK), Working Group II Co-Chair, presented on progress towards the AR4 (IPCC-XXV/Doc.

title: Working Group III
abstract: Working Group III Co-Chair Davidson presented on progress towards the AR4 (IPCC-XXV/Doc.

title: AR4 Synthesis Report
abstract: Chair Pachauri informed the Panel that the core writing team for the AR4 Synthesis Report (IPCC-XXV/INF.

title: TGICA
abstract: Co-Chair of TGICA, Jose Marengo (Brazil), provided a progress report on the activities of the TGICA (IPCC-XXV/Doc.

title: EFDB
abstract: TGICA Co-Chair Hiraishi provided the Panel with details on the new and continuing members of the EFDB Editorial Board, as well as the geographic distribution of members (IPCC-XXV/Doc.

title: Final Outcome
abstract: The Panel agreed that: a small team of delegates will work with Chair Pachauri and the Secretariat to conduct a review of the terms of reference for consideration at IPCC-26; if acceptable to the Panel, the review could be presented by Chair Pachauri on behalf of the IPCC to the next session of the WMO Congress in 2007; and the review will be conducted primarily via electronic means as a meeting is not likely to be necessary.

title: TWENTIETH SESSION
abstract: IPCC-20 was held from 19-21 February 2003, in Paris, France.

title: TWENTY-FIRST SESSION
abstract: At IPCC-21, held from 3-7 November 2003, in Vienna, Austria, delegates reviewed the outlines of the proposed Working Group contributions to the AR4 and the Chairs proposal for an AR4 Synthesis Report.

title: TWENTY-SECOND SESSION
abstract: IPCC-22 convened from 9-11 November 2004, in New Delhi, India.

title: TWENTY-THIRD SESSION
abstract: At IPCC-23, which convened on 8 April 2005, in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, delegates considered the joint activities of Working Groups I and II on the Special Report on Safeguarding the Ozone Layer and the Global Climate System.

title: TWENTY-FOURTH SESSION
topics: IPCC Governance|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System
abstract: IPCC-24 was held from 26-28 September 2005, in Montreal, Canada.

title: COMMISSION ON SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT
abstract: During 2006 and 2007, the UN Commission on Sustainable Development is focusing on four key issues: energy for sustainable development, industrial development, air pollution and the atmosphere, and climate change.

title: OTHER MEETINGS
abstract: Other recent events include the first ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate (11-12 January, Sydney, Australia).

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP 3 in Kyoto, Japan, agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries making the transition to a market economy to achieve emissions reduction targets.

title: BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION
abstract: The process for finalizing the rules and operational details of the Protocol was agreed at COP 4 in 1998 in a document known as the Buenos Aires Plan of Action.

title: MARRAKESH ACCORDS
abstract: In late October and early November 2001 at COP 7 in Marrakesh, Morocco, delegates resumed their discussions and reached agreement on the Marrakesh Accords.

title: COP 10
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: At COP 10 in Buenos Aires in December 2004, delegates agreed on the Buenos Aires Programme of Work on Adaptation and Response Measures.

title: SEMINAR OF GOVERNMENTAL EXPERTS AND SB 22
abstract: This seminar took place in May 2005, in Bonn.

title: COP 11 AND COP/MOP 1
abstract: COP 11 and the first Conference of the Parties serving as the Meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol (COP/MOP 1) took place in Montreal, Canada, from 28 November to 10 December 2005.

title: UNFCCC MEETINGS
abstract: Various UNFCCC events have been held since COP 11 and COP/MOP 1, including meetings of the CDM Executive Board (22- 23 February and 10-12 May, Bonn), Joint Implementation Supervisory Committee (2-3 February and 8-11 March, Bonn), Compliance Committee (1-3 March, Bonn) and Expert Group on Technology Transfer (9-11 March, Brussels).

title: IPCC
topics: IPCC Governance|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: As well as these UNFCCC gatherings, there have been a wide range of other relevant meetings in recent months.

title: OPENING OF THE MEETING
topics: Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: On Monday morning, 15 May, Richard Kinley, Officer-in-Charge of the UNFCCC Secretariat, welcomed delegates, noting that this session marked the beginning of two weeks of UNFCCC-related events, including SB 24, the UNFCCC Dialogue and the Ad Hoc Working Group.

title: OBSERVER ORGANIZATIONS
abstract: On Tuesday afternoon, observer organizations were invited to present their observations to the group.

title: GUIDANCE ON THE ORGANIZATION OF FUTURE WORKSHOPS
topics: IPCC Governance|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Technology Transfer
abstract: Late on Tuesday afternoon, Co-Facilitator Bamsey invited delegates to provide guidance on the organization of work of subsequent workshops.

title: ORGANIZATION OF THE MEETING
abstract: The co-facilitators of the Dialogue, Howard Bamsey (Australia) and Sandea de Wet (South Africa) outlined the planned organization of the meeting, noting that it was not a negotiation, but rather an open and non-binding discussion held 'without prejudice to any future negotiations, commitments, process, framework or mandate under the Convention.

title: EXCHANGE OF VIEWS ON ISSUES TO BE DISCUSSED IN THE DIALOGUE
topics: Reasons for Concern|Reasons for Concern|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: On Monday morning, parties engaged in an initial exchange of views about the issues on the Dialogues agenda.

title: EXCHANGE OF EXPERIENCES AND ANALYSIS OF STRATEGIC APPROACHES FOR LONG-TERM COOPERATIVE ACTION IN FOUR THEMATIC AREAS
abstract: Following the initial exchange of views on Monday morning and afternoon, delegates shared experiences and opinions on strategic approaches for long-term cooperative action in four thematic areas: advancing development goals in a sustainable way; addressing action on adaptation; realizing the full potential of technology; and realizing the full potential of market-based opportunities.

title: ADVANCING DEVELOPMENT GOALS IN A SUSTAINABLE WAY
abstract: On advancing development goals in a sustainable way, Uganda expressed concerns that climate change was making global economic inequalities even more pronounced, and Singapore outlined its experience as a small island state and its various policies and approaches.

title: ADAPTATION
abstract: Tanzania and the Philippines said adaptation should have the same status as mitigation, expressing concerns that it had not yet been seriously addressed.

title: TECHNOLOGY
abstract: On technology, the Russian Federation said much needs to be done to promote renewable and alternative energies, but cautioned that traditional energy sources such as fossil fuels would inevitably continue to be employed, and urged a focus on technology development and transfer to reduce their impact.

title: MARKET-BASED OPPORTUNITIES
abstract: The Russian Federation supported a 'truly global carbon market.

title: EXCHANGE OF VIEWS ON RESPONSES TO CLIMATE CHANGE, RESEARCH AND INVESTMENT, VOLUNTARY ACTION, ACCESS TO TECHNOLOGIES AND ADAPTATION
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
countries: Canada|Brazil|Saint Lucia|France|Cameroon|Ghana|Saudi Arabia|Cuba|Norway|Papua New Guinea|Germany|Chile|Russian Federation|China|Kazakhstan|Netherlands|Philippines|Mauritius|Sweden|Kenya|New Zealand|South Africa|India|United Kingdom|Uganda|Tuvalu|Japan
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: On Tuesday morning, 16 May, Co-Facilitator Bamsey opened the meeting, emphasizing that the previous days discussions had been valuable.

title: OPENING OF THE AWG
abstract: On Wednesday afternoon, COP/MOP 1 Vice-President Enele Sopoaga (Tuvalu) welcomed delegates and noted that COP/MOP 1 President Rona Ambrose (Canada) was unable to attend.

title: AWG
abstract: Chair Zammit Cutajar said the AWG is important because it presents an opportunity to Annex I parties to demonstrate leadership and an occasion to give a signal of continuity to the carbon markets.

title: Future commitments
actors: African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Technology Transfer
abstract: On the nature of future commitments, South Africa, for the G-77/CHINA, said Annex I commitments for the second commitment period should be substantially stricter and stressed the need for information on Annex I countries  performance toward meeting their targets for 2008-2012.

title: Length of the second commitment period
abstract: CHINA said the second commitment period could be longer and offer more flexibility, and appreciated the EU's proposal for 15-30% reductions for developed countries.

title: Links with other processes
abstract: The RUSSIAN FEDERATION, CANADA, NORWAY and SWITZERLAND noted the linkages between this process and the one for Article 9, while the G-77/CHINA, ALGERIA, SAUDI ARABIA, EGYPT and INDIA suggested that each process was independent.

title: Scientific basis
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Several parties, including the EU, AOSIS, RUSSIAN FEDERATION and CANADA stressed the need for a scientific basis to the AWG work.

title: Conclusion
abstract: Summarizing the first round of discussions, Chair Zammit Cutajar identified a number of themes that had emerged, including the speed and timeline for the process, the complexity or simplicity of the task ahead, possible linkages with other processes, burden-sharing and allocation, costs, architectural issues, sectoral approaches, bunker fuels, methodological matters and the AWG working methodology.

title: GENERAL STATEMENTS:
abstract: Many parties commented on the AWG's future work plan, focusing on such issues as the nature and strength of the second commitment period, the timescale/length of the next commitment period and other matters relating to timing, continuity between the first and second commitment periods, links with other processes such as Protocol Article 9 (review of the Protocol), key topics that should be discussed by the AWG, and the scientific basis of the AWG's work.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: Parties agreed to the agenda (FCCC/SBI/2006/1 and Corr.1) and organization of work after deleting an item on application of the COP -GEF Council memorandum of understanding, and agreeing that submissions on matters related to Protocol Article 3.14(a dverse effects) would be provided intersessionally.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The Secretariat introduced a report on the activities of the non-Annex I national communications consultative expert group (CGE) (FCCC/SBI/2006/8).

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS:
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: SBSTA Chair Kishan Kumarsingh (Trinidad and Tobago) presented the provisional agenda (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/1 and Add.1).

title: ADAPTATION:
abstract: The Secretariat reported on the five-year adaptation work programme (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/4 and FCCC/SBSTA/2006/INF.3).

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: On reducing emissions from deforestation in developing countries (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.5), many non-Annex I parties emphasized the need for positive incentives.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: Bernard Mazijn (Belgium), Chair of the Expert Group on Technology Transfer (EGTT), reported on EGTT activities (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/INF.4).

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: The RUSSIAN FEDERATION underscored observation and early warning systems.

title: IPCC 2006 Guidelines for national GHG inventories
abstract: Thelma Krug, IPCC, presented the IPCC 2006 Guidelines.

title: Harvested wood products
abstract: The EU stressed that harvested wood products are not for consideration for the first commitment period and, with others, noted the complexity of the issue.

title: Bunker fuels
abstract: On emissions from fuel used for international aviation and maritime transport, the International Maritime Organization reported on cooperation with the UNFCCC.

title: Brazilian proposal
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The EU, BRAZIL and AOSIS welcomed work by MATCH (Modeling and Assessment of Contributions to Climate Change) and, opposed by the US, supported further consideration by SBSTA 25 (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.8).

title: UNFCCC ARTICLE 4.8 AND 4.9:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: On adverse effects and the impact of response measures, the Secretariat reported on recent workshops on response measures, economic diversification and regional adaptation in Latin America.

title: Experience with reporting and review, and with training of experts
abstract: Parties considered a report on this item (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/2), with several noting the need to sustain expertise.

title: HCFC-22 facilities:
abstract: Parties considered implications of the establishment of new HCFC-22 facilities seeking to obtain certified emission reductions for the destruction of HFC-23.

title: NUMERICAL VALUE FOR FOREST MANAGEMENT UNDER PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.4 FOR ITALY:
abstract: Italy said this issue was a technical issue (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.1).

title: AD HOC WORKING GROUP
abstract: The AWG convened informal consultations on Thursday evening.

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: Parties discussed the possible scope of the planned workshop, including issues relating to definitions, drivers of deforestation, methodological and scientific issues, and positive incentives.

title: ADAPTATION:
abstract: Co-Chair Plume proposed using the tables on initial activities listed in the report of the Vienna workshop (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/4) as a basis for discussions.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING:
abstract: On capacity building under the UNFCCC (FCCC/2006/5, MISC.4, and MISC.4/Corr.1), JAPAN said the monitoring process should be streamlined.

title: Budget performance for the biennium 2006-2007
abstract: The Secretariat introduced this item (FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.4).

title: Implementation of the Headquarters Agreement
abstract: Germany summarized progress on the new UN Bonn campus.

title: Privileges and immunities
abstract: The Secretariat introduced the issue of privileges and immunities for individuals serving on constituted bodies under the Kyoto Protocol (FCCC/SBI/2006/6 and FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.6).

title: OTHER MATTERS:
abstract: Level of emissions for the base year of Croatia: The Secretariat introduced the position paper by Croatia (FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.1).

title: AMENDMENT OF THE PROTOCOL IN RESPECT TO THE COMPLIANCE MECHANISM:
abstract: Delegates considered this item in light of Decision 27/CMP.1, which agreed to begin consideration of the issue with a view to taking a decision at COP/MOP 3.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSACTION LOG:
abstract: Parties discussed progress on the International Transaction Log (ITL) (FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.3).

title: Third review of the financial mechanism
abstract: The Secretariat introduced this item (FCCC/SBI/2006/7 and 18, MISC.9, MISC.3 and INF.7).

title: COOPERATION WITH RELEVANT INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS:
abstract: Special report on the ozone layer and climate system - issues relating to hydrofluorocarbons and perfluorocarbons: The Secretariat introduced this issue (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.2 and MISC.7).

title: OTHER MATTERS:
abstract: On Protocol-related matters, the Secretariat reported on training for Protocol Article 8 expert review teams.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
abstract: Co-Chair Levaggi presented on the outcomes of a workshop on the Fund (FCCC/SBI/2006/10, annex), and the Secretariat noted that current analyses of the value of CERs that could be applied to the Fund are US$350 million by 2012 (at US$10 per CER).

title: HFC-23:
abstract: On avoiding perverse incentives that would result in increased production of HCFC-22 as a result of crediting the destruction of HFC-23 under the CDM, BRAZIL, SOUTH AFRICA, BOLIVIA and others proposed limiting crediting to existing production capacity.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
topics: Post-Kyoto Agreements|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The Secretariat explained that the 1946 UN Convention on Privileges and Immunities cannot automatically be extended to individuals serving in constituted bodies under the Protocol, and a new legal instrument or ad hoc arrangements are necessary. ARGENTINA mentioned amending the Protocol and MEXICO a new agreement, while the EU supported existing legal frameworks.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: Co-Chair Castellari said the aim of the contact group is to decide on implementation of Decision 9/CP.11.

title: REVIEW OF THE FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
abstract: Co-Chairs Sach and Levaggi proposed exchanging views based on the criteria in the annex of Decision 3/CP.4 (review of the financial mechanism).

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: The G-77/CHINA stressed implementation, capacity building and economic and market barriers.

title: INFORMAL CONSULTATIONS DEFORESTATION:
abstract: Co-Chairs Audun Rosland (Norway) and Hern n Carlino (Argentina) presented a proposal on the scope of the upcoming workshop on deforestation.

title: ADAPTATION:
abstract: Before beginning discussions on revising the initial list of activities for the period from SBSTA 24 to SBSTA 28 under the five-year programme of work on adaptation (as presented in the report of the Vienna informal meeting), the G-77/CHINA proposed various additions and alternative text.

title: Special Climate Change Fund (SCCF)
abstract: SBI Chair Becker introduced this item (FCCC/SBI/2005/10 annex I).

title: SPECIAL REPORT RELATING TO HFCs AND PFCs
abstract: In informal consultations, several industrialized countries said further consideration of this issue was not necessary, as the Special Report provided parties with the guidance they need to act domestically.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Parties exchanged views on the work of the CGE, compilation and synthesis of initial national communications, and the provision of financial and technical support.

title: COP 12 and COP/MOP 2
abstract: Richard Kinley, UNFCCC Officer-in-Charge, briefed delegates on arrangements for COP 12 and COP/MOP 2 (FCCC/SBI/2006/2), highlighting the huge challenge of holding the COP, COP/MOP, SBI, SBSTA, AWG, UNFCCC Dialogue, and contact groups within a two-week period.

title: Review of COP 11 and COP/MOP 1
abstract: Richard Kinley noted questions about the participation of observers in the COP/MOP.

title: Organization of the intergovernmental process
abstract: Richard Kinley noted recent discussions on how to manage complicated agendas, multiplicity of contact groups, and exhaustion of delegates.

title: ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
abstract: The Secretariat introduced a synthesis of reports on demonstrable progress by Annex I countries in achieving their Kyoto targets (FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.2).

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The Secretariat introduced documents relating to the Adaptation Fund (FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.5, MISC.7 & Add.1) and Chair Becker reported on the workshop in Edmonton (FCCC/SBI/2006/10).

title: POLICIES AND MEASURES:
abstract: On Annex I parties  policies and measures, the EU, SAUDI ARABIA, BELARUS and others, opposed by the US and JAPAN, supported further consideration of this issue by SBSTA.

title: Cooperation with other conventions, organizations and bodies
abstract: Delegates were briefed on cooperative activities (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.4), a relevant CBD decision in March 2006, the outcome of CSD 14, and recent activities of the IPCC. MAURITIUS called for a SBSTA agenda item on the Mauritius Strategy.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The Co-Chairs distributed a proposal based on the outcomes and submissions from the Adaptation Fund workshop held in June 2005, noting that the proposal is not a formal negotiation text.

title: INFORMAL CONSULTATIONS ADAPTATION:
abstract: During informal consultations, delegates continued to work through the initial list of activities identified at the Vienna workshop with a view to simplifying the list.

title: IPCC 2006 GUIDELINES ON INVENTORIES AND HARVESTED WOOD PRODUCTS:
abstract: In informal consultations conducted by Riitta Pipatti (Finland), parties exchanged views on the process for considering the Guidelines, and on issues forwarded from the previous SBSTA, including biomass burning, methane emissions, and harvested wood products.

title: AD HOC WORKING GROUP
abstract: Informal bilateral and small group consultations continued on Saturday, with discussions focusing on general issues of process and objectives.

title: WORKSHOP ON CARBON Capture AND STORAGE
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Flexibility Mechanims|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: An in-session workshop on carbon dioxide capture and storage (CCS) convened on Saturday.

title: COP 12 and COP/MOP 2
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: Co-Chair Wörgetter drew attention to the recent Earth Negotiations Bulletin's In The Corridors section, which noted concerns about meeting fatigue.

title: Future sessional periods
abstract: Parties agreed to a US proposal to move the dates for the second sessional period in 2011 to 28 November - 9 December.

title: Review of COP/MOP 1 and COP 11 arrangements
abstract: The US and AUSTRALIA noted new information on participation of observer states since the Secretariat's paper (FCCC/SBI/2006/2) had been produced, and Chair de Wet said this would be taken into account.

title: Organization of intergovernmental process
abstract: Parties suggested proposals to increase efficiency through innovations such as agenda clustering and multi-year work cycles (FCCC/SBI/2006/3 and MISC.8).

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: Co-Chairs Carlino and Rosland presented draft text on the scope of the upcoming workshop.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
abstract: Delegates discussed options for protecting individuals serving on constituted bodies under the Protocol from legal actions, which include a COP/MOP decision granting them privileges and immunities, written confirmation from private entities to settle all disputes at the Secretariat's headquarters and ad hoc arrangements.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: Delegates met informally on Saturday morning and in a contact group that afternoon, when they considered draft conclusions paragraph-by-paragraph.

title: SPECIAL CLIMATE CHANGE FUND:
abstract: Delegates began discussions on the draft decision forwarded from SBI 22 (FCCC/SBI/2005/10), focusing on two proposals for using the SCCF to finance activities set out in Decision 7/CP.7, paragraph 2 (d) (funding under the Convention).

title: ADAPTATION:
abstract: In the morning contact group, Co-Chair Plume presented draft conclusions containing initial activities of the five-year programme of work on adaptation.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: The G-77/CHINA and a group composed of the US, JAPAN, CANADA and AUSTRALIA each submitted texts.

title: AD HOC WORKING GROUP
topics: Post-Kyoto Agreements|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: Delegates met for informal consultations during the morning and the afternoon.

title: WORKSHOP ON CARBON CAPTURE AND STORAGE AS CDM ACTIVITIES
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Flexibility Mechanims|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: An in-session workshop on carbon capture and storage (CCS) as CDM project activities convened on Monday.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
abstract: Delegates considered whether to accept the co-chairs  text as the basis for negotiations.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING (KYOTO PROTOCOL)
abstract: This issue was addressed in a contact group and during informal consultations.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: Informal consultations were held in the morning and afternoon before the contact group reconvened in the evening.

title: REVIEW OF THE FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
abstract: Delegates met informally during the day and in a contact group in the evening, at which time copies were distributed of a G-77/China proposal, an EU proposal, and a compilation of the proposals prepared by the Co-Chairs.

title: SPECIAL CLIMATE CHANGE FUND:
abstract: During informal discussions, delegates discussed separate proposals from the Chair and the G-77/China for the paragraph on financing activities set out in Decision 7/CP.7, paragraph 2(d) (funding under the Convention).

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS:
abstract: Parties discussed the organization of the intergovernmental process, agreeing to suggestions submitted by the EU that would mean some issues are included on SB's agenda once each year rather than twice.

title: BUNKER FUELS:
abstract: In informal consultations on emissions from fuel used for international aviation and maritime transport, little progress was reported, with some parties expressing the view that forward movement was not possible without progress in other areas, such as Protocol Article 2.3 (adverse effects).

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: During informal consultations on deforestation, parties worked through revised draft conclusions that include the scope of an upcoming workshop.

title: AD HOC WORKING GROUP
actors: African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: On Tuesday evening, the AWG reconvened in plenary.

title: ADAPTATION:
abstract: Informal consultations on the five-year programme of work on adaptation continued throughout the day, with Co-Chair Plume presenting draft SBSTA conclusions in the late afternoon, and the Secretariat presenting a preliminary estimation of required, secured and additional resources for the programme of work until December 2007.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
abstract: Delegates met informally in the morning and in a contact group in the afternoon to discuss a Co-Chairs  text that compiles parties views on operation of the Fund, and to add new options to the text, but not to negotiate wording.

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS:
abstract: On Tuesday evening, delegates convened in the contact group and exchanged views on draft text relating to the organization of COP 12 and COP/MOP 2, future sessional periods, review of arrangements for COP 11 and COP/MOP 1, and organization of the intergovernmental process.

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: The contact group convened for its closing session to finalize text already agreed at informal consultations held the previous day on the scope of an upcoming workshop.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
abstract: In this contact group, delegates considered new proposals to the text presented by the Chair and by Brazil that set out various options for protecting individuals serving on constituted bodies under the Protocol.

title: SPECIAL CLIMATE CHANGE FUND:
abstract: Delegates convened in a contact group in the evening and broke for informal consultations to discuss text on financing activities set out in Decision 7/CP.7, paragraph 2 (d)(f unding under the Convention) before returning to the contact group.

title: INFORMAL CONSULTATIONS
abstract: IPCC 2006 GUIDELINES AND HARVESTED WOOD PRODUCTS (HWP): Informal consultations continued on the IPCC 2006 Guidelines and HWP.

title: WORKSHOP ON MITIGATION: AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY AND RURAL DEVELOPMENT
abstract: An in-session workshop on mitigation relating to agriculture, forestry and rural development was convened on Tuesday.

title: AD HOC WORKING GROUP
abstract: The AWG met informally in the afternoon, evening and late into the night.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
abstract: Delegates met informally in the morning and afternoon, and in a contact group meeting in the evening.

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS:
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: On Wednesday morning, the contact group completed its work after making a number of revisions to the Chairs draft text.

title: HFC-23:
abstract: The contact group considering HFC-23 under the CDM met to adopt draft conclusions agreed previously during informal consultations.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
abstract: Delegates met informally and in a contact group in the morning to consider draft SBI conclusions and a decision.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: Delegates met in informal consultations throughout the day to discuss the Co-Chairs draft conclusions.

title: INFORMAL CONSULTATIONS ADAPTATION:
abstract: Informal consultations on the five-year programme of work continued throughout the day.

title: BRAZILIAN PROPOSAL:
abstract: Informal consultations on the scientific and methodological aspects of the proposal by Brazil concluded on Wednesday morning.

title: MAURITIUS STRATEGY ON SIDS:
abstract: During informal consultations, SBSTA Chair Kumarsingh presented text including a proposal to invite party submissions on how the Mauritius Strategy could be mainstreamed into the agenda of the subsidiary bodies.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: Delegates adopted SBI conclusions prepared by SBI Chair Becker on budget performance for the biennium 2006-2007 (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.3) and on Implementation of the Headquarters Agreement (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.5).

title: Adaptation Fund
abstract: Following a contact group meeting in which delegates were unable to reach consensus on language on inviting institutions that may manage the Fund, discussion continued in plenary.

title: EXPERTS GROUP MEETING:
abstract: SBI Chair Becker reported on the outcomes of a meeting of the three expert groups (CGE, EGTT and LEG), noting that they will explore the possibility of a joint meeting on adaptation.

title: REPORT OF THE SESSION:
abstract: Delegates agreed to the report of the session (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.1) and SBI Chair Becker closed SBI 24 at 7:24 pm.

title: AGENDA/MAURITIUS STRATEGY
abstract: SBSTA Chair Kumarsingh reported no progress on informal consultations on inclusion of the Mauritius Strategy on the SBSTA agenda, and suggested including the item.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: Co-Chair Sergio Castellari (Italy) reported on contact group consultations.

title: Bunker Fuels
abstract: Noting that conclusions on this agenda item were purely procedural, Jos Romero (Switzerland) suggested that the lack of substance was due to a perception of this being related to other issues under discussion by SBSTA.

title: Brazilian Proposal
abstract: Co-Chair Jaekyu Lim (Republic of Korea) reported on consultations on this issue.

title: Deforestation
abstract: Co-Chair Audun Rosland (Norway) reported the successful completion of work, including defining the scope of an upcoming workshop on this issue.

title: IPCC 2006 Guidelines and Harvested Wood Products
abstract: Riitta Pipatti (Finland) reported on discussions, noting the need for more time to consider these issues.

title: Reporting, review and training of experts
abstract: SBSTA adopted conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.4). METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES (PROTOCOL): HFC-23: Chair Georg B rsting (Norway) noted that no agreement had yet been reached on guidance to the CDM Executive Board and that submissions on practical approaches to address this issue would be requested.

title: UNFCCC ARTICLE 4.8 & 4.9
actors: Least Developed Countries|Group of 77 and China
abstract: On matters relating to the least developed countries (LDCs), Samuel Adejuwon (Nigeria), who co-facilitated the informal consultations, reported agreement on the LDC Expert Group's work programme, and delegates adopted the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.2). CAPACITY BUILDING (CONVENTION): Contact group Co-Chair Crispin D'Auvergne (St. Lucia) summarized discussions.

title: Numerical value inscribed for Italy
abstract: Thelma Krug (Brazil) explained that agreement had been reached, and delegates adopted conclusions and a draft decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.6 and Add.1).

title: POLICIES AND MEASURES:
abstract: Normand Trembley (Canada) reported lack of agreement on a second roundtable and said discussion will be postponed until SBSTA 28.

title: COOPERATION WITH RELEVANT INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS:
abstract: Parties adopted brief conclusions on the IPCC Special Report on the ozone layer and climate system (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.9) and on cooperation with other conventions, scientific organizations and UN bodies (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.14), with SBSTA Coordinator Halldor Thorgeirsson noting overlap between CSD 15 and SB 26.

title: OTHER MATTERS:
abstract: Delegates adopted conclusions on the greenhouse gas data interface (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.12) and on the training programme for expert review team members under Protocol Article 8 (review of information) (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.3). AD HOC WORKING GROUP The AWG plenary convened shortly before midnight.

title: ADAPTATION:
abstract: Informal consultations on the five-year programme of work on adaptation were held during the day and late into the night.

title: ARRANGEMENTS OF INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS:
abstract: Parties adopted conclusions addressing arrangements for COP 12, COP/MOP 2 and future sessional periods, and review of arrangements for COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.9).

title: COMPLIANCE:
abstract: After debating and finally accepting a proposal by SAUDI ARABIA to add that the SBI Chair will report orally to the COP/MOP 2 based on the conclusions on this agenda item, delegates adopted the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.1/Rev.1) as amended.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSACTION LOG:
abstract: Delegates adopted the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.8) without comment.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
abstract: Chair Paul Watkinson (France) explained that the Secretariat is requested to continue examining different options for protecting individuals in constituted bodies under the Protocol.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Delegates adopted conclusions on the non-Annex I national communications consultative group of experts (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.12/Rev.1), and conclusions on compilation and synthesis of initial national communications (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.13/Rev.1) with a minor correction.

title: BASE YEAR OF CROATIA:
abstract: Jim Penman (UK) reported on informal consultations.

title: ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
abstract: On the synthesis of Annex I demonstrable progress reports under Article 3.2 of the Protocol, SBI Chair Becker reported on informal consultations.

title: AD HOC WORKING GROUP
abstract: The first session of the AWG began on Wednesday afternoon, 17 May .

title: AWG
topics: Post-Kyoto Agreements|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: Chair Zammit Cutajar said the AWG is important because it presents an opportunity for Annex I parties to demonstrate leadership and an occasion to give a signal of continuity to the carbon markets.

title: PLANNING OF FUTURE WORK
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: The issue of future work was first taken up in plenary on 17 May , and required extensive informal consultations before agreement was reached just before midnight on 25 May .

title: AWG Outcome
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: In its agreement on the planning of future work (FCCC/KP/AWG/2006/L.2/Rev.1), the AWG: takes note of parties  submissions (FCCC/KP/AWG/2006/MISC.1 & Add.1) and statements concerning Protocol Article 3.9; reaffirms that its discussions will focus on the consideration of further commitments by Annex I parties to be established in amendments to Annex B of the Kyoto Protocol; recalls that AWG should aim to complete its work on time to ensure no gap between the first and the second commitment periods; reaffirms that it will proceed expeditiously towards agreement on further commitments; observes that Annex I parties need to assemble and analyze information on scientific, technical and socioeconomic topics to enhance understanding of the ambition level of further commitments; notes that information can be sought from other bodies and processes under the Convention and Protocol, IPCC, intergovernmental organizations and parties themselves; considers that it is important to keep in mind work underway and relevant results from other Convention and Protocol bodies and processes; and notes the relevance of continuing to review implementation of commitments for the first commitment period.

title: CLOSING SESSION
abstract: On Thursday, 25 May , the AWG reconvened in plenary just before midnight.

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR IMPLEMENTATION SBI
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: Chair Thomas Becker (Denmark) opened the session on Thursday morning, 18 May .

title: ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: This issue was first taken up by the SBI plenary on 19 May , when delegates considered a synthesis of reports by Annex I parties on demonstrating progress under Protocol Article 3.2 (FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.2).

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.14/Rev.1), the SBI decides to continue consideration of this matter at SBI 25.

title: PROGRESS ON IMPLEMENTING DECISION 1/CP.10
abstract: This issue was first taken up in plenary on 18 May and was then forwarded to informal consultations conducted by Emily Ojoo-Massawa (Kenya) and Henriette Bersee (the Netherlands).

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.13), the SBI notes the importance of enhancing and maintaining capacity in non-Annex I parties, inter alia , in the area of national greenhouse gas inventories.

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL:
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP 3 in Kyoto, Japan , agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries making the transition to a market economy to achieve emissions reduction targets.

title: COMPILATION AND SYNTHESIS OF INITIAL NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS:
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: This issue was first taken up in the SBI plenary on 18 May .

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Implementation|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.7), the SBI welcomes information from the GEF on its support for non-Annex I national communications and invites the GEF to continue providing such information.

title: PROVISION OF FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT:
actors: Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: This issue was first taken up in plenary on 19 May , with the G-77/China and AOSIS emphasizing the importance of addressing financial, technical and institutional constraints.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.4), the

title: THIRD REVIEW OF THE FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
abstract: This item was first taken up in plenary on 19 May .

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.6), the SBI notes that SBI 24 continued to consider the draft text produced at SB 22 (FCCC/SBI/2005/10, Annex I), and the matter will continue to be deliberated at SB 25 on the basis of that text, with a view to finalizing its recommendation to COP 12 on the operation of the SCCF. FINANCIAL MECHANISM (KYOTO PROTOCOL)

title: SPECIAL CLIMATE CHANGE FUND:
abstract: This item was first considered in plenary on 20 May , and then informally and in several contact group meetings chaired by Bubu Jallow (Gambia).

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.18), the

title: Final Outcome
abstract: SBI took note of the information provided.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
abstract: This item was introduced in the SBI plenary on 19 May , and then considered in informal consultations and contact group meetings co-chaired by Karsten Sach (Germany) and Marcia Levaggi (Argentina).

title: BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION:
abstract: The process for finalizing the rules and operational details of the Protocol was agreed to at COP 4 in 1998 in a document known as the Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA).

title: PROGRESS ON IMPLEMENTING DECISION 1/CP.10
abstract: This issue was taken up in plenary on 18 May .

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.2), the SBI expresses its appreciation of the LEG's work.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.15), the SBI states that it did not complete the consideration of this item and agrees to continue consideration at SBI 25. CAPACITY BUILDING (PROTOCOL): This issue was first taken up in plenary on 19 May .

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.16), the SBI states that it did not complete the consideration of this item and agrees to continue consideration at SBI 25.

title: MATTERS RELATING TO LEAST DEVELOPED COUNTRIES:
abstract: This issue was first taken up in plenary on 18 May , when delegates addressed the Least Developed Countries Expert Group (LEG) and its need for a new work programme in response to Decision 4/CP.11, which extends the LEG's mandate.

title: COMPLIANCE
abstract: The agenda item on amendment of the Kyoto Protocol in respect of procedures and mechanisms relating to compliance was taken up in plenary on 19 May and during informal consultations.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.11/Rev.1), the SBI agrees to consider this issue at SBI 25 with the view to completing consideration at SBI 27.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSACTION LOG
abstract: The international transaction log, a computer system that performs automated checks to verify transactions of carbon credits under the Kyoto Protocol, was considered briefly by SBI 24 in plenary on 18 May .

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.8), the SBI takes note of the progress report on implementation of the transaction log (FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.3).

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: At SB 24 , parties considered various issues relating to future arrangements and organization of meetings (FCCC/SBI/2006/2) .

title: MARRAKESH ACCORDS:
abstract: In late October and early November 2001 at COP 7 in Marrakesh, Morocco , delegates resumed their discussions and reached agreement on the Marrakesh Accords.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.9), the SBI finalizes details relating to COP 12 and COP/MOP 2, noting that additional investments in infrastructure will be required to accommodate these meetings.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.3), the

title: BUDGET PERFORMANCE FOR THE BIENNIUM 2006-2007:
abstract: This issue was introduced in SBI plenary on 19 May .

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCC/SBI/2006/L.5), the SBI: takes note of the statement made by the Host Government describing progress on the accommodation of the Secretariat's offices at the UN campus in Bonn; notes with appreciation that the Host Government has agreed to cover costs associated with the move; takes note of the statement by the Officer-in-Charge and requests him to inform the SBI of any new developments; invites the Host Government and the Executive Secretary to report to SB 26 on further progress on the implementation of the Headquarters Agreement; takes note of the amendment to the Headquarters Agreement to include the Kyoto Protocol and requests the Officer-in-Charge to proceed with the formalities necessary for entry into force of that amendment.

title: IMPLEMENTATION OF THE HEADQUARTERS AGREEMENT:
abstract: This item was discussed in plenary on 19 May , at which time Karsten Sach (Germany) updated the SBI on progress on the new UN campus and preparations for the construction of an international congress center in Bonn.

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: Vulnerabilities and Impacts|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.10), the SBI, inter alia : notes that it is essential for individuals serving on constituted bodies to be able to perform their official functions effectively; requests the UNFCCC Executive Secretary to continue consultations with the UN Secretary-General on how to best extend immunities under the 1946 Convention to individuals serving on Kyoto Protocol constituted bodies and expert review teams, and on whether the COP/MOP could invite the UN General Assembly to adopt a resolution to this effect; requests the UNFCCC Executive Secretary to report on the outcome of these consultations at SB 25, and to prepare a note for SB 25 analyzing, inter alia, the practical and legal implications of obtaining written agreement from private entities participating in CDM and JI to settle claims against individuals serving on constituted bodies or expert review teams in accordance with the decisions of the COP/MOP and at the Secretariat's headquarters, and of providing assistance upon request to such individuals faced with complaints concerning their official functions; and decides to consider this matter at SB 25 on the basis of this report and note by the Executive Secretary and to prepare a draft COP/MOP 2 decision taking into account views expressed by parties.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES :
abstract: This issue was considered in plenary on 18 May .

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.17/Rev.1), the SBI decides to continue consideration of this matter at SBI 25. closING session On Thursday evening, 25 May , the closing SBI 24 plenary convened.

title: LEVEL OF EMISSIONS FOR THE BASE YEAR OF CROATIA:
abstract: This issue was taken up in plenary on 18 May and during informal consultations conducted by Jim Penman (UK).

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL ADVICE
abstract: SBSTA 24 opened on Thursday, 18 May , when SBSTA Chair Kishan Kumarsingh (Trinidad and Tobago) welcomed participants.

title: COP 10 :
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: At COP 10 in Buenos Aires in December 2004 , delegates agreed on the Buenos Aires Programme of Work on Adaptation and Response Measures.

title: MAURITIUS STRATEGY:
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The agenda sub-item on the International Meeting to Review the Implementation of the Programme of Action for the Sustainable Development of SIDS (the Mauritius Strategy) has been held in abeyance since SBSTA 23, when the US and Australia, opposed by AOSIS, the EU and many other parties, objected to its inclusion.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
abstract: Parties then considered organizational matters, including the provisional agenda (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/1 and Corr.1).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.17), the SBSTA welcomes the exchange of views during the Vienna workshop; requests the Secretariat to regularly update the list of organizations and institutions active in areas relevant to the five-year programme of work; and agrees to consider the activities to be undertaken for the period up to SBSTA 28 on the basis of draft text included in the annex, with a view to completing this task at SBSTA 25, and to consider and further elaborate at SBSTA 28 and thereafter additional activities and modalities of the programme of work.

title: FIVE-YEAR PROGRAMME OF WORK ON ADAPTATION
actors: Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This agenda item was first taken up in SBSTA plenary on 18 May , and then a contact group and informal meetings.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.16), the SBSTA, inter alia : welcomes the recommendations by the EGTT and recognizes that they constitute a set of possible actions for enhancing implementation of the technology transfer framework that could be considered by COP 12 or at subsequent sessions; endorses the five themes included in the EGTT recommendations; notes the synthesis report on technology needs and completion of TNAs; encourages non-Annex I parties that have not done so to complete their TNAs; notes technology needs in the energy, industry and transport sectors for mitigation and agriculture and coastal areas for adaptation; identifies barriers to technology transfer; recommends that TNA summaries are included in non-Annex I national communications; urges parties in position to do so to provide technical and financial assistance to further identify and implement technology needs; highlights consideration of TNA on a sectoral basis; and invites SBI to request the GEF to consider identified barriers when providing support for TNAs.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: This agenda item was first presented in SBSTA plenary on 18 May , and subsequently taken up in contact group and informal consultations co-chaired by Carlos Fuller (Belize) and Kunihiko Shimada (Japan).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.7), the SBSTA: takes note of a side event, information and views on identified research needs; invites international climate change research programmes to submit summary reports drawing on the side event, including identification of gaps; notes efforts to establish regional climate change research networks and encourages parties to support and further develop them; recognizes the importance of data exchange and encourages parties to support and strengthen systematic observation; and notes the need for enhancing two-way communication.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION
abstract: This agenda item was first presented in the SBSTA plenary on 18 May , and subsequently taken up in contact group and informal consultations co-chaired by Sergio Castellari (Italy) and María Paz Cigarán (Peru).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
topics: forests|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.8), the SBSTA notes that, in their submissions, parties note the need to address emissions from deforestation in developing countries.

title: REDUCING EMISSIONS FROM DEFORESTATION IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
abstract: This agenda item was first presented to the SBSTA plenary on 18 May , and subsequently addressed in contact groups and various informal consultations co-chaired by Audun Rosland (Norway) and Hernán Carlino (Argentina).

title: SEMINAR OF GOVERNMENTAL EXPERTS AND SB 22 :
abstract: This seminar took place in May 2005, in Bonn.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.10), the SBSTA welcomes the timely work of the IPCC in preparing the 2006 IPCC Guidelines and recognizes that parties will need additional time to analyze them.

title: IPCC 2006 GUIDELINES FOR NATIONAL INVENTORIES AND HARVESTED WOOD PRODUCTS (HWP)
abstract: These two related sub-items were first addressed in plenary on 18 May , and subsequently in various informal meetings chaired by Riitta Pipatti (Finland).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.5), the SBSTA notes that consideration of this issue was not completed, and agrees to continue considering the matter at SBSTA 25.

title: BUNKER FUELS:
abstract: The issue of emissions from fuel used for international aviation and maritime transport - also referred to as bunker fuels - was taken up briefly in SBSTA plenary on 18 May , before being referred to informal consultations conducted by José Romero (Switzerland).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
