abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.13), the SBSTA inter alia : expresses its appreciation to the scientific community for its work to build on the Brazilian proposal and notes that this process remains open to strengthen participation from scientists from developing countries; notes that further work is required; encourages all interested parties, research institutions and scientists to undertake further work and continue to exchange information; notes that it expects the scientific work to be completed by the third quarter of 2007; requests the Secretariat to organize an in-session special side event at SBSTA 27, inviting invites parties  submissions by 7 March 2008; and agrees to complete consideration of this agenda item once the scientific work is sufficiently completed, indicating that it would like to be able to do so at SBSTA 28, or shortly thereafter.

title: BRAZILIAN PROPOSAL:
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The scientific and methodological aspects of the proposal by Brazil on accounting for historical and future emissions were taken up in plenary on 18 May and in informal consultations co-chaired by Jaekyu Lim (Republic of Korea) and Jean-Pascale van Ypersele de Strihou (Belgium).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.5) , the SBSTA notes that two sets of relevant guidelines have proved to be valuable tools in improving the consistency, timeliness, completeness, comparability and transparency of greenhouse gas inventories.

title: EXPERIENCE WITH REPORTING AND REVIEW, AND WITH TRAINING OF EXPERTS:
abstract: Parties considered a report on this issue (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/2) in plenary on 18 May , with several parties noting the need to sustain expertise.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.15), the SBSTA notes that COP/MOP 1 recognized that issuing CERs for the destruction of HFC-23 at new HCFC-22 facilities could lead to increases in the production of HCFC-22 and/or HFC-23 and that the CDM should not lead to such increases.

title: HFC-23:
abstract: The implications of the establishment of new HCFC-22 facilities seeking to obtain Certified Emissions Reductions (CERs) under the CDM for the destruction of HFC-23 was taken up in SBSTA plenary on 18 May , in a contact group and informal consultations chaired by Georg Børsting (Norway).

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.12/Rev.1), the SBI, inter alia , welcomes the CGE's progress report and notes the outcomes of two hands-on training workshops.

title: SBSTA Conclusions and draft COP/MOP Decision
abstract: The conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.6) recommend a draft COP/MOP decision(FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.6/Add.1), deciding that for the first commitment period, additions to and subtractions from the assigned amount of Italy resulting from forest management under Protocol Article 3.4 (after the application of paragraph 10 of the annex to decision 16/CMP.1 and resulting from forest management project activities undertaken under Protocol Article 6 on Joint Implementation), shall not exceed 2.78 Mt C/year times five.

title: NUMERICAL VALUE FOR FOREST MANAGEMENT UNDER PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.4 FOR ITALY:
abstract: This issue was presented in SBSTA plenary on 18 May and then addressed in informal consultations.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.11), the SBSTA invites parties to submit, by 1 March 2008, their views specifically on the need for further events to facilitate this exchange of information and sharing of experiences on policies and measures of Annex I parties, and requests the Secretariat to compile those views for consideration by SBSTA 28.

title: MITIGATION
abstract: At SBSTA 23, parties agreed to continue work on the scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of mitigation by holding workshops at the next four SBSTA sessions.

title: Special Report on the ozone layer and climate system: HFCs and PFCs
abstract: This agenda item was first presented in the SBSTA plenary on 19 May , and subsequently taken up in informal consultations conducted by Rawleston Moore (Barbados).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.9) the SBSTA: welcomes the IPCC Special Report and the Technology and Economic Assessment Panel of the Montreal Protocol (TEAP) report; recalls the SBSTA 23 decision to hold an in-session workshop on non-CO2 emissions by SBSTA 27; recognizes that actions to protect the ozone layer or address climate change can have implications for both climate change mitigation and ozone layer protection; and encourages continued cooperation between the UNFCCC and Montreal Protocol Secretariats.

title: Cooperation with other conventions, scientific organizations and UN bodies
abstract: This issue was considered briefly in plenary on 19 May (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.4) before being taken up in informal consultations conducted by Marcela Main (Chile) and Gregory Picker (Australia).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.14), the SBSTA, inter alia : recognizes that cooperation at the national level, including through the national focal points, provides the greatest opportunities for efficient and effective cooperation on issues of relevance to the three Rio Conventions; notes that parties set their own priorities regarding the conventions and encourages parties in their efforts to improve and facilitate cooperation at the national level, bearing in mind the independent mandates of each Convention; and requests the Secretariat to report on the outcome of the fifteenth session of the United Nations Commission on Sustainable Development (CSD-15) at SB 26.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.12), the SBSTA takes note of the Secretariat's oral report on progress in implementing training programmes for members of expert review teams participating in review activities under Protocol Article 8.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: TRAINING PROGRAMME FOR REVIEWERS UNDER PROTOCOL ARTICLE 8 (REVIEW OF INFORMATION): The SBSTA considered this item briefly on 19 May , when SBSTA Chair Kumarsingh said he would prepare draft conclusions.

title: COP 11 AND COP/MOP 1 :
abstract: COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 took place in Montreal, Canada, from 28 November to 10 December 2005.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.12), the SBSTA, inter alia : requests the Secretariat to continue to improve access to and regularly update greenhouse gas inventory information through the UNFCCC website; requests the Secretariat to present the data interface to parties by the end of 2006 with a view to making it fully operational before May 2007; invites parties to provide the Secretariat, by 23 February 2007, views on the data interface, on possible improvements, and on next steps; and agrees to continue this issue at SBSTA 26. closing session On Friday morning, 26 May , SBSTA convened for its closing plenary.

title: GREENHOUSE GAS DATABASE:
abstract: This issue was taken up briefly in plenary on 19 May , when the Secretariat briefed participants on the matter. SBSTA Chair Kumarsingh subsequently presented draft conclusions, which were adopted on 25 May .

title: A CYCLICAL PROCESS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: To date, climate change negotiations have shown a cyclical pattern.

title: BUSINESS NOT-SO-USUAL
abstract: One of the remarkable features about the climate process is the growing involvement of business and the interest of new business sectors.

title: GROWING PAINS - CLIMATE CHANGE AND THE UNFCCC
abstract: The UNFCCC is growing in size and complexity.

title: REPORT OF SB 24 AND AWG 1
abstract: The Ad Hoc Working Group on Further Commitments for Annex I Parties under the Kyoto Protocol (AWG) opened on 17 May .

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL:
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP 3 in Kyoto, Japan, agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries in transition to a market economy to achieve emissions reduction targets.

title: BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION:
abstract: The process for finalizing the rules and operational details of the Protocol was agreed at COP 4 in 1998 in a document known as the Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA).

title: MARRAKESH ACCORDS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation|Technology Transfer
abstract: In October and November 2001 at COP 7 in Marrakesh, Morocco, delegates reached agreement on the outstanding matters in the Marrakesh Accords.

title: COP 11 AND COP/MOP 1 :
abstract: COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 took place in Montreal, Canada, from 28 November to 10 December 2005.

title: SB 24 AND AWG 1 :
abstract: The twenty-fourth sessions of the Subsidiary Bodies and first session of the AWG were held in Bonn in May 2006.

title: AWG WORKSHOP
abstract: The AWG convened an in-session workshop chaired by AWG Vice Chair Luiz Alberto Figueiredo Machado.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 2.3:
actors: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: The EU noted that Article 2.3 (adverse effects of policies and measures) was addressed under other agenda items.

title: BUNKER FUELS:
abstract: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) reported on its work on emissions from international shipping.

title: Report of the GEF
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: In its report ( FCCC/CP/2006/3 ), the GEF highlighted climate change as the fourth replenishment's highest-ever allocation.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM OF THE CONVENTION - SCCF:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: The EU and SWITZERLAND stressed the need to fully operationalize the SCCF.

title: UNFCCC ARTICLE 6:
abstract: On Article 6 (education, training and public awareness), the Secretariat presented a synthesis report on four regional workshops ( FCCC/SBI/2006/17 ) and parties views on advancing work on CC:iNet the prototype information network clearinghouse ( FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.15 ).

title: Matters relating to LDCs
abstract: The Secretariat and LDC Expert Group (LEG) Chair Bubu Pateh Jallow reported on LDC issues and progress on NAPAs ( FCCC/SBI/2006/23 ).

title: UNFCCC ARTICLE 4.8 AND 4.9:
abstract: The Secretariat briefed participants on intersessional meetings (FCCC/SBI/2006/13, FCCC/SBI/2006/18 and FCCC/SBI/2006/19 ) and GHANA highlighted a recent African workshop on adaptation.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE CONVENTION:
abstract: The Secretariat reported on capacity building implementation, GEF capacity building performance indicators and monitoring ( FCCC/SBI/2006/5 ; FCCC/SBI/2006/16 ; FCCC/SBI/2006/22 ) and on parties views on regular monitoring of activities ( FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.4 , Corr.1 and Add.1).

title: SCIENTIFIC BASIS FOR FURTHER ANNEX I COMMITMENTS:
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Technology Transfer
abstract: On the stabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations, Bert Metz, Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), reviewed scenarios set out in the Panel's Third Assessment Report.

title: EMISSION TRENDS AND MITIGATION POTENTIAL:
abstract: Sergey Kononov, UNFCCC Secretariat, noted increasing emissions for Annex I parties, highlighted the relevance of LULUCF for some parties  emissions profiles, and underscored the high growth rate for emissions in transport.

title: REDUCING EMISSIONS FROM DEFORESTATION :
abstract: The Secretariat presented on the Rome adaptation workshop ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/10 ).

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: The Global Climate Observation System (GCOS) presented on revising reporting guidelines ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.12 ) and a regional workshop programme ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.13 ).

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES UNDER THE CONVENTION:
abstract: The Secretariat presented a technical review of and updated guidelines on greenhouse gas inventories ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/INF.6 ; FCCC/SBSTA/2006/9).

abstract: Implications of awarding CDM credits to new HCFC-22 facilities for the destruction of

title: Issues relating to greenhouse gas inventories
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The Secretariat presented results from a training programme for review experts under Protocol Article 8 on review of national communications ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/INF.7 ).

title: HFC-23:
abstract: The Secretariat presented on this issue ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.11 ). ARGENTINA and the EU welcomed the decision by Montreal Protocol parties to assess measures to reduce production of HCFCs and to consider the influence of the CDM on HCFC-22 production in consultation with the UNFCCC Secretariat, IPCC and CDM Executive Board.

title: Synthesis report on Kyoto Protocol Article 3.2 (demonstrable progress)
abstract: The Secretariat introduced the issue ( FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.2 and FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.7 ).

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM
abstract: (CONVENTION): The contact group began consideration of the third review of the financial mechanism on the basis of SB 24 conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.4).

title: IMPLEMENTATION OF DECISION 1/CP.10:
abstract: Parties discussed reports from the intersessional and presessional activities on the impacts of response measures mandated under Decision 1/CP.10.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Informal consultations on national communications from non-Annex I Parties were held.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The Secretariat introduced the issue ( FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.7 and Add.1; FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.11 and FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.16 ).

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.14:
abstract: Several parties reflected on the outcomes of a workshop on reporting methodologies held in Abu Dhabi, UAE, from 4-6 September 2006 ( FCCC/SBI/2006/27 ).

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE KYOTO PROTOCOL:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: JAPAN encouraged incorporation of stakeholders needs and preferences, while Tanzania, for the G-77/CHINA, recalled Decisions 21/CMP.1 and 2/CP.7 on financial and technical support and, with the EU, urged addressing regional imbalances in participation in CDM projects.

title: AMENDMENT OF THE PROTOCOL:
abstract: The Secretariat said Decision 27/CMP.1 had invited the SBI to give further consideration to an amendment in respect of procedures and mechanisms relating to compliance, with a view to finalizing discussions at SBI 27.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
abstract: The Secretariat introduced the issue of privileges and immunities for individuals on the Protocol's constituted bodies ( FCCC/SBI/2006/20 and FCCC/SBI/2006/21 ).

title: AWG
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China
topics: Post-Kyoto Agreements|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: The AWG began with general statements.

title: ADAPTATION FIVE-YEAR PROGRAMME OF WORK:
abstract: Co-Chair Helen Plume (New Zealand) presented text containing the initial activities of the work programme (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/CRP.1).

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: The EU and G-77/CHINA each introduced draft decisions on the issue.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
abstract: On the Fund's overarching principles (FCCC/SBI/2006/11*), the Philippines, for the G-77/CHINA, proposed a set of principles, including the COP/MOP's authority and guidance, accountability of the Fund to the COP/MOP , and funding covering full costs of adaptation.

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: Co-Chair Rosland presented draft conclusions to the contact group.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING (Convention)
abstract: The group focused on monitoring capacity building and the GEF role under Decision 2/CP.7 (capacity building in developing countries).

title: PROTOCOL:
abstract: The contact group discussed whether it should consider the recommendations of the CDM Executive Board on capacity building, as suggested by the G-77/China.

title: AWG ISSUES:
abstract: Chair Zammit Cutajar suggested an approach to a programme of work based on clusters of quantitative and qualitative issues and invited parties to respond.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: In informal consultations, the Co-Chairs presented draft text that sought to integrate proposals from drafts submitted the previous day by the G-77/China and EU.

title: ADAPTATION PROGRAMME OF WORK:
abstract: In informal consultations, progress was reported on both technical and substantive matters, as parties sought common language in the chapeau paragraphs and worked through technical details of the list of initial activities.

title: COOPERATION WITH RELEVANT INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS:
abstract: Delegates were briefed on the activities of the Joint Liaison Group, which will meet again in December 2006.

title: AWG ISSUES:
abstract: Chair Zammit Cutajar convened the second meeting of the contact group on AWG issues.

title: Convention
abstract: Parties considered a draft text.

title: Protocol
abstract: The Co-Chairs presented a draft text.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING:
abstract: Two informal consultations were held on capacity building under the Convention and the Protocol.

title: CDM ISSUES:
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The contact group exchanged views on a range of CDM-related issues.

title: COMPLIANCE COMMITTEE:
abstract: Following bilateral negotiations by the Co-Chairs with parties, travel and funding issues from the Compliance Committee were reportedly deferred, pending informal consultations on the budget under the SBI.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
abstract: During informal consultations, delegates agreed to take note of the GEF report to the COP, and completed the first reading of the documents on the third review of the financial mechanism and additional guidance to the GEF.

title: JI SUPERVISORY COMMITTEE:
abstract: Participants met in a contact group to exchange initial ideas.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
abstract: The contact group held a question-and-answer session on the proposed options on privileges and immunities for individuals serving on the constituted bodies of the Protocol, as outlined in the response from the UN Office of Legal Affairs ( FCCC/SBI/2006/20 ).

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 9:
abstract: In informal consultations, delegates engaged in a frank exchange on issues such as the scope of the review, the purpose of the review, and how it should be conducted.

title: Activities implemented jointly under the pilot phase (AIJ)
abstract: Delegates considered AIJ and a recent synthesis report ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/8 and Corr.1 ).

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: Informal consultations continued throughout the day and the Co-Chairs released new draft text.

title: Carbon capture and storage (CCS)
abstract: The Secretariat briefed delegates on the in-session workshop on the IPCC Special Report on CCS held at SBSTA 24.

title: Ozone layer and global climate system
abstract: The SBSTA considered the IPCC/TEAP Special Report on Safeguarding the Ozone Layer and the Global System.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 2.3:
abstract: Chair Kumarsingh reported that consultations on a proposal by the EU and others to combine this SBSTA item with an SBI item on Protocol Article 3.14 (adverse effects and response measures) had not resulted in any agreement.

title: BUNKER FUELS:
abstract: Chair Kumarsingh announced that informal consultations had not resulted in an agreement on how to move forward.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
abstract: The Adaptation Fund contact group broke into closed small-group consultations focused on the principles and modalities of the Fund, making some progress on the list of principles.

title: ADAPTATION PROGRAMME OF WORK:
abstract: In the contact group, Co-Chair Charles reported on progress on informal group meetings.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: During informal consultations, delegates discussed draft conclusions proposed by Chair Dovland, addressing: audited financial statements for 2004-2005; budget performance in 2006-2007; continuing review of the functions and operations of the Secretariat; programme budget for 2008-2009; and implementation of the headquarters agreement.

title: ADAPTATION PROGRAMME OF WORK:
abstract: During morning informal consultations, parties agreed on language for the chapeau paragraphs of the sub-themes in the list of activities.

title: HCFC-22 AND HFC-23:
abstract: Parties discussed a Chair's draft text on the implications of establishing new HCFC-22 facilities seeking to obtain certified emission reductions ( CERs ) for destroying HFC-23.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: The contact group finished its work on draft conclusions to be forwarded to SBSTA.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Co-Chairs Bersee and Rolle completed informal consultations on two draft conclusions the provision of financial and technical support, and the work of the Consultative Group of Experts (CGE) on non-Annex I National Communications.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
abstract: Chair Watkinson presented the contact group with SBI draft conclusions containing a proposed COP/MOP 2 decision on issues such as Secretariat assistance to individuals who are the subject of disputes, minimizing the risks of such disputes, and financial implications.

title: PROGRESS ON IMPLEMENTATION OF DECISION 1/CP.10:
abstract: Co-Chairs Churie-Kallhauge and Adejuwon convened informal consultations on progress on the implementation of Decision 1/CP.10 (response measures).

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: The Co-Chairs distributed draft conclusions and a draft decision.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: During informal consultations, delegates reached consensus on the draft COP and COP/MOP decisions and the Chair's draft conclusions, pending two parties  consultations on: the agreement concerning the headquarters of the Secretariat; and the paragraph on encouraging continued efforts of the UNFCCC Executive Secretary to ensure a wider geographical balance in senior and managerial appointments.

title: Protocol Article 3.2 (demonstrable progress)
abstract: Co-Chairs Bersee and Rolle convened informal consultations on the synthesis of reports in accordance with Protocol Article 3.2.

title: AWG ISSUES:
abstract: During informal consultations, AWG Chair Zammit Cutajar circulated his first draft text for discussion on further commitments for Annex I parties.

title: BELARUS PROPOSAL:
abstract: During informal consultations, delegates discussed technical and legal issues related to the proposal.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING: Convention
abstract: In a contact group, parties considered draft texts previously submitted by the EU and G-77/China, addressing whether text on the objective of monitoring capacity building should be preambular or operative.

title: Protocol
abstract: Negotiations on draft text on Saturday morning did not result in agreement, and the item was not taken up in the afternoon as delegates sought to make progress on capacity building under the Convention.

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: On the scope of a second workshop, parties agreed to continue discussing the topics identified in the first workshop, focusing on ongoing and potential policy approaches and positive incentives, and technical and methodological requirements related to their implementation.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
abstract: Delegates considered the Co-Chairs  draft text on the review of the financial mechanism, with unresolved issues reportedly relating to the funding of mitigation and adaptation options.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
actors: Group of 77 and China|Environmental Integrity Group
abstract: Co-Chairs Gwage and Macey presented a draft COP/MOP 2 decision.

title: JOINT IMPLEMENTATION:
abstract: Parties met informally in the afternoon to consider two draft COP/MOP decisions prepared by the Co-Chairs.

title: INFORMATION ABOUT THE BASE YEAR OF KAZAKHSTAN:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Informal consultations concluded Monday with an agreement on draft conclusions that recall the COP earlier conclusion that Kazakhstan will become an Annex I party upon ratification for the purposes of the Protocol, while remaining a non-Annex I party under the Convention.

title: PROGRESS ON IMPLEMENTATION OF DECISION 1/CP.10:
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China
abstract: Co-Chair Churie-Kallhauge presented revised draft conclusions noting discussions at SBI 25 and that talks will continue at SBI 26, with a view to adopting a decision at COP 13.

title: SPECIAL CLIMATE CHANGE FUND:
abstract: Delegates discussed Chair Jallow draft conclusions, focusing on two options regarding the assessment of financed activities on economic diversification.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: Parties met in small group consultations throughout the day and in a contact group in the evening.

title: ADAPTATION PROGRAMME OF WORK:
abstract: In the early afternoon, Co-Chair Plume reported that timing issues addressed during morning and lunch time informals were still under consideration.

title: Protocol Article 3.2 (demonstrable progress)
abstract: Co-Chairs Bersee and Rolle convened their fourth and final round of informal consultations on the synthesis of reports in accordance with Protocol Article 3.2.

title: AWG ISSUES:
abstract: During informal consultations in the morning, Chair Zammit Cutajar circulated revised draft conclusions for discussion on further commitments for Annex I parties.

title: Convention
abstract: In a short contact group session on Monday morning, the G-77/CHINA reiterated its dissatisfaction on the exclusion of elements of its proposed text.

title: Protocol
abstract: During a morning contact group meeting, little progress was made, with much debate on the operational paragraphs.

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: Co-Chair Rosland reported on agreement reached during informal consultations and presented draft SBSTA conclusions.

title: EDUCATION, AWARENESS AND TRAINING (ARTICLE 6)
abstract: Informal consultations resulted in agreement on two SBI recommendations relating to Article 6 that will be forwarded for inclusion in the draft COP decision on additional guidance to the GEF.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
abstract: The contact group convened briefly in the evening to introduce the Co-Chairs  draft conclusions on the GEF's report to the COP; a draft decision on the review of the financial mechanism; and a draft decision on additional guidance to the GEF.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: In the morning, SBSTA adopted the agenda ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/6 ).

title: ADOPTION OF SBSTA 25 REPORT:
abstract: Conference Secretary Richard Kinley informed SBSTA of the financial implications of SBSTA 25 decisions and conclusions, and SBSTA adopted the report of the session ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.18 ).

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: Chair Becker reported agreement on a SIDS agenda item resulting in its inclusion under Other Matters.

title: UNFCCC ARTICLE 4.8 AND 4.9 (ADVERSE EFFECTS): Decision 1/CP.10 (response measures)
abstract: Angela Churie-Kallhauge (Sweden) reported on consultations, noting no agreement, and said that the outcomes of two expert meetings could be used as the basis of further discussion.

title: LDCs
abstract: SBI adopted conclusions on matters relating to the LDCs ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.23 ).

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: Harald Dovland (Norway) reported agreement during informal consultations to, inter alia , maintain current practices on travel for members of constituted bodies, and consider continuing review of the Secretariat at SB 27.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.14 (ADVERSE EFFECTS AND RESPONSE MEASURES):
abstract: Al Waleed Hamad Al-Malik (UAE) reported lack of agreement over whether the group should focus on substance or procedure, particularly whether to focus on a recent workshop or on proposals to merge this item with discussions under Protocol Article 2.3.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Henriette Bersee (Netherlands) reported agreement on the work of the Consultative Group of Experts on National Communications (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.25) and on provision of financial and technical support (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.24).

title: ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
abstract: Arthur Rolle (Bahamas) reported on small group negotiations on the synthesis of reports demonstrating progress in accordance with Protocol Article 3.2.

title: AMENDMENT OF PROTOCOL IN RELATION TO COMPLIANCE:
abstract: Chair Becker reported that the SBI had agreed to consider this at SBI 26 with a view to completing consideration at SBI 27.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSACTION LOG:
abstract: JAPAN expressed concerns regarding payment and timing of fees relating to this issue.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: Soobaraj Nayroo Sok Appadu (Mauritius) reported on agreement to consider revised UNFCCC reporting guidelines on global climate change observing systems at SBI 27, and advance the implementation of actions outlined in a regional workshop programme submitted by the GCOS secretariat.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
abstract: Paul Watkinson (France) reported discussions on procedural matters, and proposed continuing discussions in 2007.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Adrian Macey (New Zealand) reported agreement on a draft COP/MOP decision, saying it was a significant step forward in operationalizing the Fund.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
abstract: Third review of the financial mechanism: Tina Guthrie (Canada) reported on the outcomes of the contact group where delegates resolved the outstanding issue on the fourth review of the financial mechanism. SBI adopted conclusions and a draft COP decision ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.32 & Add.1).

title: GEF:
abstract: SBI adopted conclusions ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.30 ).

title: Additional guidance to the GEF
abstract: Tina Guthrie reported lack of agreement in the contact group as reflected in the draft conclusions ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.31 ).

title: SCCF:
abstract: Bubu Jallow (Gambia) reported on progress achieved in the contact group.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING: Convention
abstract: Crispin d'Auvergne (Saint Lucia) reported that the contact group had eventually agreed on conclusions and a draft COP decision (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.35 & Add.1), setting out steps to regularly monitor the implementation of capacity building.

title: Protocol
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The SBI adopted conclusions and a draft COP/MOP decision (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.34 & Add.1).

title: OTHER MATTERS:
abstract: Level of emissions for Croatia's base year: Jim Penman (UK) reported on the outcomes of informal consultations, and the SBI adopted the draft decision (FCCC/SBI/2006/L.20).

title: SIDS:
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: SBI adopted conclusions on SIDS ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.27 ).

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES:
abstract: Convention: SBSTA adopted conclusions on issues relating to greenhouse gas inventories under the Convention ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.20 & Add.1).

title: ADOPTION OF SBI 25 REPORT:
abstract: Conference Secretary Richard Kinley informed parties of the new financial implications of SBI 25 decisions and conclusions, and SBI adopted the report of the session ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.19 ).

title: AWG
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: AWG 2 convened for its closing plenary on Tuesday evening.

title: BELARUS PROPOSAL:
abstract: Thelma Krug (Brazil) chaired a second informal consultation on the Belarus proposal to amend Annex B by specifying a reduction commitment at 95% of its 1990 base year.

title: JOINT IMPLEMENTATION :
abstract: Informal discussions continued in the afternoon with disagreements reported on the issue of remuneration of JISC members.

title: Protocol: HCFC-22 and HFC-23
abstract: SBSTA adopted short conclusions ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.23 ) noting that the issue had not been resolved.

title: Issues relating to GHG inventories
abstract: SBSTA adopted conclusions and a draft COP/MOP decision (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.21 & Add.1).

title: REDUCING EMISSIONS FROM DEFORESTATION:
abstract: Hernán Carlino (Argentina) highlighted agreement on holding a second workshop.

title: PROGRESS REPORTS:
abstract: SBSTA adopted conclusions on the continuation of activities implemented jointly under the pilot phase, and a draft COP decision ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.19 & Add.1).

title: ADAPTATION PROGRAMME OF WORK:
abstract: Helen Plume (New Zealand) reported agreement on activities of the programme of work on adaptation up to 2008.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: Informal consultations on Tuesday resulted in agreement to extend EGTT's mandate and membership for one year, and to forward the draft negotiating texts to SBSTA 26.

title: UNFCCC DIALOGUE
abstract: Sandea De Wet (South Africa) opened the second workshop under the Dialogue, recalling the COP decision to keep the dialogue as informal as possible and calling for expanding the creative space.

title: RECENT DEVELOPMENTS ON ECONOMICS AND INVESTMENTS RELATING TO CLIMATE CHANGE:
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Nicholas Stern presented his review on the economics of climate change, which he identified as the biggest market failure the world has seen.

title: ADVANCING DEVELOPMENT GOALS IN A SUSTAINABLE WAY:
topics: Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Financial Mechanisms and Funds
abstract: Howard Bamsey (Australia) opened the afternoon session.

title: INFORMAL CONSULTATIONS CDM:
abstract: Discussions on the Co-Chairs draft COP/MOP decision remained deadlocked on a number of issues, including guidelines for the eligibility of afforestation/reforestation (A/R) projects, with differences between some developed and developing countries on the interpretation of COP 9 decisions.

title: Post-2012 issues
abstract: Many parties highlighted the urgency of agreeing on a post-2012 regime, with some stressing it should involve all major emitters, and others underscoring the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities.

title: CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT OF NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL RESPONSES:
abstract: Parties then exchanged views on concrete actions that would enable parties to continue to develop effective and appropriate national and international responses to climate change.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL ISSUES:
abstract: The Secretariat outlined the AR4 schedule, including a briefing for SB 26 on the three working groups reports, and the IPCC presentation of the AR4 synthesis report at COP 13.

title: CLOSE OF THE WORKSHOP:
abstract: Closing the meeting, Co-Facilitator Howard Bamsey said the next workshop under the Dialogue will focus on adaptation and vulnerability.

title: CDM :
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: T he contact group discussed a revised draft decision for COP/MOP 2, consisting of a preamble, general issues, and sections on governance, methodologies, regional distribution and capacity building, and resources for work on the CDM .

title: ARTICLE 9:
abstract: The review of the Protocol was taken up in consultations throughout the day, and in the evening as part of a ministerial meeting.

title: Adaptation
abstract: Many developing countries stressed adaptation.

title: COUNTRY STATEMENTS:
abstract: Parties reflected on various topics, including post-2012 issues, adaptation, CDM , forestry and financing.

title: Forestry
abstract: Several countries highlighted forests  contribution to addressing climate change, and positive incentives on deforestation.

title: Financial matters
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: Regarding the financial mechanism, NIUE appealed for improved modalities to access the GEF Trust Fund, while the PHILIPPINES said the GEF should be more responsive to developing country needs and opposed conditionalities in the operation of the climate funds.

title: CDM :
abstract: Many African countries lamented their disheartening share of CDM projects, calling for capacity building and technology transfer, and welcoming the Nairobi Framework.

title: UNFCCC DIALOGUE ADVANCING DEVELOPMENT GOALS IN A SUSTAINABLE WAY:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: Parties continued their discussions from Wednesday.

title: REALIZING THE FULL POTENTIAL OF MARKET-BASED OPPORTUNITIES:
abstract: ELECTRICITE DE FRANCE said the market approach should be articulated alongside other policies and measures, in a balanced manner.

title: OTHER PROCESSES AND INITIATIVES:
abstract: Elliot Diringer, Pew Center, outlined the key outcomes of a climate dialogue held at Pocantico, US, including support for: the involvement of major economies through a flexible UNFCCC framework; an integrated approach to meet more ambitious targets; and an informal dialogue outside the UNFCCC to help reach political consensus.

title: ELECTION OF THE BUREAU:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds 1|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: On Friday, 17 November, the COP elected officers other than the President.

title: REPORT ON THE DIALOGUE ON LONG-TERM COOPERATIVE ACTION UNDER THE CONVENTION
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: The second workshop of the Dialogue on long-term cooperative action to address climate change by enhancing implementation of the Convention took place on Wednesday and Thursday, 15 and 16 November.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
topics: National Communications and Inventories|Financial Mechanisms and Funds
abstract: Issues related to the financial mechanism of the Convention (FCCC/SBI/2006/11 Annex I, FCCC/CP/2006/3 and Corr.1, and FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.1) were introduced in SBI plenary on 7 November and subsequently addressed in contact groups and informal consultations from 8-14 November.

title: SCCF:
abstract: Discussions focused on finalizing guidance to the GEF on the SCCF's two remaining windows on sectoral activities and economic diversification.

title: Report of the GEF
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Implementation|Financial Mechanisms and Funds
abstract: In its report ( FCCC/CP/2006/3 ), the GEF highlighted climate change as the fourth replenishment's highest-ever allocation.

title: Additional guidance to the GEF
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer
abstract: Main issues discussed focused on: streamlining GEF procedures; enhanced country ownership of projects; increased support for adaptation and technology transfer; co-financing for adaptation projects; and implications of the RAF.

title: THIRD REVIEW OF THE FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: While developed countries expressed in general their satisfaction with the GEF's performance, many developing countries expressed numerous concerns relating to the resource allocation framework (RAF), conclusions of the Third Overall Performance Study of the GEF (OPS3), conditionalities of funding, and the replenishment process.

title: ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: This issue was taken up in SBI plenary on 6 November.

title: CONSULTATIVE GROUP OF EXPERTS ON NON-ANNEX I NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The SBI took up consideration of the work of the Consultative Group of Experts on National Communications from non-Annex I parties (CGE) in plenary on Monday, 6 November.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer
abstract: This item was introduced in the SBSTA plenary on 6 November, and then considered in informal consultations and contact group meetings co-chaired by Kunihiko Shimada (Japan) and Carlos Fuller (Belize).

title: THE KYOTO PROTOCOL:
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP 3 in Kyoto, Japan, agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries in transition to a market economy to achieve emissions reduction targets.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE CONVENTION:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: This issue was introduced in SBI plenary on 7 November, when the Secretariat reported on capacity-building implementation, the GEF's development of capacity-building performance indicators ( FCCC/SBI/2006/5 ; FCCC/SBI/2006/16 ; FCCC/SBI/2006/22) and parties  views on regular monitoring (FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.4, Corr.1 and Add.1).

title: INFORMATION ABOUT THE BASE YEAR OF KAZAKHSTAN
abstract: In the COP/MOP plenary on 6 November, Kazakhstan reported on its greenhouse gas emissions inventory, requesting that 1992 be adopted as the base year for determining quantitative commitments.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS
abstract: Issues under this agenda item were taken up in SBI plenary on 6 November, and then in informal consultations coordinated by Harald Dovland (Norway) from 7-11 November.

title: REPORTS OF THE SUBSIDIARY BODIES
abstract: On 17 November, the COP adopted the reports of the twenty-fifth sessions of the SBSTA ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.18 ) and the SBI ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.19 ).

title: Adaptation five-year programme of work
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: This issue was first presented to the COP plenary on 6 November, and addressed in a number of contact groups and informal consultations, co-chaired by Helen Plume (New Zealand) and Leon Charles (Grenada).

title: Reducing deforestation in developing countries
topics: forests|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: This issue was first presented to COP plenary on 7 November and addressed in contact group meetings, informal consultations and drafting group meetings, co-chaired by Audun Rosland (Norway) and Hernán Carlino (Argentina).

title: Research and systematic observation
abstract: This item was first introduced in the SBSTA plenary on 7 November.

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL ADVICE:
abstract: Issues addressed by SBSTA 25 related to the UNFCCC included the five-year programme of work on adaptation, reducing emissions from deforestation in developing countries, research and systematic observation, methodological issues, cooperation with other organizations, and progress reports on a number of relevant issues.

title: Emissions from fuel used for international aviation and maritime transport ( bunker fuels )
abstract: The item was introduced in SBSTA plenary on 7 November, followed by a report from the International Maritime Organization (IMO) on its work on emissions from international shipping.

title: Greenhouse gas inventories
abstract: On 7 November, the Secretariat presented the annual review of greenhouse gas inventories and updated inventory guidelines (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/INF.4; FCCC/SBSTA/2006/9 ) to the SBSTA plenary.

title: BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION:
abstract: The process for finalizing the rules and operational details of the Protocol was agreed at COP 4 in 1998 in a document known as the Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA).

title: Cooperation with other relevant organizations
abstract: On 10 November, SBSTA was briefed on the activities of the Joint Liaison Group, which will meet again in December 2006.

title: Progress reports
abstract: On 10 November, SBSTA considered progress reports on activities implemented jointly (AIJ) under the pilot phase (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/8 and Corr.1), with SBSTA Chair Kumarsingh noting suggestions that the pilot phase be extended.

title: Education, Training and Awareness (Convention Article 6)
abstract: The issue was first addressed during the SBI plenary on 7 November, and was then taken up in informal consultations chaired by Marie Jaudet (France).

title: OTHER MATTERS SIDS:
abstract: Proposed agenda items on issues relating to small island developing states were the subject of some discussion, with parties eventually agreeing that the item should be included under the SBI agenda item on other matters (see also the COP 12 section on Adoption of the Agenda ).

title: LEVELS OF EMISSIONS FOR THE BASE YEAR OF CROATIA:
abstract: The issue was introduced in SBI plenary on 6 November, and in informal consultations coordinated by Jim Penman (UK).

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
abstract: On organizational matters, President Kibwana noted some parties  concerns with an agenda item relating to consultations on the Russian proposal to develop appropriate procedures for the approval of voluntary commitments.

title: AD HOC WORKING GROUP ON ANNEX I COMMITMENTS
topics: Post-Kyoto Agreements|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: The Ad Hoc Working Group on Further Commitments for Annex I Parties under the Kyoto Protocol (AWG) was established by decision 1/CMP.1, to, inter alia , ensure that there is no gap between the first (2008-2012) and the second (post-2012) commitment periods in accordance with Protocol Article 3.9 (future commitments).

title: REVIEW OF THE PROTOCOL PURSUANT TO ARTICLE 9
actors: European Union|Umbrella Group|African Group|Group of 77 and China
abstract: This issue was first considered during the COP/MOP plenary on 9 November, and subsequently in contact groups and informal discussions chaired by Fernando Tudela Abad (Mexico).

title: RUSSIAN PROPOSAL TO DEVELOP PROCEDURES TO APPROVE VOLUNTARY COMMITMENTS
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: This issue was addressed in plenary on 9 and 13 November and in closed informal consultations throughout the meeting.

title: ISSUES RELATING TO THE CDM
actors: European Union|African Group|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|forests|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: Issues relating to the CDM were first taken up in the COP/MOP on 9 November, before being referred to a contact group co-chaired by Christiana Figueres (Costa Rica) and Georg Børsting (Norway).

title: MARRAKESH ACCORDS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation|Technology Transfer
abstract: In October and November 2001 at COP 7 in Marrakesh, Morocco, delegates reached agreement on the outstanding matters in the Marrakesh Accords.

title: REPORT OF THE JOINT IMPLEMENTATION SUPERVISORY COMMITTEE
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: This issue was first considered during the COP/MOP plenary on 9 November, and in contact groups and informal discussions co-chaired by Johan Nylander (Sweden) and William Agyemang-Bonsu (Ghana).

title: COMPLIANCE COMMITTEE
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The item was first introduced to the COP/MOP on 9 November.

title: AMENDMENT TO THE PROTOCOL RELATING TO COMPLIANCE
abstract: By its Decision 27/CMP.1, the COP/MOP invited the SBI to give further consideration to an amendment with respect to procedures and mechanisms relating to compliance, with a view to finalizing discussions at SBI 27.

title: ARTICLE 3.2 (DEMONSTRABLE PROGRESS)
actors: Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adaptation|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: This issue ( FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.2 and FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.7 ) was introduced in the SBI plenary on 8 November and then taken up in informal consultations coordinated by Henrià tte Bersee (Netherlands) and Arthur Wellington Rolle (Bahamas) from 8-14 November.

title: ADAPTATION FUND
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: This issue was taken up in SBI plenary on 8 November (FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.7 and Add.1, FCCC/SBI/2006/MISC.11 and MISC.16), and in a contact group co-chaired by Philip Gwage (Uganda) and Adrian Macey (New Zealand), which broke into informal consultations and small drafting groups.

title: ARTICLE 3.14
abstract: The issue of the adverse impacts of climate change and of response measures to climate change on developing countries under Protocol Article 3.14 was taken up in SBI plenary on 8 November, with a report on the outcomes of a workshop on reporting methodologies held in Abu Dhabi, UAE, from 4-6 September 2006 ( FCCC/SBI/2006/27 ).

title: ARTICLE 2.3
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: Matters relating to Protocol Article 2.3 (adverse effects of policies and measures) were first addressed in SBSTA on 8 November, when Japan identified overlaps with the item on Article 3.14 (see section above) and proposed integrating these items.

title: PROPOSAL FROM BELARUS TO AMEND ANNEX B OF THE PROTOCOL
abstract: A proposal to amend an annex to the Kyoto Protocol so as to allow Belarus to join the group of countries with emissions reduction commitments was the subject of lengthy negotiation during COP/MOP 2 .

title: SBI conclusions and a draft COP/MOP decision were adopted on 14 November, and the COP/MOP adopted the decision on 17 November. SBI Conclusions
abstract: On the request of the CDM Executive Board to allow its members business-class travel, SBI agrees ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.21 ), inter alia , to maintain current practices on travel for members of constituted bodies of the Protocol, also noting similar requests of the Compliance Committee and JISC. COP/MOP Decision : The decision ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.21/Add.2 ) contains sections on audited financial statements for 2004-2005, budget performance for 2006-2007, programme budget for 2008-2009, and implementation of the headquarters agreement.

title: BUDGET AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS:
abstract: This agenda item ( FCCC/SBI/2006/14 and Adds.1 and 2; FCCC/SBI/2006/15 and FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.6 ) was taken up in SBI plenary on 6 November, and then addressed jointly with COP-related administrative, financial and institutional matters in informal consultations coordinated by Harald Dovland (Norway) from 7-11 November.

title: COP 11 AND COP/MOP 1:
abstract: COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 took place in Montreal, Canada, from 28 November to 10 December 2005.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES FOR MEMBERS OF PROTOCOL BODIES :
abstract: This issue was first taken up by SBI on 8 November (FCCC/SBI/2006/20 and FCCC/SBI/2006/21 ).

title: REPORTS OF THE SUBSIDIARY BODIES
abstract: On 17 November, the COP/MOP adopted the reports of the twenty-fifth sessions of SBSTA ( FCCC/SBSTA/2006/L.18 ) and SBI ( FCCC/SBI/2006/L.19 ).

title: Methodological issues under the Protocol: HCFC-22/HFC-23
abstract: This issue was first addressed in plenary on 7 November, and in various informal consultations facilitated by Lambert Schneider (Germany).

title: Issues relating to greenhouse gas inventories
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The issue was taken up at SBSTA on 7 November, where the Secretariat presented results from a training programme for review experts under Protocol Article 8 (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/INF.7).

title: MANAGEMENT UNDER PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.4 FOR ITALY:
abstract: This issue was briefly taken up by COP/MOP 2 on 17 November, following informal consultations in May 2006 during SB 24.

title: HIGH-LEVEL SEGMENT
abstract: The joint high-level segment of COP 12 and COP/MOP 2 began on 15 November and concluded on 17 November.

title: OPENING OF THE MEETING:
abstract: Kivutha Kibwana, President of the COP and COP/MOP, opened the joint high-level segment.

title: Post-2012 issues
abstract: Many parties highlighted the urgency of agreeing on a post-2012 regime, with some stressing it should involve all major emitters, and others underscoring the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities.

title: Adaptation
abstract: Numerous parties urged a stronger focus on adaptation and the African Group and Saudi Arabia expressed disappointment at slow progress on technology transfer.

title: COUNTRY STATEMENTS:
abstract: Parties reflected on a wide range of issues, including various long-term issues relevant to what happens after the Protocol's first commitment period ends in 2012, as well as adaptation, CDM issues, forestry, and financial matters.

title: SB 24 AND AWG 1:
abstract: The twenty-fourth sessions of the Subsidiary Bodies and first session of the AWG were held in Bonn in May 2006.

title: Forestry
abstract: Several countries highlighted forests  contribution to addressing climate change, and positive incentives on deforestation.

title: Financial matters
abstract: Bangladesh, for the LDCs, highlighted microfinance and compensation for those impacted by climate change.

title: CDM:
abstract: Many African countries lamented their disheartening share of CDM projects, calling for capacity building and technology transfer, and welcoming the Nairobi Framework.

title: STATEMENTS FROM UN BODIES AND AGENCIES:
abstract: Statements from various UN bodies and specialized agencies reported on relevant work and linkages.

title: STATEMENTS BY OBSERVER ORGANIZATIONS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Extension of the Kyoto protocol|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: Many relevant NGOs and IGOs spoke during the high-level segment on behalf of business and industry, women's groups, youth, indigenous peoples and other key stakeholders.

title: DON'T FORGET THE ELEPHANTS WE ARE STILL IN AFRICA
abstract: According to one wit at the meeting, a couple of elephants escaped Kenya's national parks and were found in the Nairobi negotiating rooms - although most delegates were doing their best to ignore them.

title: COP 12 REPORT
actors: European Union|Umbrella Group|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Group of 77 and China
abstract: COP 12 opened on Monday morning, 6 November.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS ADOPTION OF THE RULES OF PROCEDURE:
abstract: Parties agreed to continue applying the draft rules of procedure with the exception of draft rule 42 on voting (FCCC/CP/1996/2).

title: ADOPTION OF THE AGENDA:
abstract: Parties considered the provisional agenda (FCCC/CP/2005/1), with the exception of the item on the second review of the adequacy of UNFCCC Article 4.2(a) and (b) (policies and measures on emissions and removals from sinks), which has been held in abeyance at every COP since COP 4.

title: Final Text:
abstract: The agreed text for this section notes evidence of recent warming, including increases in temperatures, widespread melting of snow and ice, and rising global mean sea level.

title: Final Text:
abstract: This short section explains the use and interpretation of long-term paleoclimatic information, suggesting that evidence from this source supports the view that the warmth of the last half century is unusual in at least the previous 1300 years and that the last time the polar regions were significantly warmer than present for an extended period (about 125,000 years ago), reductions in polar ice volume led to 4 to 6 meters of sea level rise.

title: Final text
abstract: This section notes that most of the observed increase in temperatures since the mid-20th Century is very likely (more than 90 percent probability) due to human activity.

title: Final text
abstract: This section finds that, for the next two decades, a warming of about 0.2 ºC per decade is projected, that many changes in the global climate system during the next century would very likely be larger than those observed in the past century, and that anthropogenic warming and sea level rise are expected to continue for centuries to come even if greenhouse gas concentrations were to be stabilized.

title: Final Text:
abstract: The final version of the text explains that WGI's contribution to the AR4 is to describe progress in understanding the drivers of climate change, observed climate change, climate process and attribution, and estimates of projected future climate change.

title: Final Text:
abstract: The final text confirms that global atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide have increased markedly as a result of human activities since 1750 and now far exceed pre-industrial values.

title: Water
abstract: On Wednesday, delegates discussed freshwater resources and their management.

title: Ecosystems
countries: United Kingdom|Saudi Arabia|Palau|Saint Lucia|Finland|France|United States|China|Russian Federation|Norway|Spain
abstract: On terrestrial carbon sinks, Norway proposed inclusion of nitrous oxide (N2O) and methane (CH4).

title: Coastal systems and low-lying areas
abstract: This sub-section was addressed on Wednesday evening and on Thursday.

title: Industry, settlement and society
abstract: This sub-section was considered on Wednesday.

title: Health
abstract: This sub-section was considered on Wednesday, with discussions focusing on reference to industrialized countries and the nature of the evidence.

title: Africa
abstract: This sub-section was considered on Wednesday night and Thursday.

title: Asia
abstract: This sub-section was considered on Wednesday and Thursday.

title: Australia and New Zealand
abstract: This section was considered late on Wednesday night without much discussion.

title: Europe
abstract: The section on Europe was discussed late on Wednesday night and on Thursday.

title: Latin America
abstract: This section was considered on Thursday morning.

title: North America
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: This section was considered on Thursday, with discussions focusing on its overall structure and specific questions about coastal areas, agriculture and extremes.

title: Polar Regions
abstract: This section was considered on Thursday morning.

title: Small Islands
countries: Canada|Sudan|Saint Lucia|France|United States|Belgium|Switzerland|Argentina|Mauritius|Saudi Arabia|Cuba|South Africa|United Kingdom|Austria|Germany|Russian Federation|Japan
abstract: The section on small islands was discussed on Thursday afternoon and was adopted without major debate.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text explains that Section C focuses on key findings concerning projected impacts in each system, sector and region for the range of (unmitigated) climate change projected by the IPCC over this century.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text on Section D on responding to climate change finds that some adaptation to observed and projected future climate change is occurring now, but on a limited basis.

title: Final Text
abstract: The final text of this short section on systematic observing and research needs indicates that although information has improved, WGII advice for further observation and research should be considered seriously.

title: Table on key impacts on sectors and systems (Table SPM-1)
topics: Reasons for Concern|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: A table containing information on key impacts, on sectors and systems was initially discussed in plenary on Monday evening, and subsequently in a contact group, co-chaired by Australia and Ghana.

title: Final Table
abstract: The final table highlights key impacts on the water, ecosystem, food, coast and health sectors/systems, including: hundred of millions of people being exposed to increased water stress; increased coral bleaching, increased damage from floods and storms, and increased mortality from heat waves.

title: Table on key impacts on regions
abstract: A table containing information on key impacts on regions was initially discussed in plenary on Monday evening, together with draft table SPM-1.

title: Extreme weather events impact table (Table SPM-2)
abstract: Delegates made editorial and other minor changes to a table noting possible impacts of climate change due to extreme weather events, including amendments to ensure consistency with WGI and clarifications of language used.

title: Final Table
abstract: The final table includes two columns from figure SPM-2 of WGI's contribution to AR4, and four columns with the examples of major projected impacts in: agriculture, forestry and ecosystems; water resources; human health; and industry/settlement/society.

title: Figure on observed changes (Figure SPM-1)
abstract: A figure on changes in physical and biological systems and surface temperature was first addressed in plenary on Monday.

title: Final Figure
abstract: The final figure depicts a world map noting significant observed changes in physical and biological systems, as well as observed temperature changes for the 1970-2004 period.

title: Final Text
abstract: This short section explains that WGII's contribution to the AR4 is to describe current scientific understanding of impacts of climate change on natural, managed and human systems, their capacity to adapt and their vulnerability.

title: Final Text
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Reasons for Concern
abstract: The final text explains that the focus of Section B is on the relationship between observed climate change and recent observed changes in the natural and human environment.

title: Government policies and instruments
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Technology Transfer
abstract: Discussion focused on creating incentives for mitigation, evaluation criteria, taxes and charges, voluntary agreements, information instruments and voluntary actions.

title: Table SPM 7 on sectoral policies, measures and instruments
abstract: Under the column for policies, measures and instruments shown to be environmentally effective, Brazil proposed, and delegates agreed, to insert reference to biofuel blend in the transport sector.

title: Box on uncertainty representation (Endbox 1)
abstract: This endbox, explaining uncertainty treatment in WGIII report, was initially included as an annex to the draft SPM, and discussed in the uncertainty contact group.

title: Figure SPM 1 on 1970-2004 global warming potential
topics: Reasons for Concern|IPCC Governance|forests|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Mitigation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Pre-Kyoto|Flexibility Mechanims|Technology Transfer
abstract: When discussing the figure informally, delegates debated the inclusion of gases covered by the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer.

title: Figures SPM 5a and SPM 5b on global economic potentials
topics: Pre-Kyoto|IPCC Governance|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: The final figures show global economic potential in 2030 estimated from both top-down and bottom-up studies.

title: Figure SPM 7 on emissions pathways of mitigation scenarios
topics: Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System|forests|Anthropogenic Interference with Climate System
abstract: The final figure presents emissions pathways for mitigation scenarios for different stabilization levels.

title: KYOTO PROTOCOL:
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP 3 in Kyoto, Japan, agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries in transition to a market economy to achieve emissions reduction targets.

title: BUENOS AIRES PLAN OF ACTION:
abstract: The process for finalizing the rules and operational details of the Protocol was agreed at COP 4 in 1998 in a document known as the Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA).

title: MARRAKESH ACCORDS:
abstract: In November 2001 at COP 7 in Marrakesh, Morocco, delegates reached agreement on the outstanding matters in the Marrakesh Accords.

title: COP 11 AND
abstract: COP/MOP 1 : COP 11 and COP/MOP 1 took place in Montreal, Canada, from 28 November to 10 December 2005.

title: COP 12 AND
abstract: COP/MOP 2 : Held in November 2006, in Nairobi, Kenya, COP 12 and COP/MOP 2 placed strong emphasis on discussions on long-term action and a framework following on from the Kyoto Protocol's first commitment period, which finishes in 2012.

title: OTHER MEETINGS:
abstract: As well as the IPCC and Security Council meetings, numerous other climate change-related events have been held since COP 12 and COP/MOP 2 .

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR IMPLEMENTATION
abstract: SBI Chair Bagher Asadi (Iran) opened the meeting.

title: IMPLEMENTATION OF UNFCCC ARTICLE 4.8 AND 4.9: LDCs:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: LDC Expert Group Chair Bubu Pateh Jallow (The Gambia) presented outcomes from the Group's 11 th meeting and on implementation of its work programme.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.14:
abstract: The Secretariat introduced the report on the workshop on reporting methodologies in the context of Article 3.14 (adverse effects and response measures) ( FCCC/SBI/2006/27 ).

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE PROTOCOL:
abstract: The Secretariat introduced this issue ( FCCC/SBI/2007/5 ).

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: SBSTA Chair Kishan Kumarsingh (Trinidad and Tobago) presented the provisional agenda ( FCCC/SBSTA/2007/1 ), which was adopted without amendment.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: The Secretariat reported on this issue (FCCC/SBSTA/2007/MISCs.6, 7 and 8; FCCC/SBSTA/2006/MISC.15).

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES UNDER THE CONVENTION:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: IPCC 2006 Guidelines for national greenhouse gas inventories: Chair Kumarsingh presented this topic, suggesting that issues other than reporting on harvested woodstocks should be concluded at this meeting (FCCC/SBSTA/2007/7 and Corr.1).

title: NAIROBI PROGRAMME OF WORK ON IMPACTS, VULNERABILITY AND ADAPTATION:
abstract: The Secretariat introduced this topic, highlighting upcoming workshops in Cairo and Rome (FCCC/SBSTA/2007/MISC.4 and Add.1; FCCC/SBSTA/2007/MISC.5). COOK ISLANDS and TUVALU urged an IPCC report on SIDS' adaptation.

title: MITIGATION:
abstract: On the scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of mitigation, Chair Kumarsingh noted that three workshops are scheduled during SB 26 on this topic, and said he will report back to plenary on 16 May.

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES UNDER THE PROTOCOL: HCFC-22/HFC-23
abstract: The EU suggested postponing discussion until policy options and an associated impact study are ready.

title: COOPERATION WITH RELEVANT INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS:
abstract: Yvo de Boer reported on the successful collaboration of the UNFCCC with IPCC, sister conventions and other UN agencies.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: Parties adopted the agenda ( FCCC/SBI/2007/1 ) and organization of work after agreeing to hold two sub-items in abeyance following requests for clarification from Pakistan, speaking for G-77/CHINA, and from SAUDI ARABIA.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: Chair Kumarsingh noted recent consultations in Tokyo and Beijing, and the Secretariat introduced relevant documents ( FCCC/SBSTA/2007/2 ; FCCC/SBSTA/2007/INF.1 ).

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: On reducing emissions from deforestation in developing countries ( FCCC/SBSTA/2007/3 , MISC.2 and Add.1, and MISC.3), many non-Annex I parties emphasized capacity building and the importance of forest resources in economic development and, with some Annex I parties, the need for early action, better data, and market mechanisms or a basket of market and non-market mechanisms.

title: OPENING STATEMENTS:
actors: European Union|Umbrella Group|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The G-77/CHINA urged agreement on the Adaptation Fund's management and operational entity.

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS:
abstract: On this item ( FCCC/SBI/2007/9 ), SAUDI ARABIA and NIGERIA, opposed by NORWAY and Micronesia, for AOSIS, said IPCC AR4 should be considered under SBSTA rather than COP 13 or COP/MOP 3.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: The Secretariat introduced the item on budget performance for 2006-2007 (FCCC/SBI/2007/INF.1 and INF.5).

title: ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The SBI took note of information on Annex I parties' fourth national communications ( FCCC/SBI/2007/INF.4 and FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.2 ).

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Lilian Portillo (Paraguay) reported on the work of the Consultative Group of Experts (CGE) on non-Annex I communications (FCCC/SBI/2007/3, 6, 7, 10 and Add.1).

title: EDUCATION, TRAINING AND PUBLIC AWARENESS:
abstract: Delegates discussed the New Delhi Work Programme relating to UNFCCC Article 6 ( FCCC/SBI/2007/MISC.3 and Add.1).

title: CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER THE CONVENTION:
abstract: JAPAN emphasized the need to avoid duplicating activities and the US said there was a more logical sequence of tasks than that set out in the Secretariat's report ( FCCC/SBI/2007/5 ).

title: ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS:
abstract: The Secretariat introduced the item on demonstrable progress on commitments under the Protocol (Article 3.2), and documents synthesizing reports from parties ( FCCC/SBI/2006/INF.2 and INF.4 ).

title: GREENHOUSE GAS INVENTORIES:
abstract: IPCC guidelines for national greenhouse gas inventories: Riitta Pipatti (Finland) and Nagmeldin Elhassan (Sudan) co-chaired this meeting, noting that harvested wood products will be dealt with separately on 10 May.

title: BUDGET :
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: On the proposed budget for 2008-2009, the Secretariat elaborated on issues relating to income generated by the share of proceeds from CDM projects, noting that CDM activities under the Kyoto Protocol were moved from the core budget to fee-based income.

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS :
abstract: Chair Berghäll outlined plans to include the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report (AR4) on COP 13 and COP/MOP 3 agendas and consider it during a joint high-level segment.

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: Co-Chairs Hernán Carlino (Argentina) and Audun Rosland (Norway) presented a SBSTA draft conclusion and COP draft decision prepared by SBSTA Chair Kumarsingh to serve as a basis for discussions.

title: FINANCIAL MECHANISM:
actors: African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The Secretariat introduced the item on the Adaptation Fund and a submission received from an institution interested in managing the Fund ( FCCC/SBI/2007/MISC.2 ).

title: COMPLIANCE AMENDMENT:
abstract: Regarding the item on amendment of the Kyoto Protocol in respect to procedures and mechanisms relating to compliance, Chair Asadi said he will prepare draft conclusions.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSACTION LOG:
abstract: The Secretariat briefed delegates on progress on implementation of the international transaction log (ITL), noting the development and deployment of the ITL software ( FCCC/SBI/2007/INF.3 ).

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: Privileges and immunities: The Secretariat introduced the item on privileges and immunities for individuals serving on constituted bodies established under the Kyoto Protocol ( FCCC/SBI/2007/MISC.4 and Add.1 ; FCCC/SBI/2006/21).

title: OTHER MATTERS:
abstract: ARGENTINA, supported by BRAZIL, objected to the UK's inclusion of Islas Malvinas/Falklands Islands and other South Atlantic islands in its national communications, citing sovereignty disputes.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 2.3:
abstract: Chair Kumarsingh invited parties to discuss a way forward on Article 2.3 (adverse effects of policies and measures.

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES (CONVENTION)
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Emissions from fuel used for international aviation and maritime transport: On the issue of bunker fuels, SAUDI ARABIA, opposed by NORWAY, the EU and AOSIS, proposed deleting this agenda item.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: Co-Chair Shimada introduced the text discussed at COP 12 (FCCC/SBSTA/2006/11 and FCCC/CP/2006/5/Add.1 ), noting agreement in Nairobi on the chapeau paragraphs and drawing attention to the bracketed sections yet to be agreed.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
abstract: In this contact group, Co-Chair Anaedu asked parties to submit text on eligibility criteria, priority areas and monetizing the share of proceeds.

title: BUDGET:
abstract: In the budget contact group, JAPAN, the US and the RUSSIAN FEDERATION favored a zero nominal increase.

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: During informal consultations in the morning and afternoon, parties continued their discussion of a draft COP decision prepared by SBSTA Chair Kumarsingh.

title: EDUCATION, TRAINING AND PUBLIC AWARENESS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In informal consultations, Chair Jaudet explained that the meeting was part of a process to develop a possible future strategic approach to this issue, and outlined the stages of this process.

title: IPCC GUIDELINES ON INVENTORIES:
abstract: In informal consultations on the IPCC 2006 Guidelines for national greenhouse gas inventories, parties discussed a summary text presented by the Co-Chairs, which includes sections on acknowledgment of the Guidelines, development of a process and work plan for implementation, methodological issues, use of the 2006 Guidelines on a voluntary basis and sharing experiences thereon, and harvested wood products.

title: PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES:
abstract: In a contact group on Wednesday morning, Chair Watkinson noted that during COP/MOP 2, parties had asked for more time to explore options and proposals.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
abstract: In this contact group, Co-Chair Castellari noted SBSTA 24's agreement to explore a more effective dialogue among parties and the research community that would contribute to the implementation of Decision 9/CP.11.

title: REFORESTATION UNDER THE CDM:
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: In this contact group, Co-Chair Krug noted divergent views as presented in submissions and plenary statements, and invited general comments on changes to the limit for small-scale afforestation and reforestation project activities.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: During informal consultations in the morning, Co-Chair Mahlung presented a Co-Chairs' draft COP decision, noting some minor corrections.

title: SBI
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Chair Asadi convened the SBI briefly on Thursday afternoon, notifying delegates of successful consultations on one of the issues left pending when the SBI's agenda was adopted on Monday, 7 May.

title: BUDGET:
abstract: In the budget contact group, the Secretariat presented three budget scenarios for parties to consider: a reduction scenario adjusted for real growth using a projected inflation rate of 1.65%; a reduction scenario of US$1 million; and a reduction scenario of US$1.755 million.

title: DEFORESTATION:
abstract: Discussions on reducing emissions from deforestation in developing countries continued in a small drafting group, facilitated by Greg Picker (Australia).

title: IPCC GUIDELINES FOR NATIONAL GREENHOUSE GAS INVENTORIES:
abstract: On Thursday morning, informal discussions on non-reporting issues related to harvested wood products (HWP) took place.

title: NON-ANNEX I NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Delegates continued informal discussions on two draft SBI conclusions, one on the work of the Consultative Group of Experts (CGE) on non-Annex I communications, and another on the provision of financial and technical support.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: Informal consultations were held in the morning.

title: SMALL-SCALE AFFORESTATION AND REFORESTATION UNDER THE CDM:
abstract: During an informal group meeting in the morning, Co-Chair Akahori presented draft SBSTA conclusions on the implications of possible changes to the limit for small-scale afforestation and reforestation CDM projects.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: In the morning, informal discussions resulted in agreement on a paragraph concerning the Secretariat's facilitation role and cooperation with relevant organizations.

title: ADAPTATION FUND:
abstract: During informal consultations, three different country groupings submitted text on eligibility criteria, priority areas and monetizing the share of proceeds.

title: WORKSHOP ON MITIGATION: URBAN PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern
abstract: SBSTA Chair Kumarsingh introduced this in-session workshop on the scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of mitigation, explaining that it would focus on urban planning and development, including transportation. UN-HABITAT focused on four aspects of urban planning: transportation, homes and office buildings, industrial production and poverty reduction.

title: BUDGET:
abstract: The Secretariat distributed a new tabulated budget proposal reflecting a 2.5% increase for the 2008-2009 biennium.

title: DECISION 1/CP.10:
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: In the morning, the contact group focused on the adverse effects of climate change.

title: DEFORESTATION:
