abstract: BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY underscored sectoral and market-based approaches and technological cooperation.

title: Flexible mechanisms
abstract: The sub-item on flexible mechanisms was taken up in plenary following informal consultations and a meeting of the contact group earlier in the day.

title: MEANS TO REACH EMISSION REDUCTION TARGETS:
abstract: On analysis of means to reach emission reduction targets, AWG-KP Chair Dovland presented conclusions (FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.4/Rev.1), highlighting new paragraphs on the flexible mechanisms and LULUCF.

title: Greenhouse gases, sectors and source categories
abstract: AWG-KP Chair Dovland reported on the contact group s work and delegates adopted the conclusions ( FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.6 ).

title: LULUCF:
abstract: In the plenary, Co-Chair Rocha reported on the contact group s work on LULUCF and invited parties to share information and ideas through the UNFCCC website to enable real progress in Accra.

title: METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES:
abstract: AWG-KP Chair Dovland reported on the contact group s work, identifying, inter alia , a sense that the Protocol should maintain the basket of gases approach.

title: MITIGATION:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Environmental Integrity Group
abstract: This issue was first taken up in plenary on 2 June, in conjunction with other elements of the agenda item on long-term cooperative action.

title: ADAPTATION:
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This issue was considered at an in-session workshop on advancing adaptation through finance and technology, from 2-3 June (for more details on this workshop, see: http://www.iisd.ca/vol12/enb12365e.html and http://www.iisd.ca/vol12/enb12366e.html ).

title: TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT AND TRANSFER:
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer
abstract: This issue was addressed at an in-session workshop on 3 June (for more details of the workshop, see: http://www.iisd.ca/vol12/enb12365e.html ).

title: AWG-LCA Conclusions
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/AWGLCA/2008/L.5 ), the AWG-LCA recalls an invitation to parties and observer organizations to provide additional information, views and proposals on paragraph one of the Bali Action Plan (the five key elements), and invites parties to submit specific textual proposals on paragraph one in order to focus consideration of the five elements by the AWG-LCA.

title: AWG-LCA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/AWGLCA/2008/L.4 ), the AWG-LCA confirms that four sessions of the AWG-LCA will be held in 2009, the first in March/April, the second in June in conjunction with the 30th sessions of the Subsidiary Bodies, the third in August/September, and the fourth from 30 November to 11 December, in conjunction with the 15th session of the Conference of the Parties.

title: FINANCIAL RESOURCES AND INVESTMENT:
actors: European Union|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This issue was addressed at an in-session workshop held on 5 June (for a more details on this workshop, see: http://www.iisd.ca/vol12/enb12368e.html ).

title: CLOSING PLENARY
actors: European Union|Umbrella Group|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Flexibility Mechanism|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The final AWG-LCA 2 plenary was held on Thursday afternoon, 12 June, when p arties adopted the report of the session (FCCC/AWGLCA/2008/L.3).

title: ANALYSIS OF MEANS TO REACH EMISSION REDUCTION TARGETS AND IDENTIFICATION OF WAYS TO ENHANCE THEIR EFFECTIVENESS AND CONTRIBUTION TO SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT
abstract: The analysis of means to reach emission reduction targets was a key agenda item for the AWG-KP in Bonn.

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its general conclusions on the means to reach emission reduction targets (FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.4), the AWG-KP, inter alia, agrees that its work on LULUCF activities under the project-based mechanisms must be informed by outcomes of its work on non-permanence and methodological issues related to LULUCF.

title: Clean Development Mechanism
abstract: Various proposals were made to expand the CDM s scope to include, inter alia, carbon capture and storage (CCS), nuclear activities, sectoral crediting and crediting based on nationally-appropriate mitigation actions.

title: KYOTO PROTOCOL:
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP 3 in Kyoto, Japan, agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries in transition to a market economy to achieve emission reduction targets.

title: Joint Implementation
abstract: Canada proposed considering modalities for parties to graduate from the CDM to joint implementation (JI).

title: Emissions Trading
abstract: Parties discussed linking emissions trading schemes and mutual acceptance (fungibility) of credits.

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
topics: forests|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Flexibility Mechanims|Technology Transfer
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.8), the AWG-KP, inter alia : agrees that its work on the mechanisms should not prejudge or limit other work by other bodies under the Convention and Protocol; agrees to continue its work on this issue, within its mandate and according to its work programme, with a view to adopting conclusions in Accra; and notes that a number of issues have been identified that may be considered for application during the current commitment period, and recommends that COP/MOP 4 may consider the Chair s list and take appropriate action.

title: EMISSIONS TRADING AND THE PROJECT-BASED MECHANISMS:
topics: Extension of the Kyoto protocol|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: Issues related to the flexible mechanisms were considered during the roundtable, and in a contact group and informal consultations co-chaired by Christiana Figures Olsen (Costa Rica) and Nuno Lacasta (Portugal) from 4-12 June.

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.5), the AWG-KP acknowledged that further discussions should take into account the principles that govern the treatment of LULUCF, as set out in decision 16/CMP.1.

title: LAND USE, LAND-USE CHANGE AND FORESTRY:
abstract: Issues related to LULUCF were considered during the roundtable and in a contact group and informal consultations co-chaired by Bryan Smith (New Zealand), and Marcelo Rocha (Brazil) from 4-11 June.

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.6 ), the AWG-KP, inter alia : notes that approaches targeting sectoral emissions could be used by Annex I parties as a means to reach, but not replace, their targets; and agrees to continue working on these issues so that conclusions can be adopted at the first part of AWG-KP 6 in Accra.

title: SECTORAL APPROACHES, AND GREENHOUSE GASES, SECTORS AND SOURCE CATEGORIES:
abstract: These topics were considered during the roundtable, and a contact group and informal consultations on other issues chaired by AWG-KP Chair Dovland from 4-12 June.

title: CONSIDERATION OF RELEVANT METHODOLOGICAL ISSUES
abstract: In Bonn, the AWG-KP initiated work on relevant methodological issues, including the methodologies to be applied for estimating anthropogenic emissions and the GWPs of greenhouse gases.

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.7 ), the AWG-KP, inter alia , takes note of the summary of views at the workshop on relevant methodological issues (FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/MISC.3), and agrees to continue its work so that conclusions can be adopted at the first part of AWG-KP 6 in Accra.

title: COP 11 AND COP/MOP 1:
abstract: COP 11 and the first Conference of the Parties serving as the Meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol (COP/MOP 1) took place in Montreal, Canada, from 28 November to 10 December 2005.

title: CLOSING PLENARY
abstract: AWG-KP 5 s closing plenary took place on Thursday evening, 12 June.

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL ADVICE
abstract: The twenty-eighth session of the Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice (SBSTA 28) was opened by Chair Helen Plume (New Zealand) on Wednesday, 4 June.

title: NAIROBI WORK PROGRAMME ON ADAPTATION
topics: Legal Status of Agreements|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: The Nairobi Work Programme on impacts, vulnerability and adaptation to climate change (NWP), which was finalized at COP 12 in 2006, establishes a five-year programme of work on the scientific, technical and socioeconomic aspects of impacts, vulnerability and adaptation to climate change.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/L.13/Rev.1), the SBSTA requests the Secretariat to prepare, before SBSTA 29, technical papers: on the implications of physical and socioeconomic trends in climate-related risks and extreme events for sustainable development; and on integrating practices, tools and systems for climate risk assessment and management and disaster risk reduction strategies into national policies and programmes.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: This agenda item was first taken up in plenary on Wednesday, 4 June, and subsequently in a contact group, co-chaired by Carlos Fuller (Belize) and Kunihiko Shimada (Japan).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Technology Transfer
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/208/L.4), the SBSTA, inter alia : endorses the EGTT s 2008-2009 rolling work programme; notes the heavy workload of the EGTT and invites the EGTT to adjust its programme of work if so requested by the subsidiary bodies; endorses the terms of reference for the EGTT to develop a set of performance indicators on the effectiveness of the implementation of the technology transfer framework; endorses the terms of reference for the EGTT for identifying and analyzing financial resources for technology transfer; welcomes progress in the update of the Technology Needs Assessments guidelines; and requests the Secretariat to organize to EGTT meetings prior to SBSTA 29.

title: REDUCING EMISSIONS FROM DEFORESTATION IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
abstract: This issue was first taken up by the SBSTA plenary on 4 June, when the Secretariat introduced the relevant documents (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/MISC.4 & Adds.1-2).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/L.12), the SBSTA identified the main methodological issues that could be included in its report to COP 14.

title: RESEARCH AND SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATION
abstract: This issue was taken up at SBSTA 28 in light of previous discussions at SBSTA 26, when parties had agreed to develop and maintain a dialogue with regional and international climate change research programmes and organizations, and to invite these groups to keep the SBSTA informed about relevant research activities.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/SBSTA/2008/L.5 ), the SBSTA expresses its appreciation for the briefings provided during the informal discussion on 5 June, and emphasizes the usefulness of further enhancing the dialogue with relevant organizations.

title: AWG-KP AND CONVENTION DIALOGUE:
abstract: Between COP 11 and COP 13 in December 2007, the newly-established AWG-KP and Convention Dialogue each convened four times.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/L.7), the SBSTA, among other things: agreed that the work carried out has established robust methodologies to quantify historical contributions to climate change; noted that there are uncertainties in the underlying historical emissions data, in particular from land-use change and forestry; noted that results of the work may be relevant to the work of parties under other bodies and within other processes under the Convention and its Kyoto Protocol; and concluded its consideration of this issue.

title: SCIENTIFIC AND METHODOLOGICAL ASPECTS OF THE PROPOSAL BY BRAZIL :
abstract: Parties considered written reports on the scientific and methodological aspects of the proposal by Brazil, which seeks to explore historical contributions of emissions sources to climate change.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/208/L.8), the SBSTA, inter alia : notes views by parties on work by the IMO and ICAO; agrees to continue to receive information from IMO and ICAO during the next three sessions; and agrees to further consider the issue at SBSTA 32.

title: EMISSIONS FROM INTERNATIONAL AVIATION AND MARITIME TRANSPORT:
abstract: This agenda item was first taken up in the SBSTA plenary on Wednesday, 4 June, with presentations by the International Maritime Organization (IMO) and International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) ( FCCC/SBSTA/2008/MISC.9 ) on their work on the issue.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/L.2), the SBSTA agrees to continue its consideration of this issue at its twenty-ninth session.

title: HCFC-22 / HFC-23
abstract: The establishment of new HCFC-22 facilities seeking to obtain Certified Emission Reductions under the CDM for the destruction of HFC-23 was addressed in informal SBSTA consultations facilitated by Jeffrey Spooner (Jamaica).

title: CARBON CAPTURE AND STORAGE UNDER THE CDM:
actors: European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This agenda item (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/INF.1) was first taken up in SBSTA plenary on Wednesday, 4 June.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/L.11), the SBSTA requests the Secretariat to integrate the formulas into the Common Reporting Format Reporter module.

title: LULUCF GOOD PRACTICE UNDER PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.3 AND 3.4:
abstract: This issue was addressed briefly in plenary on 4 June, and then in informal SBSTA consultations co-facilitated by Anke Herold (European Community), and Nagmeldin Elhassan (Sudan).

title: MITIGATION
abstract: This agenda item (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/MISC.6) was first taken up in SBSTA plenary on Wednesday, 4 June.

title: BALI CLIMATE CONFERENCE:
abstract: COP 13 and COP/MOP 3 took place from 3-15 December 2007, in Bali, Indonesia, alongside the resumed fourth session of the AWG-KP.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/208/L.9), the SBSTA recognizes that negotiations under the Bali Action Plan address mitigation and agree to consider the issue at SBSTA 33, taking into account the best available scientific information, particularly from the IPCC.

title: POLICIES AND MEASURES
abstract: The issue of policies and measures of Annex I parties had been considered at several previous SBSTA sessions, with little progress reported.

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/L.3), the SBSTA notes that parties have already addressed some aspects of this matter in the context of other SBSTA and SBI agenda items, and that the issue is also being considered by the AWG-KP and AWG-LCA.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 2.3
abstract: The SBSTA agenda item on Protocol Article 2.3 (adverse effects of policies and measures) has been the subject of dispute at previous SBSTA sessions, particularly over whether the issue should be considered along with Protocol Article 3.14 (adverse effects and response measures).

title: SBSTA Conclusions
abstract: There were no separate conclusions on this matter.

title: COOPERATION WITH RELEVANT INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS
abstract: This issue was taken up briefly during the opening SBSTA plenary on 4 June, when UNFCCC Executive Secretary Yvo de Boer and representatives of other UN bodies commented on UN system-wide climate change activities and cooperation, including the IPCC s Fourth Assessment Report (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/MISC.2).

title: CLOSING PLENARY
abstract: In the closing plenary on Friday morning, 13 June, the SBSTA adopted 12 conclusions and its report of the session (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/L.1).

title: SUBSIDIARY BODY FOR IMPLEMENTATION
abstract: The twenty-eighth session of the Subsidiary Body for Implementation (SBI 28) was opened by Chair Bagher Asadi (Iran) on Wednesday morning, 4 June.

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: Chair Asadi introduced the agenda and organization of work ( FCCC/SBI/2008/1 ), and suggested leaving a sub-item on information contained in national communications from non-Annex I parties in abeyance until SBI 29 in December 2008.

title: NON-ANNEX I COMMUNICATIONS
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Three issues were listed under the draft agenda in relation to non-Annex I national communications: the work of the Consultative Group of Experts (CGE); information contained in non-Annex I communications; and the provision of financial and technical support.

title: AWG-LCA 1 AND AWG-KP 5:
abstract: The first session of the AWG-LCA and first part of the fifth session of the AWG-KP took place from 31 March to 4 April 2008 in Bangkok, Thailand.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.9), the SBI decides to continue consideration of the issue at SBI 29 based on an annex containing a bracketed draft COP decision and terms of reference.

title: CONSULTATIVE GROUP OF EXPERTS:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Discussions focused on the review of the mandate and terms of reference of the CGE, as required by decision 3/CP.8 (CGE on non-Annex I communications).

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.10), the SBI recognizes that the information in document FCCC/SBI/2008/INF.3/Rev.1 is incomplete, and invites the GEF to provide information, which should be detailed and complete, to COP 14.

title: FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT:
topics: Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The main issues discussed under this sub-item were access to funding for preparation of non-Annex I national communications and information on financial support provided by the GEF for the preparation of non-Annex I communications ( FCCC/SBI/2008/INF.3/Rev.1 ).

title: REPORTING AND REVIEW OF INFORMATION FROM ANNEX I PARTIES THAT ARE PARTIES TO THE KYOTO PROTOCOL
abstract: This issue focused on the review of initial reporting by Annex I parties to establish their assigned amounts under the Protocol and determine their eligibility to participate in the flexible mechanisms.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.5), the SBI, inter alia :recalls its conclusions from SBI 27 that the review process needs further strengthening; urges parties to ensure effective reporting and review processes under the Convention and Protocol; and invites submissions by 19 September 2008 on experiences and lessons learned from the review process.

title: FOURTH REVIEW OF THE FINANCIAL MECHANISM
abstract: The fourth review of the financial mechanism was first addressed in plenary on 5 June (FCCC/SBI/2008/MISC.3 and Add.1) and in informal consultations facilitated by Tina Guthrie (Canada) and Bubu Jallow (Gambia).

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: In the conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.11), the SBI notes the submissions from parties; requests the Secretariat to provide, upon request, information to non-Annex I parties on the assessment of financing needs to implement mitigation and adaptation measures; and decides to continue consideration at its 29th session on the basis of the draft text contained in the annex.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.12), the SBI agrees on a list of actions that could be carried out to further implement decision 1/CP.10, divided into actions on the adverse effects of climate change, and actions on the impact of the implementation of response measures.

title: PROGRESS ON IMPLEMENTING DECISION 1/CP.10
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This agenda item ( FCCC/SBI/2008/MISC.4 ) was first taken up in plenary on 4 June and then in contact groups and informal consultations chaired by Leon Charles (Grenada).

title: REPORT OF THE MEETINGS
actors: European Union|Umbrella Group|Least Developed Countries|Group of 77 and China|Group of 77 and China
topics: Legal Status of Agreements|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The second session of the Ad Hoc Working Group on Long-term Cooperative Action (AWG-LCA 2) under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change began on Monday, 2 June.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/SBI/2008/L.2 ), the SBI endorses the work programme of the LEG for 2008-2010, welcomes the submission of 34 NAPAs and encourages parties who had not submitted their NAPAs to do so.

title: MATTERS RELATING TO THE LEAST DEVELOPED COUNTRIES:
abstract: On 4 June delegates heard a report from the Chair of the LDC Expert Group (LEG) on the 13th meeting of the LEG ( FCCC/SBI/2008/6 ).

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER
abstract: Technology transfer was taken up by the SBI, SBSTA and the AWG-LCA.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBSTA/208/L.7), the SBI, inter alia : endorses the EGTT rolling programme of work; requests the SBI Chair to prepare draft terms of reference for the review and assessment of the effectiveness of the implementation of Convention Articles 4.5 and 4.1(c) (technology transfer), taking into consideration submissions by parties, relevant work by the EGTT and deliberations by parties at SBSTA 28; notes that the EGTT performance indicators should be used as one of the tools for the review; notes the report by the GEF on a strategic programme, encourages the GEF to consider the concerns of parties, and looks forward to a further GEF report at SBI 29 outlining a programme that fully addresses COP requests; and invites the GEF to consider the AWG-LCA and the EGTT s work on finance when further elaborating the strategic programme.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING FOR DEVELOPING COUNTRIES UNDER THE CONVENTION
abstract: Capacity building under the Convention ( FCCC/SBI/2008/6 ) was first considered in plenary on 4 June.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.4), the SBI endorses the terms of reference for the second comprehensive review, requests parties to submit to the Secretariat information on their experiences in monitoring and evaluating capacity building at the national level by 15 August 2008, and requests any additional or updated information and views by 13 February 2009; and recommends a draft COP decision.

title: CAPACITY BUILDING FOR DEVELOPING COUNTRIES UNDER THE PROTOCOL
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Implementation|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: This issue ( FCCC/SBI/2008/6 ) was first taken up in plenary on 4 June.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: The SBI conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.8) under this agenda item are similar to those on capacity building under the Convention.

title: PROTOCOL ARTICLE 3.14
abstract: The SBI agenda item on Protocol Article 3.14 (adverse effects of climate change and impact of response measures) has been the subject of dispute at previous sessions, particularly over whether the issue should be considered along with SBSTA considerations of Protocol Article 2.3 (adverse effects of policies and measures).

title: COMPLIANCE
abstract: This issue was taken up by the SBI plenary on 4 June.

title: ENABLING THE FULL, EFFECTIVE AND SUSTAINED IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CONVENTION THROUGH LONG-TERM COOPERATIVE ACTION
abstract: Delegates spent most of the meeting in discussions on this agenda item.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR SECOND REVIEW OF THE PROTOCOL UNDER ARTICLE 9
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure
abstract: This issue (FCCC/KP/SBI/2008/INF.1 and MISC.2 & Adds.1-3) was considered by the SBI plenary on 4 June, and during informal consultations facilitated by Adrian Macey (New Zealand) and Ana Maria Kleymeyer (Argentina) from 6-13 June.

title: SBI Conclusions
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/KP/SBI/2008/L.14), the SBI, inter alia: recalls that the second review shall aim to further enhance the Protocol s implementation and shall not prejudge action by the COP/MOP and lead to new commitments for any party; recalls that preparations need to be streamlined with other relevant activities to avoid duplication of work; recommends that the COP/MOP address issues among those identified in preparing for the second review on which decisions could be adopted by the COP/MOP 4, and identify issues that require further consideration and refer them to the appropriate body; and recommends that the COP/MOP give attention in particular to the issues listed in decision 4/CMP.3.

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR INTERGOVERNMENTAL MEETINGS
abstract: The agenda item on arrangements for intergovernmental meetings was first taken up by the SBI in plenary on 4 June ( FCCC/SBI/2008/4 and Add.1 ).

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.13), the SBI notes parties concerns about time management at COP 14 and COP/MOP 4 due to the workload.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.6) the SBI urges parties to make voluntary contributions to the budget to help cover the shortfall and requests the Executive Secretary to take into consideration ways to minimize the effects of exchange rate fluctuations when considering the next budget.

title: BUDGET PERFORMANCE FOR THE BIENNIUM 2008-2009:
abstract: In the opening SBI plenary on 4 June, the Secretariat introduced this agenda item ( FCCC/SBI/2008/3 & INF.6 ), highlighting the US$6 million shortfall due to the depreciating US dollar.

title: SBI Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/SBI/2008/L.3), the SBI, inter alia , takes note of the statement made by the representative of the host government confirming that construction work for the new conference facilities and offices are scheduled to be completed by 2010 and 2011, respectively.

title: IMPLEMENTATION OF THE HEADQUARTERS AGREEMENT:
abstract: The item generated little discussion and the SBI plenary adopted conclusions drafted by the Chair Asadi on 13 June.

title: OTHER MATTERS
abstract: On 4 June during the opening plenary, the Philippines, for the G-77/China, raised the operationalization of the Adaptation Fund as an issue on which it was seeking further discussion.

title: CLOSING PLENARY
abstract: The SBI held its closing plenary on Friday afternoon, 13 June.

title: A SHARED VISION FOR LONG-TERM COOPERATIVE ACTION:
actors: Environmental Integrity Group|African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: This issue was addressed in an AWG-LCA contact group on 9 June.

title: PROCEDURAL COMPLEXITY: AGENDA FORMATION AND PROLIFERATION
abstract: Agenda proliferation is a complaint as old as the Convention itself.

title: SIGNS OF SUBSTANTIVE COMPLEXITY
topics: Extension of the Kyoto protocol|Flexibility Mechanims
abstract: In Bonn, delegates were given a taste of the substantive complexity surrounding the issues they will be trying to finalize in Copenhagen.

title: COMPLEXITY AHEAD: DELEGATES ARE HUMAN
abstract: As delegates departed Bonn and started thinking about Accra, many commented on the amount of work at hand and the logistical and human implications.

title: WHY MANAGING COMPLEXITY MATTERS
abstract: In themselves, the Bonn meetings are not likely to feature prominently in the annals of history, or even those of the climate change negotiations.

title: AWG-LCA:
abstract: The AWG-LCA has a mandate to launch a comprehensive process to enable the full, effective and sustained implementation of the Convention through long-term cooperative action, now, up to and beyond 2012.

title: Flexible mechanisms
abstract: In Bonn, a workshop was held on the topic, with many parties voicing support for continuing the mechanisms after 2012.

title: AWG-KP:
abstract: The AWG-KP is taking up an analysis of the means available to reach emission reduction targets and identification of ways to enhance their effectiveness and contribution to sustainable development.

title: Sectoral approaches
abstract: Developing countries have stressed that sectoral approaches should apply only to Annex I parties, and should supplement rather than replace national caps on emissions.

title: LULUCF:
abstract: Differences remain among parties on the rules that might be applied for the second commitment period.

title: THE ACCRA NEGOTIATIONS
abstract: The climate change talks in Accra represent one in an ongoing series of meetings leading up to Copenhagen in December 2009 - the deadline for an agreement on a post-2012 framework.

title: Shared vision
abstract: This issue was the subject of considerable discussion in Bonn in June.

title: Mitigation
abstract: In Bonn, discussions on mitigation centered on measuring, reporting and verifying commitments or actions, sectoral approaches and reducing emissions from deforestation and degradation in developing countries (REDD).

title: Adaptation
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Post-Kyoto Agreements|Adaptation|Technology Transfer
abstract: Discussions on adaptation issues in Accra will focus on technology transfer and financing.

title: Technology and financing
abstract: In Bonn, two in-session workshops were held on technology development and transfer, and on financing.

title: WELCOMING CEREMONY
abstract: Kwadwo Adjei-Darko, Minister of Local Government, Rural Development and Environment, Ghana, welcomed delegates to Accra, describing the talks as an important milestone on the path to Copenhagen and an opportunity to demonstrate the seriousness of current efforts to address climate change.

title: AWG-KP
abstract: AWG-KP Chair Harald Dovland (Norway) opened AWG-KP 6, informing delegates that he would conduct informal consultations throughout the week on the 2009 work programme.

title: OPENING STATEMENTS:
actors: African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Antigua and Barbuda, for the G-77/CHINA, stressed the importance of limiting discussions to issues related to further quantified commitments for Annex I countries.

title: ANALYSIS OF MEANS TO REACH EMISSION REDUCTION TARGETS:
abstract: AWG-KP Chair Dovland introduced documents ( FCCC/TP/2008/2 and Corr.1; FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/3 ; and FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/INF.2 ).

title: LULUCF:
abstract: Marcelo Rocha and Bryan Smith co-chaired the contact group on LULUCF.

title: AWG-LCA
abstract: AWG-LCA Chair Luiz Machado (Brazil) opened the session, emphasizing the need for parties to focus on concrete ideas and proposals, and to identify common views.

title: CONSIDERATION OF A WORK PROGRAMME FOR 2009:
abstract: Chair Machado and AWG-LCA Vice-Chair Michael Zammit Cutajar (Malta) will hold informal consultations with a view to reaching agreement on the work programme for 2009.

title: LONG-TERM COOPERATIVE ACTION:
topics: Legal Status of Agreements|Post-Kyoto Agreements|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning
abstract: The Secretariat introduced documents ( FCCC/AWGLCA/2008/MISC.2 and FCCC/AWGLCA/2008/MISC.4 ) containing submissions from parties on ideas and proposals on the elements contained in paragraph 1 of the Bali Action Plan and on the Convention workshops scheduled for 2008, respectively.

title: WORKSHOP ON SECTORAL APPROACHES AND SECTOR-SPECIFIC ACTIONS:
actors: European Union|Least Developed Countries|Group of 77 and China
abstract: Chair Machado informed delegates that previous discussions on the topic are summarized in documents (FCCC/AWGLCA/2008/6 and 11 ), and invited parties to make presentations on this issue.

title: WORKSHOP ON SECTORAL APPROACHES AND SECTOR-SPECIFIC ACTIONS:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Delegates reconvened in the workshop, where they continued to present their views.

title: WORKSHOP ON REDD, CONSERVATION AND SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds 2|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|forests|Compliance and Enforcement|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: AWG-LCA Chair Luiz Machado opened the workshop and SBSTA Chair Helen Plume presented on progress made during SBSTA 28 and the outcome of the recent UNFCCC Workshop on Methodological Issues Relating to REDD.

title: LULUCF:
abstract: Co-Chairs Rocha and Smith chaired the contact group on LULUCF.

title: FLEXIBLE MECHANISMS:
abstract: The contact group, co-chaired by Figueres and Lacasta, met twice on Friday.

title: OTHER ISSUES:
abstract: The group, chaired by AWG-KP Chair Dovland, discussed the inclusion of new gases and relevant methodologies.

title: LONG-TERM COOPERATIVE ACTION:
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Adaptation|Legal Status of Agreements|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|Post-Kyoto Agreements|forests|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: Delegates convened in an AWG-LCA plenary and considered the organization of work.

title: ADAPTATION AND MEANS OF IMPLEMENTATION:
actors: African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: AWG-LCA Vice-Chair Cutajar opened the contact group and suggested that the discussion focus on national planning for adaptation and enhancement of knowledge sharing.

title: MITIGATION AND MEANS OF IMPLEMENTATION:
abstract: The contact group chaired by AWG-LCA Chair Machado met in the afternoon.

title: OTHER ISSUES (SPILLOVER EFFECTS)
actors: African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: AWG-KP Chair Dovland chaired the contact group.-¯South Africa, for the G-77/CHINA, stated that consideration of spillover effects should focus on non-Annex I parties .

title: FLEXIBLE MECHANISMS:
abstract: Co-Chairs Lacasta and Figueres convened the contact group and introduced an updated list, classifying possible improvements to the mechanisms based on, inter alia , whether or not they have potentially significant implications for the ability of Annex I parties to meet emission reduction targets.

title: LULUCF:
abstract: During informal consultations, parties sought to clarify their positions and specify details of the set of accounting options on the table.

title: DELIVERING ON TECHNOLOGY AND FINANCE:
abstract: The contact group, chaired by AWG-LCA Chair Machado, met in the morning.

title: MITIGATION AND MEANS OF IMPLEMENTATION:
actors: African Group|Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: The contact group was chaired by AWG-LCA Chair Machado.

title: ADAPTATION AND MEANS OF IMPLEMENTATION:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: AWG-LCA Vice-Chair Cutajar invited parties to focus on institutional frameworks for adaptation, as well as streamlining and scaling up financial and technological support.

title: 2009 WORK PROGRAMME:
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Mitigation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: During informal consultations, AWG-LCA Chair Machado observed that the 2008 programme had centered on exchanging ideas, but that the focus in 2009 should be on negotiating.

title: FLEXIBLE MECHANISMS:
abstract: In the afternoon and evening, Co-Chairs Figueres and Lacasta convened two contact groups to discuss the Chairs draft text.

title: LULUCF:
abstract: During informal consultations, parties discussed the new Chairs text on possible options for amendments to LULUCF definitions, modalities, rules and guidelines and began to draft conclusions.

title: OTHER ISSUES:
abstract: Parties met in informal consultations to discuss draft conclusions prepared by AWG-KP Chair Dovland.

title: MITIGATION AND MEANS OF IMPLEMENTATION:
abstract: The contact group, chaired by AWG-LCA Chair Machado, convened in the morning.

title: ADAPTATION AND MEANS OF IMPLEMENTATION:
actors: European Union|African Group|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: AWG-LCA Vice-Chair Cutajar opened the session ARGENTINA described various low and no-cost adaptation options, such as knowledge sharing and global or regional information clearing houses.

title: DELIVERING ON TECHNOLOGY AND FINANCE:
actors: European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The contact group was chaired by AWG-LCA Chair Machado.

title: 2009 WORK PROGRAMME:
abstract: During informal consultations, AWG-LCA Chair Machado presented draft text, stating that he would prepare a document assembling ideas and proposals on the elements of the Bali Action Plan.

title: LULUCF:
abstract: During informal consultations, Co-Chair Rocha introduced the changes to the new draft annex.

title: FLEXIBLE MECHANISMS:
abstract: Co-Chair Figueres convened the contact group and explained that friends of the Chair consultations had resulted in agreement on the need for further elaboration on the lists of possible improvements to the flexible mechanisms, as well as on the utility of additional input from parties, and, in turn, requested submissions on a voluntary basis before 17 October.

title: LULUCF:
abstract: Co-Chairs Rocha and Smith chaired the final contact group on LULUCF.

title: OTHER ISSUES:
abstract: In informal consultations and friends of the Chair discussions, parties worked to draft conclusions on the other issues agenda items.

title: MITIGATION AND MEANS OF IMPLEMENTATION:
actors: Umbrella Group|African Group|Group of 77 and China
abstract: Issues related to mitigation and associated means of implementation were introduced in plenary on 21 August, and discussed in two in-session workshops, on sectoral approaches and sector-specific actions and on REDD, conservation and sustainable forest management, on 21-22 August (for more details on these workshops, see: http://www.iisd.ca/vol12/enb12378e.html and http://www.iisd.ca/vol12/enb12379e.html ).

title: ADAPTATION AND MEANS OF IMPLEMENTATION:
actors: European Union|African Group|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts
abstract: This item was introduced in plenary on Saturday, 23 August.

title: AWG-LCA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/AWGLCA/2008/L.7 ) on the agenda item on long-term cooperative action, the AWG-LCA invites its Chair to prepare a document assembling the ideas and proposals presented by parties on the elements contained in paragraph 1 of decision 1/CP.13 (the Bali Action Plan).

title: AWG-LCA Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/AWGLCA/2008/L.8 ), the AWG-LCA determines that it will shift into full negotiating mode in 2009, advancing negotiation on all elements of the Bali Action Plan; and calls on parties to put forward proposals on the content and form of the outcome to be agreed at COP 15, to enable parties to review and assess the scope and progress of negotiations at AWG-LCA 6 in June 2009.

title: DELIVERING ON TECHNOLOGY AND FINANCE:
abstract: Issues related to this item were introduced in plenary on Thursday, 21 August, and discussed in a contact group chaired by AWG-LCA Chair Machado.

title: CLOSING PLENARY
actors: African Group|Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: The AWG-LCA closing plenary was convened on Wednesday afternoon, 27 August, at 4:00 pm by AWG-LCA Chair Machado, who reported on deliberations of the contact groups on mitigation and associated means of implementation and on delivering on technology and financing, including consideration of institutional arrangements.

title: ANALYSIS OF MEANS TO REACH EMISSION REDUCTION TARGETS AND IDENTIFICATION OF WAYS TO ENHANCE THEIR EFFECTIVENESS AND CONTRIBUTION TO SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT
abstract: This agenda item was introduced in plenary on Thursday, 21 August, and then taken up in the aforementioned contact groups and informal consultations.

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its general conclusions on the means to reach emission reduction targets (FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.13), the AWG-KP notes the iterative nature of its work programme, and agrees to continue its work in Poznan and, as appropriate, in its work programme for 2009, on the agenda item and all sub-items, including the flexible mechanisms, LULUCF, greenhouse gases sectors, and source categories, and possible approaches targeting sectoral emissions.

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.12 ), the AWG-KP: notes the importance of further assessing possible improvements to the mechanisms and clarifying any implications for the ability of Annex I parties to achieve their mitigation objectives; agrees to continue consideration of these possible improvements in Poznan; and requests the Chair to elaborate on the elements in Annexes I and II based on views submitted previously by parties and the new submissions requested.

title: EMISSIONS TRADING AND THE PROJECT-BASED MECHANISMS:
abstract: This sub-item was introduced in plenary on 21 August and then taken up in contact groups and Friends of the Chair consultations, co-chaired by Christiana Figueres (Costa Rica) and Nuno Lacasta (Portugal).

title: KYOTO PROTOCOL:
abstract: In December 1997, delegates at COP 3 in Kyoto, Japan, agreed to a Protocol to the UNFCCC that commits developed countries and countries in transition to a market economy to achieve emission reduction targets.

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.11 ), the AWG-KP decides to continue its consideration at its resumed sixth session, taking into account the information contained in an annex to the conclusions, and noting Annex IV to the report of the AWG-KP at its resumed fifth session ( FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/3 ).

title: LAND USE, LAND-USE CHANGE AND FORESTRY:
abstract: Issues related to LULUCF were introduced in plenary on Thursday, 21 August, and discussed in contact groups and informal consultations co-chaired by Bryan Smith (New Zealand) and Marcelo Rocha (Brazil).

title: Greenhouse gases, sectors and source categories
abstract: In the contact group, parties agreed on a basket approach to use aggregate carbon dioxide equivalent treatment of greenhouse gases provided for in Article 3 of the Protocol in the second commitment period.

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.15 ), the AWG-KP agrees to continue the use of aggregate carbon dioxide equivalent treatment of greenhouse gases provided for in Article 3 of the Kyoto Protocol ( basket approach ) in the second commitment period, and notes the need to maintain a coherent approach between the Convention and Protocol in relation to Annex I parties commitments.

title: Spillover effects
actors: African Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
abstract: In a contact group meeting focusing on spillover effects, the G-77/China stated that consideration of spillover effects should focus on non-Annex I parties .

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions ( FCCC/KP/AWG/2008/L.10 ), the AWG-KP notes the deliberations on the matter, as well as party submissions.

title: Consideration of relevant methodological issues
abstract: On this agenda sub-item, discussions in the contact group and in consultations were dedicated for the most part to discussing the use of global warming potentials (GWPs) versus global temperature potentials (GTPs).

title: AWG-KP Conclusions
abstract: In its conclusions (FCCC/AWG/2008/L.14), the AWG-KP notes the need to maintain a coherent approach between the Convention and the Protocol, where appropriate, when considering relevant methodological issues in relation to Annex I party commitments.

title: OTHER ISSUES :
abstract: Issues related to greenhouse gases, sectors and source categories, possible approaches targeting sectoral emissions, consideration of relevant methodological issues, and spillover effects were introduced in plenary on Thursday, 21 August, and discussed in a contact group on other issues chaired by AWG-KP Chair Dovland.

title: CLOSING PLENARY
abstract: AWG-KP Chair Dovland convened the AWG-KP closing plenary at 5:38 pm on Wednesday, 27 August.

title: COP 11 AND COP/MOP 1 :
abstract: COP 11 and the first Conference of the Parties serving as the Meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol (COP/MOP 1) took place in Montreal, Canada, from 28 November to 10 December 2005.

title: WHEN TO TALK
abstract: With parties, observers, and the press carefully watching the climate negotiations as they progress from Bali to Copenhagen, there has been a focus on the pace of the negotiations.

title: WHERE TO TALK
actors: Umbrella Group|European Union|Group of 77 and China
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Flexibility Mechanims|Technology Transfer
abstract: As parties prepare for more substantive negotiations over the next year, defining the appropriate forum for discussing key issues has become a hotly contested process.

title: WHAT TO TALK ABOUT
abstract: Workshops on cooperative sectoral approaches and sector-specific actions, and on policy approaches and positive incentives on issues relating to REDD in developing countries, and the role of conservation, sustainable management of forests and enhancement of forest carbon stocks in developing countries, served as significant milestones in consideration of both of these issues, according to many close to the process.

title: TALKING OUR WAY FROM ACCRA TO COPENHAGEN
abstract: Just as delegates expressed mixed hopes upon arrival in Accra, it is no surprise that they expressed mixed opinions about the week upon departure.

title: AWG-KP AND CONVENTION DIALOGUE:
abstract: Between COP 11 and COP 13 in December 2007, the AWG-KP and Convention Dialogue each convened four times.

title: BALI CLIMATE CONFERENCE :
abstract: COP 13 and COP/MOP 3 took place from 3-15 December 2007, in Bali, Indonesia, alongside the resumed fourth session of the AWG-KP.

title: AWG-LCA 1 AND AWG-KP 5:
abstract: The first session of the AWG-LCA and first part of the fifth session of the AWG-KP took place from 31 March to 4 April 2008 in Bangkok, Thailand.

title: SB 28, AWG-LCA 2 AND AWG KP 5:
abstract: During the first two weeks of June 2008, delegates convened in Bonn, Germany, to participate in four meetings as part of ongoing negotiations under the UNFCCC and the Kyoto Protocol.

title: REPORT OF THE MEETINGS
topics: Legal Status of Agreements|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adaptation|Extension of the Kyoto protocol
abstract: The third session of the Ad Hoc Working Group on Long-term Cooperative Action under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and first part of the sixth session of the Ad Hoc Working Group on Further Commitments for Annex I Parties under the Kyoto Protoco l opened on Thursday, 21 August 2008.

title: ENABLING THE FULL, EFFECTIVE AND SUSTAINED IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CONVENTION THROUGH LONG-TERM COOPERATIVE ACTION
actors: Group of 77 and China|Least Developed Countries|Group of 77 and China|Umbrella Group|European Union|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Legal Status of Agreements|Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Reasons for Concern|Post-Kyoto Agreements|forests|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: Discussions on this agenda item focused on the key elements outlined in the Bali Action Plan (decision 1/ CP.13), including a shared vision for long-term cooperative action, mitigation, adaptation, technology and financing.

title: THE POZNAN NEGOTIATIONS
abstract: The climate change talks in Poznan mark the halfway point in an ongoing series of meetings leading to Copenhagen in December 2009, which is the deadline for concluding negotiations under the Bali roadmap.

title: AWG-LCA:
abstract: The AWG-LCA has a mandate to launch a comprehensive process to enable the full, effective and sustained implementation of the Convention through long-term cooperative action, now, up to and beyond 2012.

title: AWG-KP:
abstract: In Accra, the AWG-KP focused on analyzing the means available to reach emission reduction targets and is expected to continue these deliberations in Poznan.

title: COP and COP/MOP
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|forests|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adaptation|Vulnerabilities and Impacts|Technology Transfer
abstract: The COP and COP/MOP will take up a number of routine agenda items, such as administrative and financial matters.

title: COP 14
abstract: COP 13 President Rachmat Witoelar (Indonesia) opened the meeting, describing it as an important bridge from Bali to Copenhagen.

title: ANALYSIS OF MEANS TO REACH EMISSION REDUCTION TARGETS:
abstract: Delegates agreed to hold informal consultations on the flexible mechanisms, co-chaired by Christiana Figueres (Costa Rica) and Nuno Lacasta (Portugal), and on LULUCF, co-chaired by Bryan Smith (New Zealand) and Marcelo Rocha (Brazil).

title: SPILLOVER EFFECTS:
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|Adverse Effects and Response Measure|Technology Transfer
abstract: SAUDI ARABIA said Protocol Articles 2.3 and 3.14 (adverse effects) should govern future actions, and that the AWG-KP should address possible funding, insurance and technology transfer arrangements to minimize adverse impacts on developing countries.

title: SBI 29
topics: UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: Delegates adopted the SBI agenda ( FCCC/SBI/2008/9 ) with the item on information contained in non-Annex I national communications held in abeyance.

actors: European Union|Umbrella Group|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
topics: Financial Mechanisms and Funds|UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol Functioning|Adaptation|Technology Transfer|National Communications and Inventories
abstract: The G-77/CHINA said the Adaptation Fund must be fully operationalized with sufficient and predictable resources, and stressed the principle of direct access.

title: NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS AND GREENHOUSE GAS INVENTORY DATA FROM ANNEX I PARTIES:

abstract: The SBI noted information on these issues (FCCC/SBI/2008/12, Corr.1 and FCCC/SBI/2008/INF.7).

actors: European Union|Umbrella Group|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States
abstract: Belize, for AOSIS, underlined the need to discuss risk assessment and management.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER:
abstract: EGTT Chair Jukka Uosukainen (Finland) reported on the EGTT s work (FCCC/SB/2008/INF.5-8).

title: ORGANIZATIONAL MATTERS:
abstract: Parties agreed to continue applying the draft rules of procedure with the exception of draft rule 42 on voting.

abstract: Antigua and Barbuda, for the G-77/CHINA, lamented that the negotiations have not reflected the sense of urgency about climate change and called for progress on the AWG-KP and developed country commitments.

title: AWG-LCA 4

title: OPENING STATEMENTS:
actors: European Union|Umbrella Group|African Group|Group of 77 and China|Alliance of Small Island States

abstract: The G-77/CHINA stressed its proposals on financing and technology, and the need to organize the AWG-LCA s work in a manner that allows for effective participation.

title: WORK PROGRAMME FOR 2009:
abstract: Chair Machado noted that the issue of convening an additional session in 2009 would have to be decided in PoznaÅ.

abstract: The G-77/CHINA expressed concern over slow progress and said conclusions on several agenda items should be adopted in PoznaÅ.

abstract: On this item (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/INFs.1 and 3 and MISC.10), SAUDI ARABIA, NORWAY, the EU, JAPAN and others supported including CCS under the CDM.

abstract: On this item (FCCC/SBSTA/2008/8), Chair Plume will prepare draft conclusions. PROTOCOL ARTICLE 2.3 (ADVERSE EFFECTS): A joint SBI/SBSTA contact group on Protocol Article 2.3 and Article 3.14 will be chaired by Kamel Djemouai (Algeria) and Kristin Tilley (Australia).

abstract: Delegates continued their discussions, with many interventions focusing on mitigation action by developed countries, as well as linkages between a shared vision and the objective and principles of the Convention.

abstract: SBI Chair Asadi explained that this SBI-mandated round table aimed to exchange experiences, lessons and best practices in planning and implementing actions to address adverse effects of climate change and the impact of response measures.

abstract: Co-Chairs Kleymeyer and Macey explained that the draft text would be circulated only after the plenary statements have been completed and said this session would focus on procedural issues.

abstract: The AWG-KP agreed to discuss various agenda items together.

abstract: In the contact group, delegates addressed concerns raised in the previous session.

EGTT Chair Jukka Uosukainen proposed options for cooperation, such as a global pooling of funds, increased public sector investment, and incentives for greater private sector investment.
